TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Religion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The U.N. declaration on the elimination of all forms of intolerance and of discrimination based on Religion and Belief.
(a)Denies the Freedom of Religion guaranteed in the Australian Constitution
(b)Is designed to impede or oppose the Biblical life and ministry of the Christian Church
(c)Is being introduced as law to bring changes to our nation that were rejected by the people in the last Referendum on the Constitution.
We therefore ask the Senate to take all steps to have this Declaration disallowed from the HREOC Act 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Religion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

1.That the declaration by the Attorney-General, dated 8 February, 1993 of the United Nations Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief, made under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, be disallowed by members of the Senate.
2.As the terms of the Declaration are vague and imprecise and its potential impact is unclear, (particularly in the area of the authority of parents over children) and

3.That it is doubtful whether the Australian situation warrants the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission being given power with respect to religious freedom beyond those contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which is already incorporated into the HREOC Act.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners: Shares
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
The legislation passed in December 1992 to count the increases in the value of shares held by pensioners as income, even if the shares are never sold to realise the gain:
(1) Is unjust.
(2) Has its most detrimental effect on pensioners with small holdings.
(3) Only affects Australian Stock Exchange listed shares.
(4) Discourages small scale investment in Australian companies.
Your Petitioners request that the amendments in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (no 3) 1992 relating to unrealised capital gains on shares should be repealed.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: That the Senate consider proposing amendments to the Child Care Act with regard to the current policy on Attendance Records

PARA.TAB: because:

PETITION.PARA: The Attendance Records are impractical for Family Day Care services.
Family Day Carers homes are not set up with separate office facilities, as Child Care Centres are.
Children who are transported to and from school may require the parent or responsible person to sign four times each day for each child.
Carers are responsible for making sure parents sign their children in and out each day.
The issue of accountability is not addressed by the Attendance Records.

PARA.TAB: We wish the Minister to look at proposed amendments. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate consider these amendments.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:

PARA.TAB: 1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PETITION.PARA: The United Nations declaration on the elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion and Belief:
prohibits all forms of religious discrimination, thus potentially restricting the freedom of Australians to make any choices on the grounds of their belief;
could lead to US-style prohibitions on public Christian prayers, Christmas carols, or nativity scenes;
has the potential, according to the NSW Attorney-General, to restrict greatly the freedom of religious groups.
and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12-16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only the legally-weak term "respect" for the rights of parents in Article 5;
could result in Government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:

PARA.TAB: Act to disallow these two international instruments from the HREOC Act.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 6PR
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned call on the Senate to support the granting of a narrowcast broadcast licence, to allow Radio 6PR's talk back programs to continue broadcasting.
We understand that the failure of the Minister to grant this licence will result in job losses and the cancellation of vital afternoon talk back programs.

We believe that the Honourable Minister for Communications, Senator Bob Collins, should give his immediate and special consideration to the granting of a narrowcast licence to allow the vital role 6PR plays in Western Australia to continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to speak on behalf of a distinguished lawyer who alleges defamation under privilege.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about a matter which a distinguished lawyer has raised with me. It concerns the response from Mr Dennis Rose QC, an eminent QC from the Attorney-General's Department, which was made during a hearing before the Senate Select Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Mr Geoff Petersson became most concerned when a person of Mr Rose's eminence passed what he saw as a slighting remark about his professional ability.

PARA.TAB: I have raised this matter with Senator Cooney, who is the chairman of the committee. He tells me that the committee will be producing a report shortly, but cannot specify the exact date. It is right and proper that the record be put straight as soon as possible and I feel correction cannot await the uncertain date of the report. Accordingly, I now take steps to put the record straight for the benefit of Mr Petersson.

I have a letter that was sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs relating to its reference on the constitutional validity of the provisions of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At the hearing of the Committee in relation to the above reference on Thursday 9 September 1993, during the course of his giving evidence, Mr Dennis Rose may have, perhaps inadvertently, misled the Committee when referring to a submission to the Committee prepared by me on behalf of the Taxation Institute.
At page 15 of the transcript Mr Rose is reported as saying:

"Mr Morris talked of the opinions that have been given and the opinions by Dr Howard and himself and Mr Petersson. I suppose one can regard that last one as the Taxation Institute opinion. I am not aware of Mr Petersson having any expertise in constitutional law. It may be that he does but I am not aware of it.

I find it surprising that Mr Rose could have stated that he was not aware whether I had any expertise in constitutional law given that I have worked closely with Mr Rose over the 17 years in which I worked as a lawyer in the Attorney-General's Department between 1972 and 1989. During that time I held various senior positions in the then Advisings Division (now Office of General Counsel) working within that Division in the Constitutional and Financial Branch, the Constitutional, Broadcasting and Administrative Branch, and the Constitutional and Electoral Branch. During that period I spent two years as Principal Legal Officer, Assistant to the Solicitor-General assisting in the preparation of cases and opinions, many involving

questions of constitutional law. During the time I spent in the Advisings Division, Mr Rose held positions of Branch Head and Divisional Head. On more than one occasion, Mr Rose and I occupied adjacent offices.

I think it is fair to say that by any measure I have had considerable experience in dealing with, and advising on constitutional law matters over a long period of time. Whether this experience may be said to give rise to expertise in constitutional law is another matter. However, Mr Rose's response implies that he is unaware as to whether I have had experience in advising on constitutional issues. This is clearly not so.
I would respectfully request that your Committee's report should note my concern.
Yours faithfully,
Geoff Petersson
Technical Director
That letter is from Mr Petersson of the Taxation Institute of Australia. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Panizza's motion to refer the operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, ATSIC, the Aboriginal Legal Service, ALS, and any other body, company or corporation which receives funding from ATSIC with particular regard to accountability, et cetera to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I will not read out the details of the motion.

PARA.TAB: I support Senator Panizza's motion because of a number of things which have been brought to my attention with regard to ATSIC and which, I believe, need investigating from the point of view of the accountability and the management of that body. As Senator Panizza highlighted in his speech, a number of leaders in the Aboriginal communities in Western Australia also support this motion. I particularly refer to Robert Isaacs, a prominent Aboriginal in Western Australia, who also happens to be on the shire council of Gosnells.

I want to highlight a couple of points here about the accountability, the spending, the functioning and the operations of ATSIC. The first issue brought to my attention—which, I am told, is fairly typical of what is happening in many instances—revolves around an effort by a group of Aboriginals to develop a business in a country town in Western Australia. I will not name that country town because people will know who I am speaking about and those individuals could be put under some unfair pressure.

That group endeavoured to get assistance through ATSIC to purchase a tyre business in which they had worked for a number of years in conjunction with the owner, who wished to sell the business. After some 18 months of effort, toing-and-froing and not being able to get satisfactory answers as to what had happened to their application, how it was being accounted for and how it was being processed, finally, that particular operator had to sell the business.

It seems to me to be not quite right that a group of Aboriginals, who were totally self-supporting but who needed some capital assistance to give themselves the opportunity to become commercially viable in their own business, was denied that assistance purely and simply because of the financial management and accountability processes within ATSIC. Even to this day, as far as I am aware, they have not received a satisfactory answer to their problem.

The other points I wish to raise in this debate come from some documents which were given to me—or to use the commonly used term from the newspaper, were leaked to me—just last week. They refer to the operations of ATSIC in Western Australia. I find the issues I raise particularly despicable and disappointing.

Western Australia has some 1,300 Aboriginal families currently seeking assistance to get into their own homes or to get a roof over their heads. These documents were presented at the meetings of ATSIC commissioners from 9 to 12 August 1993. We see in terms of community housing development that of the $48.6 million allocated to Western Australia for Aboriginal housing, only $40.8 million was spent. One must ask, when you have a situation where, as I said, there are some 1,300 Aboriginal families currently seeking to get their own homes or a roof over their heads, why $8 million was returned to the Commonwealth.

I put on the public record that I believe that three most important things in dealing with Aboriginal problems or concerns that we have in this nation are housing, health and education. The first is housing. I think it is absolutely imperative that this particular aspect be addressed in a sensitive and fair manner and that it be done in such a way that it caters not only for the community Aboriginals who, basically, live in the north or central Australia, but also for regional Aboriginals and for those termed `fringe dwellers'. I do not particularly like that term, but that is the term that is used consistently.

It was recently reported that in Kalgoorlie one-third of the Aboriginals under the age of 40 had passed on in the last 18 to 20 months. We can see that this question of housing is, indeed, a very important one. It is something that I believe this committee could look at in terms of accountability, functions and expenditure, and in terms of why, when we have this serious situation in Western Australia, this money was returned to the Commonwealth.

I have already mentioned the housing situation. In order of importance, the next matter is health. I believe that housing and health are linked inextricably together. Next on my list is education. These documents highlight that of the $11.7 million which was allocated for health in Western Australia, $700,000 was not spent. Substance abuse is another problem that, unfortunately, the Aboriginals have had to deal with. Some $1.4 million was spent in this area.

On the other side of the coin are major Mabo bids. This document shows quite clearly the government's position as far as Aboriginals are concerned. The emphasis is not on the matters that I raised, which are very important and which Aboriginal people consistently bring before me and Senator Panizza and other colleagues of mine in Western Australia. This document says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided that;
the $10 million is to be removed from the Commission's global allocation in 1994-95 . . .
It goes on to say something which I find absolutely disgraceful:
Atsic may retain the $10 million as part of the Commission's contribution to the Mabo response IF:
(a) the Ministers for Finance and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs can:
(i) Define activities on which the funds can be spent; and
(ii) provide for consultation prior to the expenditure of the funds between the Minister and ATSIC; and
(b) the Commission accepts that Mabo expenditure within ATSIC's budget would not be limited to the earmarked $10 million.

I think this highlights very clearly the importance of this inquiry. First of all, we are seeing the government directing that $10 million be taken out of ATSIC's global allocation, which could and would be spent on such things as housing, health and education, and holding a gun at its head, threatening, `Unless you spend the money this way, we will take it away from you. You will not get it'. The government is hiding behind ATSIC and trying to make ATSIC the bad boy for what I believe in many instances to be the false expectations that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has built up around the Mabo decision. I emphasise that for the vast majority of Aboriginals there are far more important things than Mabo.

PARA.TAB: I grew up in a country district and spent the whole of my primary school career attending a school at Bindi Bindi, where there were more Aboriginal children than there were children of European origin. I got to know Aboriginal people pretty darn well. They taught me a lot of things that today I feel very privileged to have learnt. Hopefully I taught them one or two things.

I believe that this motion by Senator Panizza is not only important but crucial. It is not only Senator Panizza who is asking for this reference, supported by his colleagues; it is also many Aboriginal people who feel that they are being misled and thwarted by some of the things that have been happening.

They cannot understand why in Western Australia, for example, as I have mentioned, when those 1,300 people want to get a home, a roof over their head, that $8 million is returned to the Commonwealth. They cannot understand why in terms of the operations of ATSIC—and I must say in its original format the only basis on which I personally supported it was that it would give Aboriginals some independence, a say in how they sorted out their destiny—we see the government through the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) saying, `Unless you spend this $10 million on Mabo related claims, burn it up with lawyers and in the legal processes'—in most instances for little or no return—`we will take the money away from you'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even though I know that most honourable senators will have listened attentively to the first three minutes of my speech on Monday night—
—I did.

—I thank the minister. Just to put my own thoughts in perspective, I will reiterate some of my opening remarks with regard to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1993. The stated purpose of the original Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992 was unclear other than to encourage expenditure on the lease of new capital or the upgrading of existing capital in certain large enterprises. It must be remembered that the cost of imported capital has already decreased as a result of decreases in tariffs. Employment creation was obviously not a criterion.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth legislation claimed that the allowances were for industries with an effective rate of assistance of less than 10 per cent. Up until 2 September 1993, 80 per cent of projects registered are in the manufacturing and mining sectors. To give honourable senators an idea of what the allowance was meant for, let me quote the One Nation statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government wishes to build on this advantage and promote an early upturn in investment in new plant and equipment for projects which offer particular benefits for Australia's competitiveness in world markets.

The broad criteria intended to identify such projects relate to the absence of any substantial assistance or protection. This was mentioned in relation to the rate of assistance being less than 10 per cent. The broad criteria state:
.positive facilitation by State and local governments in relation to such matters as project approval processes—
For that read fast-tracking—

and, where appropriate, the economic and efficient pricing of inputs under the control of public utilities and statutory marketing authorities. Where a need for similar or complementary action at the Commonwealth level is identified, it will be taken
.employers and employees committing to management and industrial relations arrangements which promote the achievement of world best practice.

How does this link with the states actually work? In Western Australia it came out in a report called The WA Advantage. I was somewhat horrified at the time because, according to that report those projects which would be disadvantaged would be the ones that would not receive special attention and administrative assistance. Those were projects with a capital investment of less than $50 million; those employing less than 100 people—that is, the majority of Australian businesses; those producing for the local market; and those not requiring significant infrastructure to be provided by the state.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the major rubs. The state government in Western Australia, in linking with the Commonwealth legislation, said, of the projects to be identified, that one of the identifying criteria was the creation of significant infrastructure which was required by the state. That is assistance, but somehow or other it did not get added in. If, as part of the criteria, the state were required to provide cheaper inputs like electricity and water, that is also assistance, but this somehow or other did not get added into the 10 per cent. The other criterion was that those people who were disadvantaged were those who were not requiring an environmental clearance, including many who were helping to repair the environmental damage. The other people who were disadvantaged by this package were those not impacting on Aboriginal reserves, national parks or areas of major land use conflicts.

The way it worked in Western Australia was that the Commonwealth legislation worked in with Western Australian legislation which actually singled out large, imposing projects which had major environmental impacts or major impacts on Aboriginal land, or which required large amounts of state government assistance. The way the actual legislation worked in Western Australia was contradictory. In other words, apart from fast tracking and reduced tariffs on electricity and water in Western Australia, the selection criterion was that the community had already contributed to the projects' infrastructure costs.

Considering that in Western Australia there are already a number of other built-in subsidies, such as reduced royalties, it would appear that the development allowance has already defeated its own purpose. In other words, this so-called development allowance is operated as a job shedding subsidy to industries which are already heavily subsidised by the community, even without costing in the environmental costs of such subsidies. In the absence of any real information that such an allowance is not simply allowing large corporations to benefit even more at the expense of employment, the Greens (WA) senators cannot support the expansion of this scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1993 is to extend the development allowance to projects in the motor vehicle and printing production industries. Somewhat surprisingly, there is a further amendment to this amendment bill to extend the proposed definition of the `ancillary printing plant' to include units placing inserts into magazines, newspapers and periodicals—an amendment which, to the cynical eye, has all the elements of pressure from particular vested interests.

PARA.TAB: The Senate will be aware that the principal act had its genesis in the February 1992 One Nation statement. The development allowance measure currently before the Senate provides a tax deduction of 10 per cent on eligible plant during the first year of installation or use. The allowance is in addition to the generous depreciation allowances. Eligible projects must have a capital cost of over $50 million and be approved by a special statutory authority called the Development Allowance Authority.

The government's objective at the time was to provide an incentive to promote an early upturn in investment, especially in the state-of-the-art technology involving new plant and equipment and, thus, the shedding of jobs—in summary, projects which offered benefits to improve Australia's competitiveness in world markets. That was the theory through the One Nation statement.

But even then, in 1992, the Liberal-National Party coalition had a number of difficulties with the original bill. Firstly, it discriminated against projects with a capital cost of less than $50 million. Secondly, it did nothing for investment in plant and equipment in the poorest areas of the economy—those that need fixing. But due to its haste of passage and shortly after its enactment, the principal act, not surprisingly, was amended because it was too restrictive. It needed to allow a greater flexibility to permit the aggregation of two or more joint venture projects involving new and existing plant. In other words, it was so hastily conceived that it was unworkable.

A change was effected to permit a combination of long-term lease arrangements with short-term owned equipment. We have before the Senate today an amendment to the proposed amendment to extend the allowance to include the motor vehicle industry and the print media. We are extending it even further to allow installations to include the newspaper folding machines so that these big newspapers can get a bigger segment of the advertising market; they will be able to compete with others because their costs of production will be much more efficient.

By the end of June 1993, registered projects were worth something like $14.5 billion. That might appear to be a significant figure but, compared with the estimate, it fell far short of the original figure. While the government is still confident—this government is always confident—of reaching the much touted figure of $130 billion, the attainment of such a venturous goal is dependent on the overall level of confidence in the global economy. That is certainly beyond the par of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). The next two years do not indicate an environment of strong growth to sustain such an optimistic outcome. We are used to predictions of optimistic outcomes and the subsequent revelation of those outcomes not being achieved.

During the election campaign, the Prime Minister gave great prominence to the impact of this alleged $130 billion investment that would bring in the much needed recovery. In fact, the new measures introduced in the amendment bill originated during the heat of the 1993 election campaign when the Prime Minister, in desperate measures, was determined to try to woo back the business vote to his government. Mr Keating believed that a sharp reduction in the corporate tax rate to 33 per cent, plus an extension of the development allowance to include the motor vehicle industry and the print media, would catch the corporate vote. But we have now found that there has been a bit of a sting to the 33 per cent corporate tax rate because it has created a whole lot of anomalies.

Those anomalies are giving rise to further pieces of legislation which will shortly be debated in the Senate. They include draconian measures to tighten up fringe benefits; one will have to spend $1.27 to get a $1 deduction. There are a lot of inconsistencies. The issues have not been thought through and this is one of them.

I wish to use the second reading debate to foreshadow a committee stage amendment whereby the Liberal-National Party coalition, in a sense of fairness and equity, will be seeking to remove the $50 million threshold—a threshold that excludes small business from this very generous concession which is being granted to the larger corporations involving the publication and the print industry. As explained earlier, in addition to the normal depreciation deduction, qualifying corporations are entitled to an extra deduction equal to 10 per cent of the eligible expenditure before the determination of taxable income.

Good taxation law requires an adherence to the concept of neutrality and equality in that, in the determination of taxable income, all taxpayers in the same industry should be entitled to the same deductions and they should be assessed on the same taxable income. But it is not so. This government positively discriminates against the smaller operators and positively discriminates in favour of the big barons. This amendment is all about giving a special concession—a special benefit—to those entrepreneurs big enough to spend $50 million plus in greenfield development that will make them world competitive.

What are these industries in the print media—I will exclude the motor vehicle industry because I think it has an entitlement because it is starting to export—going to do to our export income? How much income is generated from the overseas sale of big Australian newspapers in a particular year compared with the income generated from the iron, coal, wheat, wool and other industries? It is a special concession to the vested interests of those who have been able to get to the ear of some prominent people in government. It is quite unfair.

The Liberal-National coalition seeks to take away this discrimination. I am horrified that the smaller parties cannot see the fairness of this particular scheme. Are they in favour of the small person? Are they in favour of small business? After all, these are the areas which are keeping people in employment. It is the big firms that are shedding the jobs. I do not mind companies becoming more internationally competitive, but let it be in terms of the legislation that we put before this house, a house which supposedly looks after people's interests, neutrality, fairness and equality. We should make sure that when we pass legislation it will reflect that degree of fairness and not give a competitive edge to the big players vis-a-vis the small players.

This parliament rightly recognises that there are special circumstances for disadvantaged people—the poor and the needy—and these taxpayers need special consideration. But in this bill there is a deliberate discrimination in favour of the rich and powerful who will be able to use this generous tax concession to further improve their profits and their market share as against the smaller operators who are competing. I think the opposition's amendment that I am foreshadowing, which removes that threshold, deserves support.

Where there is positive assistance through the tax mechanism, the larger corporations will be able to reduce their unit costs and improve their competitive position over the smaller and generally less financially secure firms. Admittedly, if this amendment is successful, they will have to move very fast because of the time constraints. But at least it would let us give the right appearance and let them have the opportunity, if they can move, to take advantage of a concession that is given to the rich and powerful.

I certainly hope the Senate will endorse the amendment proposed by the opposition in the interests of equity and fairness and not give an advantage to those who are already in a powerful state. After all, this amendment defies the original intent to make industry world competitive in order to increase export income. The government would be moving against one of the very important tenets that helped get it elected—that is, to make Australian industry world competitive. I urge the Senate to support the amendment that I now foreshadow.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am at a bit of a loss as to whether I should make a passionate speech in response to Senator Watson's foreshadowed amendment or a reasoned and responsible response to what were otherwise considered second reading debate speeches by a number of honourable senators. In reality, I should make my response to Senator Watson's impassioned pleas at the committee stage, but I will make some comments now and try not to unduly extend the consideration of the Senate by speaking twice on the matter.

PARA.TAB: The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1993 is not in itself a major amendment. It has the potential to have some significant positive economic benefits and it is therefore welcome. To the extent that it will create an incentive which leads to further major investment in Australia and therefore generate jobs, exports and the economic success that we need to assist and increase the rate of recovery in the Australian economy, it is a welcome measure.

I thank the Senate—including individuals in other parties who may, if they were in government, have proceeded otherwise—for the support given to the fact that this is at least an attempt to engender more investment and create more jobs for Australians. While in this chamber we disagree, sometimes vehemently, about the most appropriate mechanisms for achieving economic growth and creating jobs for Australians, we share the objective that it is a desirable outcome and a necessary and proper responsibility of the government to be concerned about seeking to encourage public and private investment—in this instance, private investment—in a way that will create jobs for Australians.

That is the essence of this amendment. It reflects commitments which we made during the election campaign. I was surprised to hear an indication that this was in some way in conflict with our election commitments because it was an explicit commitment that we made during the election campaign. We are honouring that election commitment. I think it is something we should have done, and it is something we are obliged to do after having made that commitment.

I will not take the time of the Senate unnecessarily by reiterating those things which are central to the Development Allowance Authority concept itself, which is not being essentially changed by this bill. It is merely amending the principal act to extend the development allowance to projects in the motor vehicle industry and certain printing production aspects of projects in the print media. I think there is a very reasonable prospect that this will lead to even further welcome investment, as the Development Allowance Authority already has, and as the potential in the areas covered by the original bill would suggest. I am sure that, notwithstanding differences that senators may have about matters of detail, it will be welcome to the extent that it engenders new investment and new jobs. Therefore, I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson said that he was horrified at the thought that the minor parties might not support him. I suspect that some of his colleagues, if they ever thought they would be in government, would be horrified at the thought that they might support this amendment. The last thing they would want is for this amendment to be carried.

PARA.TAB: I in no way reflect on Senator Watson's integrity in putting forward the proposal because we have debated these sorts of issues too often; I understand the approach he takes on this matter. But the opposition collectively puts forward rhetoric to the effect that it wants to reduce outlays, but it involves proposals that will always cost a lot of money. We get rhetoric that it wants to reduce the public sector, but in the form of proposals that will always require massive increases in the administrative burden.

We are talking about a fundamental change to the nature and whole purpose of the proposal at great cost to revenue. The proposal will not produce the benefits which are the underlying rationale for the Development Allowance Authority, which are not just to generate investment and jobs, as fundamental as that it is, but to do so in a way that encourages large scale, world competitive investment to assist Australia in the increasingly competitive international environment in which we find ourselves.

Regardless of what happens in the GATT and the outcome of international trade negotiations, communications and technology changes mean inevitably that countries will have to compete internationally. There will be more competition in areas that we do not currently envisage. The old boundaries of geography are breaking down and we need to provide assistance, within the limits of our capacity, to investors in Australia to use this as a base from which they can compete successfully in that environment. We are increasing the cost beyond that which the government believes is responsible in budgetary terms—there has been a significant increase in revenue forgone for the government—and we are reducing the focus and targeting of the benefit.

For those reasons I do not believe this is a responsible amendment in the circumstances. We want a tax system that effectively encourages investment and generates jobs. We now have before us a proposal that would be a very significant cost to revenue without the consequent economic benefits that the Development Allowance Authority proposal is designed to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that a number of the earlier benchmarks have been revised to accommodate the new entrants. This is where it differs significantly from the original One Nation proposal. Those benchmarks were removed admittedly as a result of pressure during the heat of an election campaign. Both the motor car industry and the print media were previously excluded from the development allowance in the 1992 legislation because they failed the eligibility test in the principal act. The mechanics of the matter are that both industries now have until either 30 December 1993 or 28 days after this act receives royal assent, whichever is the latter, to lodge the application.

PARA.TAB: I admitted during my speech on second reading that if the Senate accepts this amendment, the smaller operators will have to act pretty speedily. So the concept that was raised in the very thoughtful contribution of my colleague Senator McMullan was that it would cause a problem for the deficit, et cetera. There will not be too many people who will be in a position to actually take advantage of this situation. Again, it is a question of fairness. So I remind the Senate that the initiatives will assist the development of greenfield site projects.

Such amendments should be viewed with suspicion by the smaller operators, particularly in the printing industry, who will see their share of the market eroded as a further result of the lower costs of production by those who have access to capital and who now have access to this very generous concession—a concession that is not available to the smaller, though maybe entrepreneurial, more successful competitor.

The government is trying to further entrench the newspaper and other print media in the hands of what I might call an entrepreneurial elite. The problem I see with this amendment and another reason why we believe it is fair and equitable to extend it to all people to ensure that we do not give a positive discrimination in favour of the entrepreneurial elite is the criterion of contributing to export income. The government has deliberately removed such a benchmark—it was admirable in the One Nation statement—to suit particular vested interests. I do not think this is fair to the rest of Australia and those other participants in the print media.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:

PARA.TAB: ", but the Senate:
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for the Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage provides limited compensation for expenses incurred for clean-up operations, preventative measures, damage to property and economic loss; and

(ii)the Convention supplements existing mandatory and voluntary compensation regimes and will increase the amount of compensation for oil pollution damage available to Australian interests for claims involving "quantifiable economic loss" to $120 million, increasing to $400 million when the amending Protocol to the Convention enters into force; and

(iii)a major oil pollution incident in an environmentally sensitive area such as the Great Barrier Reef may substantially impact upon tourism, commercial fisheries and other marine-based industries and the claims for compensation arising from such an incident may go beyond the scope of the Convention compensation regimes, particularly claims for non-economic loss and claims by indigenous groups;

PARA.TAB: (b)recognises actions by the Australian Government to accord the highest possible level of environmental protection from shipping activities to Australian coastal waters including:

TAB.TAB: (i)the response to the report, "Ships of Shame—Inquiry into Ship Safety", by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure;
(ii)the preventative measures taken by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority including the introduction of compulsory pilotage in the Great Barrier Reef area; and
(iii)the review of Australia's national contingency plan to respond to marine oil spills;

PARA.TAB: (c)recommends that Australia continue to develop effective means to include in an international comprehensive liability regime compensation for environmental harm and non-economic loss from marine based oil pollution; and

(d)resolves, that there be laid on the table of the Senate, by the Minister for Transport and Communications, on or before the last sitting day in 1994 a report setting out developments in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill 1993 and the three cognate bills provide for the legal regime that will enable Australia to become part of the International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution. While the Greens (WA) are not opposing the legislation, we are moving this amendment to the motion to express some of the concerns raised by the environment movement to the convention and the two protocols.

PARA.TAB: As has been said before, the convention establishes a fund for the compensation of oil pollution damage. The fund has a number of problems. Firstly, the fund, even if the 1992 protocol is adopted, limits claims for compensation to $400 million. Whilst this may seem a significant amount, this is the maximum that can be claimed for any one spill. Some have estimated that the clean-up bill for the Exxon Valdez spill alone was $US3 billion. The figure of $400 million would have to cover all economic and commercial losses, as well as clean-up and remediation costs.

Secondly, the fund defines oil pollution damage in a way that excludes compensation for non-economic loss and damage to the environment. This also excludes the possibility of Aboriginal groups claiming for loss and damage to areas of cultural and spiritual significance and for loss of natural resources for non-economic purposes.

Thirdly, the convention does not establish a provision for liability by negligent acts or omissions. The convention is about compensation; it is not about prevention or liability. It does not alter the actions of shipping companies who use flags of convenience to register substandard or poorly maintained vessels, nor does it provide a disincentive for Australian based companies who profit by placing Australia's environment at risk in this way.

The Greens (WA) recognise that the limitations expressed above are not able to be rectified in this legislation. However, that does not mean that Australia should not try at both the national and international level to use its best efforts to protect and preserve the environment and safeguard the rights of indigenous people.

In particular, we would like to acknowledge the very successful work of Australia's international negotiators in implementing the compulsory pilotage scheme in the Great Barrier Reef. The introduction, under international law, of such a regime demonstrates that Australia has a significant role to play in the development of an international regime for environmental liability.

I would like to add that the rest of Australia is not included in such a pilotage scheme. In Western Australia we have a very significant reef at Ningaloo which is not covered by any such pilotage. There are many other sensitive areas around Australia which suffer the same risk. It is not that pilotage itself prevents an accident, but it reduces the risk significantly. Therefore, we are not actually doing anything which will necessarily stop the risk of this happening in most parts of Australia.

We are very pleased that the government and the opposition are supporting the motion before us today. The Australian Democrats are also supporting the motion. Indeed, it was Senator Coulter, in his second reading speech on 20 May 1993, who outlined his major concerns about the convention that have resulted in this motion today. The motion picks up the major concerns outlined by Senator Coulter and we acknowledge the work of Senator Coulter on this matter.

The Greens (WA) acknowledge also that the motion before the Senate is not as strong as it perhaps could be. We also acknowledge that part 3 of the motion mentions neither national action nor land based marine pollution. In the first part, we acknowledge the views of both the government and the opposition that Australia should not go it alone in developing a comprehensive liability regime. While we acknowledge this position, we do not support it. Rather we feel that with this motion the Senate makes it clear that Australia, and the nations of the world, must pursue at an international level the vexed question of liability for environmental harm.

This does not mean that we will abandon attempts by organisations such as Greenpeace Australia and the Australian Conservation Foundation to promote the necessity for uniform national laws covering marine pollution from both land based and sea based sources. Indeed, it is useful to place on the record the need for such legislation and suggest that it is appropriate that the final report of the Resource Assessment Commission's inquiry into coastal zone management, soon to be presented to parliament, be given serious consideration by the government to the repeal of the various acts implemented by the Offshore Constitutional Settlement in 1980. The restriction of the motion dealing with marine based oil pollution and not land based pollution has been done to avoid any need for the matter to be referred back to cabinet due to land based marine pollution being a matter of a different department.

The final matter at issue relates to the presentation of the report to the minister. The Greens (WA) are not opposing the legislation because we realise that it is the international convention that contains the problems. We commend the amendment to the Senate and thank the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, and the shadow minister for their support on the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the amendment moved by Senator Margetts. As she indicated, the opposition has been involved in the discussions that have gone on leading up to this point. I will not make a further speech on the matter as the opposition's position in relation to the whole package of bills was dealt with in May. I understand why Senator Margetts, who was not in the parliament in May, would want to make some remarks at this stage, but I do not believe it is necessary for us to do so as our position in support of the bills and of this amendment is clear.

—As Senator Margetts has indicated, we will also be supporting this amendment. I want to make three points reiterating some of the points that she made in her speech, which, as she said, I made back in May. We are concerned that there are limitations under this regime. It is quite conceivable that there could be losses which far and away exceed the amounts covered. We recognise, however, the danger to fuel imports for a small nation like Australia if it should seek to have unlimited liability. For those sorts of balancing reasons we have supported this legislation.

PARA.TAB: We are also concerned about the non-economic loss. Senator Margetts has pointed to traditional uses of the environment which may be damaged. I do not think one need even extend into the Aboriginal area how the sheer enjoyment of the environment by many people can be damaged in non-economic ways. There is no compensation within this legislation for those sorts of losses.

The final point I would like to make is that at the request of some of the conservation groups, I was responsible for sending this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I want to put on the record that I believe the Senate committee system, which allows people to come in and have an input into legislation at the very point at which it is being debated in this parliament, is a very important one. It is a very important part of the democratic process.

But in this particular case those conservation groups which had indicated an interest in appearing were rather lax in coming forward and one group failed to appear altogether. If this Senate has provided that mechanism for such groups, a mechanism that I strongly support, I think they need to recognise that the business of the Senate is complex and time consuming, and they need to respond to those opportunities. I was quite disappointed that in this particular case that opportunity was not fully taken up and accepted. Having said that, I support this amendment put by Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to amend the Australian Citizenship Act of 1948. Firstly, it seeks to insert a preamble, to quote the government, `giving recognition to the significance of Australian citizenship'. Secondly, it seeks to amend the citizenship act to abolish the current oath or affirmation of allegiance and to replace it with a so-called pledge of commitment. Thirdly, and consequent upon that second amendment, it seeks to remove all reference to allegiance to the Queen as head of state from the commitment made by new citizens on taking the grant of citizenship.

PARA.TAB: So far as the last of those three objectives of the bill is concerned, this is not the first time that the Labor government has attempted to delete reference to the Crown from the oath and affirmation. It was attempted in 1973 and again in 1984. On both those occasions the attempt was defeated in the Senate. In 1984 it was defeated by the coalition with the support of the Don Chipp led Australian Democrats.

I very much regret that in 1993, when this issue and this bill are again being debated, the indication is that the Australian Democrats will not be maintaining their opposition to the deletion of reference to the Crown—the centrepiece of our constitution—from the wording of the, be it called an oath or an affirmation or a pledge, that new citizens are required to make. I do hope that, in the course of this debate and before a final vote is taken on the bill, the Democrats will reconsider their position.

At the time of its introduction into the parliament on 6 May this year I said, on behalf of the coalition, that we considered this bill to be premature and that it was designed to pre-empt the debate—in particular, the republican debate—on possible changes to our constitution. I stressed that so long as the Queen remains our head of state and the Crown remains the centrepiece of our constitution, new citizens should continue to be required to state publicly their allegiance to the Crown and, therefore, to the constitution and all the institutions that underpin our nation.

The Senate, at the coalition's initiative, referred the bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration. That committee produced a divided report. The majority of the committee, being Labor senators, supported the bill. The coalition members of the committee—Senator Vanstone, Senator Kemp and Senator O'Chee—expressed their opposition. Nothing that occurred in that committee and in its public hearings has allayed the coalition's concerns about the bill or has in any way altered the coalition's formal position of total opposition to the bill at this time.

In saying that, I emphasise that the coalition is not being negative or reactionary about the matter. We are simply saying that these matters should follow a due and orderly process of consideration. If the Australian community opts, in time, for a change in our constitutional arrangements, if in time we decide to replace our existing constitutional monarchy with some form of republican structure, that will be the time to make the relevant changes to our oath, allegiance or whatever form of words we use, but not before then.

With this bill, the government has put the cart before the horse. It has done so quite deliberately. It is a deliberate, calculated attempt by a calculated, opportunistic government and Prime Minister to hijack the republican debate. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has totally misread the mood of the Australian public on this and, in his desperate push for a republic, has quickly proved himself to be the most divisive Prime Minister in Australia's history. That will come back not just to haunt him and his government; it will be of very grave concern to the future of the Australian nation and Australian society.

The coalition will not have a bar of contributing to that division. I note in passing in that respect that the Australian public seems to be waking up to the Prime Minister's secret agenda on this issue. He should very carefully heed the result of the latest opinion polls on the republic issue published in today's press. A poll taken last weekend after the Olympic bid decision was announced showed a very significant swing against a republic since the last poll was taken, with a majority of Australians now favouring the retention of our present constitutional arrangements.

As well as that issue, there are other very important reasons why the coalition is opposed to this bill. I will elaborate on these in more detail a little later. However, in summary, the citizenship act needs a total rewrite. This bill makes no attempt whatsoever to tackle the basic weaknesses and deficiencies in the act. As I say, it is essentially another attempt by the Labor Party to force the pace of the republican push and to pre-empt the outcome of the emerging debate on constitutional issues.

It represents a further significant weakening of the commitment required of new citizens. A `pledge'—which is the word now being used to replace the oath or affirmation which is going to be abolished—involves very much less commitment than an oath or affirmation. The wording of the proposed pledge itself is a significant weakening of the present situation. It contains no reference to the head of state, to the constitution or to any of our other basic institutions. Rather, it makes vague allusions to `Australia and its people' and contains such ambiguous concepts as `democratic beliefs'.

The legality of those phrases, let alone their essential meaning, has been questioned by many eminent persons. One of those who has expressed very grave concern about the changes being announced—not just in the legal sense but more particularly in the symbolic sense—is the very respected clergyman, the leader of the Anglican Church in Australia, Archbishop Peter Hollingworth. He recently wrote that what is being proposed in this bill `is a matter of deep symbolic and civic importance to us as a nation'. He wrote:

There is good reason for changing words or formulae if they give a wrong impression, or the original meaning has changed or if there is widespread objection based on conscience. But does the existing Oath of Allegiance offend in these ways?
The swearing of an oath goes right to the heart of human belief. To take an oath is to highlight the solemn seriousness, power and efficacy with which a person's own word becomes endowed.

SPEECH.PARA: He makes the point very well and very strongly—I will not continue with all of the article—that the changes being proposed in this bill do not represent changes for the better in that respect; that indeed they represent a `removal of significant traditional linchpins in our society without having something of like substance to put in its place'. Those words by Archbishop Hollingworth are ones that we should all heed very carefully.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's position on the question of citizenship has been very clear for a long time. Our last policy statement on the matter was made in 1988 and our position has been essentially unchanged since then. We pointed out that it was essential that the requirements of acquisition and awarding of citizenship should be strengthened to ensure that intending citizens understand more fully the meaning of their commitment to Australia.

We made the point then that, compared with most other countries, Australian citizenship requirements are amongst the least rigorous in the world. Indeed, it is interesting to compare them—even our existing ones, let alone the changes now being made—to, say, the United States situation. To become an American citizen, an applicant must have been physically present in the United States for at least half of the required five-year residency period.

Every applicant for what the Americans call naturalisation—we use the term `citizenship'—has to go through a two-stage process. First of all, the applicant has to demonstrate an understanding of the English language, including an ability to read, write and speak words in ordinary English language usage. People who are aged or who have particular disabilities are exempted from that. The applicant for citizenship has to demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of the fundamentals of the history, the principles and form of government of the United States.

At the preliminary hearing, the first-stage hearing in his citizenship approach, the applicant may be represented by a lawyer or a social service agency. There is a 30-day wait after the preliminary hearing. If that preliminary hearing is favourable to the applicant, there is a final hearing before a judge, who then administers an oath of allegiance. The American oath of allegiance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereignty, to whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen; that I will support and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States of America against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform noncombatant service in the armed forces of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by the law; and that I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; so help me God.

I am not suggesting that in Australia we follow the American wording to that extent. The point I make, though, is that a new citizen of the United States is required to make a very strong commitment. This bill seeks to remove an already insufficiently strong commitment in Australia for new citizenship. We are weakening that commitment still further and I think that is a very dangerous trend.

PARA.TAB: As well as that, though, the coalition has for a considerable period advocated a major overhaul of the current citizenship act to better reflect Australian citizenship as a privilege which has an overriding and unifying commitment to Australia and its basic structures and principles. We have also proposed the incorporation of a statement which spells out clearly the rights and obligations of citizenship during the citizenship ceremony in order to reaffirm that overriding and unifying commitment.

We are not by any means on our own in that sense. Earlier in my speech I mentioned the words of Archbishop Hollingworth. Many other people and bodies have spoken even more directly about those issues. A very important report—the so-called FitzGerald report entitled Immigration—a commitment to Australia which, I regret to say, this government has ignored—was produced in 1988 by the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. In this very notable report the FitzGerald committee made a similar recommendation to that which the coalition has in mind. It produced a draft suggested declaration to be adopted at citizenship ceremonies, linking the grant of citizenship with respect for fundamental institutions and principles in Australian society.

The FitzGerald committee also recommended that ways be examined to restrict certain public benefits to non-citizens as a means of enhancing the value of citizenship. There are very considerable, difficult and sensitive issues involved in that, but I do think we need to look at ways of making citizenship more attractive to potential citizens who may be deciding whether to take up citizenship.

That FitzGerald report also recommended that a group of eminent Australians be appointed to advise on further ways of making Australian citizenship a more meaningful commitment to Australia and of encouraging its acquisition. We on this side of the chamber have always felt that that recommendation has considerable merit and that it warrants follow-up action. Accordingly, in January earlier this year the Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson, announced that a coalition government would establish a national council on citizenship to advise on a clear and unambiguous statement of the rights and obligations of citizenship in the context of a multilateral society.

Another very important critic of the existing citizenship act has been the very eminent, very distinguished and universally respected former Governor-General of Australia, Sir Ninian Stephen. In a very important address to the Alfred Deakin Society on 26 August of this year—the Alfred Deakin lecture—Ninian Stephen described our existing citizenship act as `a masterpiece of legislative incoherence'. And he is absolutely right. The act is almost incomprehensible. It has enormous deficiencies. It does not really set out at all who are Australian citizens and what is required to be an Australian citizen.

For example, the only reference in the existing act to a citizen in the sense of defining who is a citizen is in section 10, which deals with citizenship by birth. That section states that someone is a citizen if that person was born in Australia after 26 January 1949, which was about the date of proclamation of the Australian Citizenship Act. Indeed, 1949 was the first time we had a citizenship act as such. In the current act the only reference to citizenship by birth occurs in section 10 and it relates only to post-January 1949 births. That is a classic example of why this act needs major change. The act is arcane, incomprehensible, unfriendly and does not set out clearly who are citizens.

For all of those reasons and, in particular, the point that the bill is premature at this time given the state of debate on our constitutional arrangements, we on the coalition side are totally opposed to this legislation. To proceed with it in advance of any change in our constitutional arrangements would be divisive, pre-emptive and of questionable legality. The citizenship act requires a complete overhaul—not the partial, piecemeal, confused, politically motivated and divisive amendments being proposed in this bill. For all of those reasons, the coalition very strongly opposes this bill in its entirety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill seeks to replace the current oath or affirmation of allegiance with a pledge of commitment, omitting reference to the Queen in doing so. In contrast to the oath or affirmation by members of parliament, the oath for new citizens can be changed by legislation. This is what the bill seeks to do.

PARA.TAB: As has been stated, the main argument against replacing the current arrangements with a new pledge of commitment is that it is a first, and fairly significant, step towards making Australia a republic. The Australian Democrats support the move towards a republic, but that is quite different from the consideration that applies to this bill. One needs to consider whether it is appropriate at this particular time to take this step. If it were a step that affected the substance of government in Australia, I think the position that the Democrats are adopting, which essentially is one of support, would be different.

The view we take is that a reference to the Queen and the swearing of allegiance to the Queen in a new citizenship ceremony is somewhat of an anachronism. We believe that new citizens who have entered Australia intending to make this country their home see Australia as the country to which they swear allegiance. It is Australia that they want to make their new home. To them, I believe, reference to the Queen is of some historical interest but, in terms of everyday life, in terms of pledging their commitment to their new home country, it is not of great relevance.

In my case there is a personal element. I am probably one of the few members of this chamber who, as a newcomer to this country some time ago, has actually taken the oath. I recall that when I came in 1949 I determined very clearly and very strongly that this was going to be my new home. I applied for citizenship even before the time had elapsed that would formally have entitled me to take that step.

When I took the oath in 1952, I carefully considered the words. I must admit that it surprised me a little to find the reference to the Queen in that oath. I had come to Australia, I had not come to another country, and I did not expect to find the monarch of another country, even if she was called the Queen of Australia, to be the head of the community to which I was pledging my allegiance. My commitment to Australia was as strong then as it is now.
I believe that the words of the new oath have a poetic simplicity which goes back to

SPEECH.PARA: the fact that former Senator Tate used the work of poet Les Murray in wordsmithing the words of this new pledge of commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Les Murray hates the new words, though.
—That may or may not be so. Les Murray has contributed significantly to the final result, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

To me the words are a very noble statement. If individuals wish to add in the first line `under God`, it is their choice to do so. I believe these words are significant and represent a significant commitment on the part of new citizens. In considering the wording, and in being a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which had a reference on this matter, I felt—and the Australian Democrats felt—that it would perhaps be useful to look at a variant to emphasise more the commitment that new citizens are making. I put forward a wording which read:
From this time forward,
I . . . pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

In the end, after long and careful consideration, we decided that it would be difficult to improve on the words that originated from poet Les Murray's efforts, but the concern that there should be a stronger commitment to the citizenship obligations of new citizens remained. Therefore, I have moved an amendment which I understand will be supported by the government, and hopefully the opposition, the Greens and Senator Harradine, inserting the words `undertake to' in the preamble to the oath. The preamble would then read as follows:
. . . Australian citizenship represents formal membership of the community of the Commonwealth of Australia; and
Australian citizenship is a common bond, involving reciprocal rights and obligations, uniting all Australians, while respecting their diversity; and
Persons granted Australian citizenship enjoy these rights and undertake to accept these obligations—
the two words `undertake to' represent my amendment—

PARA.TAB: by pledging loyalty to Australia and its people, and
by sharing their democratic beliefs, and
by respecting their rights and liberties, and
by upholding and obeying the laws of Australia . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that we recognise that we live in a period of change, that we are attempting to forge a national identity, and that we are attempting to forge a multicultural society that accepts diversity even as it builds this new identity. I believe that from time to time in this period of change we need to take steps that move us ahead towards that new identity, and that from time to time we need to discard symbolic relics of the past which might intervene in this attempt to forge a new community.

PARA.TAB: I am taking this change to the preamble a little further by asking the minister to give an undertaking to introduce regulations that this preamble will be read at every citizenship ceremony and, in addition, that the citizenship certificate will be amended to include the words `having undertaken to fulfil the responsibilities of a citizen'. As I have said before, I believe that new citizens do take extremely seriously their obligations to their new country. I think the oath, the preamble and the ceremony should reflect that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. As we have heard from Senator Short and Senator Spindler, the bill seeks to replace the current oath or affirmation of allegiance with a pledge that will not include a reference to the monarch.

PARA.TAB: Many people around Australia are extremely concerned about this not so subtle move to a republic without any public debate. It is ironic that for the second day in a row I am standing in the Senate accusing this government of doing things without public debate. Yesterday the issue was the UN declaration on religious freedom; today we are talking about a major change to something that is most significant to many people in this country. But, this government refuses, yet again, to take the issue to the people. I do not know what has happened to this government over the period of 10 years but it has become more and more aware of the need not to take its changes—I will not call them reforms; `reforms' suggests that something good will come out of it; they are absolute blatant changes—to the public.

I know that the minister at the table may well say to me, `But we had a Senate committee'. That was all very well, but the Senate committee inquiry was not held over an extended period. Most people to whom I have spoken were totally unaware of its existence. They did not have an opportunity, according to the way they view it—which is the important factor—to contribute to the debate, and here we are in a situation whereby they will be run roughshod over yet again. I just think that the whole situation is totally and utterly unsatisfactory and so do the people out there, who are the ones who will be affected by this measure.

I do not say that there are not a number of people out there who think that it might be extraordinary to pledge allegiance to the Queen. There are people out there; it would be stupid of me to the deny that. But the fact of the matter is that those very same people also find it quite extraordinary to think that they do not even have to pledge allegiance to the constitution under the proposal that has been put forward to us today. They look at comparisons with other countries. Take United States, for example, which Senator Short mentioned earlier. The situation there is very different. They have to pledge allegiance to a whole range of things, which makes this oath or affirmation look like something that would be said in kindergarten.

I just find that this whole thing is being treated with absolute and utter disrespect. I think it has been marginalised and minimised in terms of its importance to this country. Therefore, a very important factor that we must consider is creating opportunities for people to debate this. Let us have due consideration given to any changes that are made and not just have them rammed through the parliament in the way that this measure is.

One of the overriding and important observations about the whole debate on the oath of citizenship is that it needs to be made more relevant to Australian society. If the government is so sure that it has the support of the public, why cannot the public be allowed to decide the nature of a solemn oath when people become new citizens of this country?

It was interesting that a little while ago Senator Spindler made mention of Mr Les Murray's contribution. Senator Short and I said to him that that very same man, Les Murray—the poet—now thinks that this is wrong. I will just give him what he said. Mr Murray is a poet and a former literary editor. He is best described as a poet who has an enduring admiration for the quality and sanctity of Australian rural life. He is also a man who displays such attitudes as devotion to the Australian rural scene, respect and affection for the ordinary country man, and a conviction that modern society relinquishes at its peril the values that are enshrined in the land and the lives of those who live in intimacy with it. I will quote Mr Murray—and I must emphasise that the words are not necessarily parliamentary. He said that the government has `stuffed up' his original poem by turning it into `bureaucratic gobbledegook'. They are his words.

If Senator Spindler thinks that Mr Murray is still in favour of this when he uses that type of terminology, I would be awfully surprised. Mr Murray did not support the pledge in its current form and said Australians would not support Mr Keating's vision for a republic if a referendum were held now. I assume that if a referendum were held for the so-called `pledge of commitment' it would suffer a similar fate because it is so wishy-washy. Let us face it, that is part of the problem and that is the concern that is being expressed to the people of this parliament today. Mr Murray also said, `Not unless they'—Australians—`trust it'—the republic—`and they sure can't trust the one they are being offered at the moment'.

That is the problem that Mr Murray is identifying. That is the real crux of this issue. They do not trust what the government is doing. They do not see that it is a relevant thing to be just ramming down their throats. These are the people who will be affected, but these are the very people that this government refuses to consult. I suspect the reason the government wants to radically change the oath and affirmation through legislation is that it knows that no-one can trust the bearer of the changes. I think the question is: what is it that the government is dreading and fearful of in relation to this issue?
The current oath is very different. I want to put it on the record. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I swear by Almighty God—
in the affirmation it is `I solemnly and sincerely promise and declare'—

that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors, according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
People have had that opportunity to take either the oath or the affirmation and feel that there is some commitment in it. The proposed affirmation states:
From this time forward,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.
One only has to read them to see the difference.

PARA.TAB: Some of the ethnic communities to whom I spoke only two weeks ago today said to me that they believe that this just diminishes the significance of such an important occasion for them. If they are saying that, what do Australian born and bred people feel about it? They, too, feel as though it just diminishes the significance of such an important occasion.

I just want to put on the record the fact that there are many reasons why we are opposing this legislation. Senator Short has given a very comprehensive list of reasons why we are opposing this legislation—from a technical viewpoint, an emotive viewpoint and from the angle of significance to this country. I want to report to the Senate that there are real people out there who are not happy, who have not been consulted, who want to have a say in this and who feel that this government is denying them that right. They are the people who will be affected and they want to be consulted.

PARA.TAB: The minister went on to say:
