I have not heard too many who come to Australia from republics, other kingdoms or whatever, make a demand as to the sort of oath they will take. I believe that what they want to do is become citizens of Australia for the advantages they can get from Australia, otherwise they would not have migrated here in the first place. They may have entered this country on a resident visa or with PR status, seen what sort of a country Australia is and the opportunities that are here, and decided to become citizens. I have not heard too many immigrants saying, `No, I will not become an Australian citizen because I don't like the oath of allegiance', and I believe it is a fallacy to say that.

I would like to take a poll on that because I believe it is a totally stupid argument. When one wants to join a club or when one is a junior in a club, one does not demand that the rules change so that one can be admitted as a special person. I believe that if one wants to be admitted to a club—and I think Australia is a pretty good club to belong to; my family considers that it has been a pretty good club to belong to—one takes the rules as they are. In time, if Australia decides to change its flag, its constitution and its head of state, let it be done then, and not before, in bits and pieces and by trying to put it all over Australian citizens. I totally support the position that Senator Short and others have so ably pointed out to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill which we are discussing in the Senate today is not a bill which in any way relates to democracy. It is not a bill which in any way relates to the will of the Australian people. It is nothing more than a blatant attempt by our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) once again to impose upon the community his will, and his agenda alone. If I remember correctly no public outcry instigated this bill. There were no representations that called for changes. Rather, our Prime Minister decided that in his endeavour to push Australia towards a republic he would pre-empt any constitutional referendum and any decision of the parliament and, as usual, impose his own views.

PARA.TAB: When the proposed new oath and affirmation of allegiance was announced by the Prime Minister in his usual press release method, on 17 December 1992, he stated that the new oath and affirmation would better reflect the contemporary reality of Australia and our nation aspirations. It should be remembered that once again these comments were made without any public support. Naturally, when Labor was returned to government following the March 1993 election, one of the first bills to be introduced to the parliament was this Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill which, as we have heard today, deletes all reference to the Queen and any reference to the constitution or any of our other institutions from the oath of allegiance required of people on being granted Australian citizenship.

We would have thought there would have been a few other higher priorities on the agenda, such as getting the budget through parliament and a few other things like that. Nevertheless, this was one of the first bills we saw after the election. If we are to judge in any way the merits of the government's proposal, I take this opportunity to place on record through Hansard the exact wording that will be used by our new Australian citizens. It has already been quoted by Senators Knowles and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward, under God,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold, and obey.

This pledge of commitment which represents the government's proposals is an extremely poor attempt to give our new Australian citizens any understanding of what it means to be an Australian citizen. More particularly it in no way reflects the many obligations and responsibilities which accompany such an honour. There is no doubt this bill is an attempt by the Prime Minister and the Labor Party to continue their republican push and, by doing so, to pre-empt any outcome of the debate which is occurring in Australia today.

PARA.TAB: As can be seen from the newspoll released today, the initial support for the republic is quickly dwindling. That is because the Australian community has had an opportunity to come to terms with what exactly it means to be part of a constitutional monarchy. According to the figures, only 39 per cent of Australian citizens support the concept and 44 per cent are against a republic. I have no doubt that this trend will continue. Our Prime Minister has absolutely no right to pretend that he represents the views of the majority of Australians on this issue. The decision by the Labor Government to delete any reference to the Queen or to our constitution from the oath of allegiance is totally unfounded whilst Australia remains a constitutional monarchy and whilst the debate which is occurring at present continues.

This bill is another attempt by the government to divert the attention of this parliament, and perhaps the media, away from the other critical issues that are facing our country today. We do not need to be reminded that we have the worst unemployment problem this country has ever known. We have young people who are facing the prospect of no future whatsoever. We have a business community that has stagnated. Our international trade figures continue to reflect doom and gloom.

These are not the times when the government should be looking at these matters; it should not be bringing these red herrings into the parliament. What is more important in this day and age is that the government should be directing its energies towards resolving the real issues this country is facing at the moment. That has not occurred because the government does not have the answers. It proved over the last decade that it does not have the answers.

The issue of whether Australia should become a republic and result in the removal of our monarch as the head of state is still to be resolved. Our Prime Minister has failed to demonstrate why our existing form of government is in any way flawed when the latest figures clearly demonstrate that he is losing the argument. Piecemeal measures such as this bill which pre-empt such debate will serve only to divide the Australian community further.

When I speak on this matter of citizenship, I do so with a certain amount of personal experience. I was the elected head of a local government area in Tasmania. I conducted hundreds, if not thousands, of personal and collective citizenship ceremonies in my then municipality of Clarence, which is now the city of Clarence. During all that time, I never once met a prospective citizen who was concerned about the oath or affirmation that they were going to take. All they were worried about was being a good citizen of Australia, and they were very proud to partake in that ceremony. I can recall only too well the numerous occasions on which I saw pride in the eyes of individuals when they repeated the words which obviously meant so much to them, coming to a country where they could be free.

I have been out of that job for some seven years now, but it is amazing the number of people who walk up to me in the street, or when I am at social functions, and say, `Do you remember me? You naturalised me. I remember that ceremony; it was a wonderful occasion'. At the ceremonies in our city, people were presented with a native eucalyptus tree. I usually asked them how the tree was going and, in most cases, they said that it was growing well. They look after it; it symbolises the event and reminds them of the happiness and pride they felt at the ceremony.

As Senator Panizza said earlier, the receipt of Australian citizenship is probably the most important event for any migrant who has chosen to call Australia their home. As such, the oath or affirmation of allegiance should be a meaningful occasion for the new citizen which reflects their loyalty to Australia. There is not one person who applies for citizenship without the knowledge that the Queen of Australia is our head of state. Therefore, I believe that we will create confusion in prospective migrants if we ask them to make a pledge of commitment that in no way refers to that head of state.

Because this bill is piecemeal and because it does not reflect the result of a referendum, our Queen will be referred to in a number of oaths but she will not be referred to in the citizenship ceremony. Senators know that, when enlisting for the defence forces, there is a requirement for an oath or affirmation to Her Majesty the Queen to be taken. Similarly, there is a requirement under section 42 of the constitution that members of the House of Representatives and members of this place make an oath or affirmation of allegiance to the Queen.

This bill will guarantee nothing more than a situation where we have different statements of allegiance by different categories of Australians. This is hardly the evidence of a well thought out and considered initiative. Rather than strengthening our existing citizenship oath, this new legislation will merely weaken it. The pledge which is contained in the government's proposal reflects much less commitment than the oath or affirmation which was previously used. A pledge makes no reference to our head of state, our constitution, or any of our other basic institutions. It completely ignores the heritage on which our nation was originally founded. The vague allusions contained in the pledge to Australia and to its people, or to other concepts such as democratic beliefs, create no sense of sureness in the prospective citizen.

The bill fails to address the real issue of concern in the Citizenship Act: it does not reflect in the true manner what it really means to be an Australian, or the privileges and obligations which accompany that citizenship. There is no reference to a unified Australia. There is no reference to our values, our principles and our basic institutions.

Because the Australian Citizenship Act has not been altered substantially since 1948, the coalition has called several times for a full review and overhaul of the citizenship act. During consideration of this bill by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, a former Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, described the act as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only is it an extraordinary example of legal and bureaucratic language, but it is extraordinarily inappropriate for its title.

As part of our commitment in the lead-up to the last election, John Hewson announced that a coalition government would establish a national council on citizenship which would be chaired by a prominent Australian and which would overview the whole question of the rights and obligations which accompany the honour. The coalition believes that this parliament should support legislation which strengthens the citizenship act and that this should be a matter of priority.

PARA.TAB: Since assuming the role of Prime Minister, Mr Keating has repeatedly attempted to deride and undermine our national symbols. He has even had the gall to attempt to rewrite our history. His recent outburst over the Olympic Games further demonstrates his willingness to ignore reality. When I witnessed members of the Australian community celebrating the selection of Sydney to host the 2000 games, it was quite obvious from the way they proudly paraded the Australian flag that they had no intentions or thoughts of changing this particular act, the flag or anything else—they were just proud to be Australian.

The strengthening of public opinion behind the status quo demonstrates to me that Australians are valuing more and more their stability and our constitution. They will eventually reject, in no uncertain terms, this attempt to push our country into a position of instability. It could be that our Prime Minister inherits his derision of our past from his Irish ancestors, but the overwhelming majority of Australians from varying backgrounds are proud of our nation's background and the manner in which we have developed.

It is not surprising that this bill allocates a further $230,000 to be spent in the 1993-94 financial year to promote this so-called new pledge to the Australian community. Let there be no doubt that this quarter of a million dollars of taxpayers' money will not be used to push the pledge but will be just another excuse to push the republican cause at the expense of all else. It is nothing more than a slush fund for our Prime Minister to push his ideals.

Whilst on the subject of funding by this government, I have had a lot of representations regarding the government's allocation of hundreds of thousands of dollars to the republican committee with the sole aim of pursuing the government's agenda, yet not one cent of taxpayers' money has been allocated to support our Australian constitution and our Australian way of life.

This bill is divisive. It does nothing to address the real issues facing Australia. It creates two classes of Australian citizens: those who were born in Australia and therefore have an allegiance to the Queen; and those from overseas who will not.

However, the main reason why this parliament should reject this pledge is that it totally pre-empts the outcome of any debate by the community and a change to the pledge without the input of the Australian people will show once again that this parliament is more concerned with Mr Keating's agenda than with the wishes of the majority of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak with a feeling of some anger. This morning I attended a citizenship ceremony in Canberra because a friend of mine was making an extraordinarily important decision in his life to become an Australian citizen. He was not a new settler; he had been here a long time. He loves this country and he wants to be a citizen of it. Interestingly enough, the person who drove me to the ceremony has lived here for 40 years and is also in the process of becoming an Australian citizen. One could say that it is one of the most important days of one's life when one makes a decision to become a citizen and to swear one's allegiance and loyalty to a new nation, to uphold its rights and duties and to give one's pledge that one will honour the country that one is becoming a citizen of.

PARA.TAB: This ceremony was held in a dirty, dingy little room in a building in Civic. Only 22 people were in this ceremony because something like ten ceremonies had to be performed today. There was an apology from the person officiating that those people who had sworn on the Bible could not keep it because of budgetary measures in the department. When we stood up to sing the national anthem there was a sense that we could not even afford to have a decent tape of it to sing to. There were more apologies afterwards.

This is the nation's capital. As I sat here and heard earlier in the day from those on the government benches what I can only describe as cant—superficial language and superficial arguments as to why we should remove the whole concept of owing fealty and allegiance to an individual, and about getting rid of the concept of taking the oath or affirmation and replacing it with something called a commitment when one is pledging one's loyalty for the rest of one's life to this great nation—I thought once again that the attitude is downright un-Australian. We have a Prime Minister who is un-Australian. We win the Olympics and he comes home and says that we are all second-rate. We had just taken on the world and said that we are proud and have won and he comes back and says that we have to change everything because we are all second-rate. The only person who is second-rate in this whole equation is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As my colleague Senator Calvert has said, the so-called modest advertising budget that will be made available to go out and advertise—allegedly—this change in how one becomes a citizen will just be more of the unintentional or unrecognised hidden funding for the republican push and the changing the flag push of the Prime Minister.

I have great faith in the good, sensible Australian people. They love this country, they love their national symbols and they are proud of them. They are proud of the sacrifice that others have given in the name of the nation and under that flag. At the end of the day, it is always well to remember that it is us who bring credit to our flag and not the other way around. The flag is there for us to rally to, not for it to bring glory upon us. If there has been a failure to take the Australian reputation and its symbols to the rest of the world and have the rest of the world recognise what they mean, the failure is the failure of the person in whom we have placed executive power—the Prime Minister. It is his responsibility to say that he is proud of his country and his people, but he cannot even do that. He cannot even fly his own flag on his automobile. What sort of a leader is that? He puts himself first and Australia second. This is just part of the continuing subterfuge of finding more money to promote the great crusade to become King Paul I of Australia.

As I sat watching that citizenship ceremony this morning, I thought to myself, `This is the nation's capital. This ceremony should be taking place in the nation's parliament'. Heaven knows, we have plenty of empty space around here. It should have been attended by the minister, not just an official. No member of either the government or the opposition was invited to speak, as happens when I attend citizenship ceremonies in Blacktown or Parramatta, where it becomes a bipartisan thing and everybody welcomes in the new citizens.

These were proud, marvellous, new Australians. There were little people; there were people who had been here a long time before taking that decision; and there were people who had clearly come more recently. But they all had one thing in common—they wanted to be Australian. What a wonderful thing to want to be—to become part of the best country in the world. Yet what did we give them? A shabby room, no Bible to take home because of budgetary cuts, the feeling that it was a second-rate occurrence and nobody to speak officially from those who have been elected. I could see the pride within them because they had fulfilled their ambition to become an Australian citizen. I thought they deserved better and I think we should seriously look at having those ceremonies in this parliament. Two hundred people were to be done today. What a gathering and what a celebration that could have been. If only we could think first about how good we are, how strong we are and how magnificent it is to decide to become an Australian citizen.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Is the minister aware of a recent survey by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which found that more than one in four households rely on social security payments for their main source of income? Can the minister explain to these families, many of which are victims of the government's recession, how the Prime Minister's obsession with Australia becoming a republic and having a new flag will assist those families in achieving greater self-sufficiency and prosperity?

—First of all, I think it is important that the Senate understands what one in four families being in receipt of social security payments really means. Senator Newman failed to say that families in receipt of the family assistance as well as those in receipt of the family allowance supplement receive funds from the same source.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman's question conveys the understanding that all of those families are social security pension beneficiaries. That is a misunderstanding of the payments to those families. Approximately 90 per cent of Australian families enjoy a family allowance payment that is also paid in the same way. I urge Senator Newman to be cautious in respect of what those statistics mean.

Amongst other things, the assistance given to help rear children is a fair recognition by government of the importance of children. That is why we have the family payment and the family allowance supplement. When the family allowance supplement was introduced, the government did something that the opposition never did: it set benchmarks for the assistance of children. Those figures have been set; they are indexed; and they are there forever. I suspect that the opposition, if it ever were in government, would not remove them. So it is important to understand the meaning of that simple statistic which Senator Newman dropped into this place.

In response to the second part of Senator Newman's question, it is quite clear from dealing with any people at all in the community that people who have a sense of confidence, a sense of their own place in the world and a sense that they are making decisions about their own lives are the ones who manage better. That is what this government recognises. It recognises the right of people to be assisted and the right of people to be able to stand on their own two feet, define their lives and make choices. That is the exact analogy of what the Prime Minister is saying to this country. When this country is standing on its own two feet, defining itself, confidently facing the rest of the world and winning Olympic bids, it is meeting the challenge that is faced by women in this country. Senator Newman should know that. As women are defining themselves and becoming more confident, so is the nation.

I see an entire parallel; so do thousands of Australians. I am shocked that Senator Newman does not. She is misrepresenting this statistic and she simply does not understand that confident people make the best choices. I have no doubt at all that most Australians are very pleased that Australia stands proud, as is this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. For the benefit of the Minister for Family Services, I have to explain that my question asked—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my right. This is one of the faults of the Senate's adopted system of a one-minute time limit for asking supplementary questions.
—The minister obviously cannot hear, as well as not read. I said that the ABS figures said these people were living on social security payments as their main source of income.
—`Main source'.
—It is their main source of income. We are not talking about family allowances. They are ABS figures based on 1990 unemployment statistics of eight per cent. If this minister believes—
—Order! I have been tolerant. Ask the question.
—Does the minister believe that the confidence engendered by having a republic will fill their bellies and give them jobs?

—Mr President, you could conclude many things from Senator Newman's peculiar association of these ideas. If she understood exactly what a confident Australia means, she would know that it also means a country that is in a position to export its products, produce more, manufacture and engender wealth so that eventually that wealth is recirculated to families.

PARA.TAB: I also take it that Senator Newman does not want this government or any government to resile from assisting families through income. That is one thing of which we are very proud. We have set benchmarks for the payments to families. We will not leave families or children abandoned, and this government recognises that. I think Senator Newman's question trawls a very long line. She is catching the wrong things in the thread. It is a confident country that looks after its citizens best.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to the announcement yesterday that the sale of surplus defence weapons will no longer be permitted. Is the minister in a position to advise the Senate of the reasons for this change in policy? How has the government arrived at a decision of this significance?

—Yesterday, the Minister for Justice, Mr Duncan Kerr, and I issued a joint statement to announce that the sale of surplus Defence automatic and semiautomatic small arms would cease. Previously, the sale of these weapons to private collectors and museums was permitted, provided that the weapons had been rendered inoperable and the buyer had police permission.

PARA.TAB: I directed my department to review its policy for the disposal of the surplus weapons following representations from the Australian Police Ministers Council through the Minister for Justice. Their request for a review of the policy followed an incident where a non-working weapon was made operable after it was sold by Defence. Apart from destruction, there is no known method for rendering a weapon irreversibly inoperable.

Under the revised policy, surplus weapons will be destroyed. Exceptions will only be made for, firstly, the domestic sale of working weapons to government agencies; secondly, export sales to foreign governments of working weapons in accordance with Defence export controls; and, thirdly, the domestic disposal of rendered weapons to government controlled museums, subject to approval of the local police force.

I recognise that this decision may inconvenience legitimate collectors and some private museums. However, this point must be placed and balanced against the community's desire for the tighter control of guns.

A number of collectors had ordered and paid for weapons from Defence when this decision was made to stop all sales pending the review. Defence will refund this money. Advice from the Attorney-General's Department is that Defence liability to prospective buyers will be limited to the amount that they have paid.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax on Business Travel

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the government's humiliating backdown on the budget proposal for FBT on business travel, announced by the Assistant Treasurer in 1993, occur as a result of an analysis by Access Economics? Does the government and the minister agree with Access Economics that the proposal runs directly counter to the claimed job creation focus of the budget, undermines the government's deficit reduction strategy and, rather than reducing the federal deficit by $60 million, could increase the deficit by as much as, or even considerably more than, that amount? Will the government now back down further on its original backdown and completely abandon the proposal?

—It is not the government's view that the measure concerned is likely to run counter to either job creation objectives or the deficit reduction strategy. It is always the case that every time there is a proposal to increase the tax on those best off, the opposition leaps to their defence with alacrity. I can say with 100 per cent accuracy that that has been the record of those opposite every time there has been a proposal to increase the rate of tax on those who are well off. Whether it be capital gains tax, the original introduction of the fringe benefits tax or whatever, they have at least been loyal on every occasion in their defence of the wealthy and well off.

PARA.TAB: It has always been true that if one says to any business, `Could you employ more people if you did not have to pay any tax?', that business could always say yes. The net result of that is that revenue would not be raised. In net terms, there is no acceptance by the government that this proposal runs counter to its job creation strategy and it will, in our view, be quite—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the job creation strategy?

—The 100,000 jobs in the budget which the opposition is doing its best to undermine. The proposal that it would run counter to our deficit reduction strategy is not correct. It will quite clearly raise additional revenue. It is the additional revenue that it will raise that is exactly the concern of those people that those opposite are seeking to represent.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is a very interesting answer in view of the industry assessment that 20,000 to 30,000 jobs would be lost, not gained, as a result of the proposal. How does that fit in with the job creation process? In addition, even John Brown, a former Labor minister, said that this proposal was not about revenue. Even the departmental officials concede that. I think John Brown was right when he said that the tax was an `antiquated, philosophical dogma of the ALP, where Labor appears to have ceased its social maturation process and reverted to the worst aspects of envy and class warfare'. Does the minister agree?
—Assuming that the question is, `Do I agree with John Brown on that matter?', the answer is no.
—And about the job creation.
—That was not the question, but I will respond to it.
—It was.

—As I understood it, the honourable senator asked something else. But I am very happy to respond to that question. The situation is simply this: I have been involved in public debate of public issues for 20 years and I have never heard an industry come forward and say, `This increase in tax is a great idea and we will create more jobs if only you would do it'. So coming forward with industry analyses which say that the industry does not think putting a tax on it is a good idea is not actually very unique. They all say that, and history usually proves that Chicken Little lives in most industries. They always say that the sky is going to fall in, and it very rarely does.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications and relates to a question asked yesterday concerning the current industrial situation on the waterfront. Can the minister update his advice on any further developments in the resolution of the current industrial dispute at Australian Stevedores?

—I advised the Senate yesterday that I intended to convene a meeting this morning with the parties to discuss this issue. That meeting was convened very early this morning and continued until a short time ago. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the meeting was successful. It goes without saying that industrial action in relation to this dispute ceased yesterday afternoon to allow the meeting to take place.
—Self-proclaim.

—I am sorry that it was not the result Senator Alston wanted. A joint statement has been issued by the participants in the meeting—Australian Stevedores, the ACTU, the Maritime Union of Australia and the Australian Maritime Officers Union. I will table that statement.

PARA.TAB: The results of the meeting were to the following effect: it has been agreed that Australian Stevedores must achieve a level of labour costs which will allow it to achieve profitability and to compete effectively with other stevedores in the industry. A range of measures were explored this morning with a view to achieving this objective. I wish to acknowledge the positive approach that was adopted this morning by both employee and employer representatives. I also wish to acknowledge the very high level of assistance that was provided by the ACTU in the meeting this morning. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the minister accept that, despite the huffing and puffing of ministers in the lower house about the illegitimacy of the Senate, this house does have a right and, in fact, an obligation to review government legislation to ensure that harsh and unfair measures are not foisted upon the Australian people? Does the minister also accept that there is a fine line between that obligation to knock off the hard edges of ill-considered legislation and the obligation to allow the government to govern without unreasonable and unproductive obstructionism? Does the minister agree that the Senate is fast approaching that fine line, as Malcolm Fraser has suggested in today's Australian newspaper?

—There is no doubting that the Australian constitution confers certain powers on this house and, unless and until a referendum is successfully carried, that will pertain into the immediate future. Therefore, I accept that the Senate has conferred on it, quite properly, powers under the constitution. Although this house was originally envisaged by the founding fathers as a states rights house, that disappeared very quickly when political partisanship came into this chamber, as inevitably it must. Therefore, what this chamber has evolved traditionally as its historical role is that of a house of review but, again, that has always been governed to some extent by party discipline.

PARA.TAB: I must say to Senator Kernot that some of the problems in terms of the powers of this chamber, the House of Representatives and the broad question of mandates would be better served if we had simultaneous elections rather than a hangover from elections several years ago which can well not reflect the meaning of the people. I would not like to see this chamber head in that particular direction and I do not think that most people in this chamber would like that. Whilst we have acknowledged that this Senate has had certain rights and privileges, et cetera conferred on it, all politics also operate by way of convention and historical practice as well.

The change that we have seen in this chamber has only really occurred in the past few months. The Labor government has never had a majority since 1983. So what has changed? What has changed is that we now have an opposition that, having been rejected by the people for five successive elections, has suddenly found that defeat has changed it. We promised before the last election—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The minister asked what it was that had changed in this chamber. What in fact has changed is that the Australian people only gave the Labor Party 30 senators. In other words, the question asked by the senator—

—Mr President, I read in the newspapers that Senator Bishop is considering running—

—The crucial point about politics in this country is that the government is responsible for the macro-economic performance of the country. If this chamber so grossly interferes with our macro-economic policy, does anybody think that any of the people who interfere with it will take any responsibility come the next election? PARA.TAB: What goes up comes down. Does anybody think any of these opposition tactics will apply to the opposition if it ever wins government? PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —This ought to be something opposition senators are interested in. What will be the contribution of the government's economic stimulus to employment in this sector over this period?

—As most senators would be aware, one of the important aspects of the retail sales activity in the Christmas period is that it also leads to a surge in employment in that period; a very important surge in employment for many ordinary Australian families and their children who, as students, are seeking part time jobs, and for the unemployed for whom, although the jobs may be temporary, they are nevertheless extremely welcome.

PARA.TAB: The ABS publication says that last December, Australia's retail sector created an additional 35,000 to 40,000 seasonal jobs—jobs additional to the underlying pattern of an increase in employment. December 1993 has the potential to see an even bigger seasonal boost than in previous years. The government's fiscal policy is designed to provide an additional stimulus just so that there will be more available for people to spend in the retail stores this year, while laying down a firm schedule for reducing the budget deficit in the medium term.

The key ingredient of that additional stimulus is the personal income tax cuts scheduled for 15 November. That will contribute at least $300 million in extra retail outlays to pump into the retail stores this year. It will be a great tragedy if the intransigence, the lack of cooperation—the sorts of problems that Senator Ray so articulately outlined in the Senate—and the fiscal irresponsibility of the Senate were to lead to the situation where those personal income tax cuts could not go ahead on time.

If the medium-term reduction strategy is still being held hostage by the Senate, the government will not be in a fiscally responsible position to go ahead with the bringing forward of those tax cuts, and those extra jobs over Christmas will be in jeopardy; they will be at risk.

There are significant concerns about the loss of the tax cuts to those ordinary Australian working men and women, because they deserve them. The bring forward to which this budget contributes is important to those families; it is important to those individuals. Over and above that, it is a very fundamental economic stimulus to create more of those seasonal jobs over Christmas that are so important but which may not be of concern to the complacent opposition, which is concerned just to play spoiling tactics.

The tax cuts are very important to ordinary Australian men and women and their children and I hope we can get a responsible passage through the Senate of the budget measures so that the tax cuts can come into effect on 15 November, economic stimulus can be generated and those jobs can be created.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the minister or any other member of the government given any assurance, formal or informal, to residents or other interested groups in the Mascot-South Sydney area that once the third runway is completed, use of the 07/25 runway, the east-west runway, will be heavily restricted and it will be used only during strong easterly or westerly wind conditions? Does the minister not agree that any such restriction on continued use of that runway would erode a significant amount of the benefit gained by construction of the third runway?

—The facts are that the future use of the east-west runway at Sydney airport will be restricted to times when wind conditions make safe landing on the two parallel runways unsafe. That is correct. I might add that that information has been in published form for a very long time. It is contained in detail in the documents that were prepared for the construction of the second parallel runway.

PARA.TAB: Might I also say that one of the results of the second parallel runway—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to resign over the third runway.
—Just remain quiet, Senator Macdonald. You will be pleased to know that I actually used you as a role model yesterday. Two young law students from the Northern Territory that were—
—They wanted a village idiot, did they?
—No. They were very apprehensive about their end-of-year exams in a month's time.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to ask the minister to direct his comments through you and not directly to Senator Ian Macdonald.
—Order! I will do that and at the same time I will ask Senator Ian Macdonald to cease constantly interjecting.
—I said to them, `Don't worry about your exams. We've got a bloke in the Senate who is living proof that anyone can pass a law exam'.
—You couldn't. You tried and failed.

—That is a nonsense. I do not know where Senator Macdonald gets this stuff from. One of the values of the second parallel runway is that it will no longer be necessary to maintain simultaneous operations at Sydney airport. The use of both of the parallel runways will provide an extra 30 per cent capacity to Sydney airport. As I say, all of those matters were factored into the planning of the second parallel runway to the extent that the use of the east-west runway is not required to achieve that capacity unless the wind conditions provide that it is essential to use it.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I know that the Minister for Transport and Communications gave his full support to the construction of the third runway and that this support was in opposition to some of his colleagues.
—Name them.
—Order! Ask the question, Senator Brownhill.

—I am quite happy to ask the question, Mr President, but I hope that the minister will be able to answer it. I know that the minister gave his support to the construction of the runway. I also know that he did it against a lot of opposition from some of his colleagues who represent that area. Will the minister give me his absolute assurance that he did not kowtow or bow to those constituents being represented by those people in this place?
—I can assure the honourable senator that I would find both of those tasks difficult if not impossible to perform.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I ask whether the minister is aware of this claim made by Senator Herron in the debate on the second reading of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill last evening in this place:

QUESTION.PARA: Half the obstetricians in Australia have given up obstetrics in the last five years.
I ask the minister whether this assertion is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator McKiernan and anybody else unfortunate enough to have been listening last night that it is not true. I think it has become the stuff of urban medical legend recently that obstetricians all over the country are leaving their specialty to practise in gynaecology and fertility, but that claim simply is not true.

PARA.TAB: Last week I met with the President of the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists as part of my regular consultations. I would suggest that the president, Dr Hinde, might have a bit better idea of what is happening in his specialty than Senator Herron. Dr Hinde informed me that it was not true. He said that, while the increased cost of medical defence was putting a great deal of fear into the specialty, they had not been leaving it yet, but they might in the future if something was not done.

In terms of Senator Herron's exact remarks, it is certainly true that in the USA there has been a greatly increased tendency for people to take out cases against obstetricians, although there is no evidence of increased cases here. I think there are two reasons why the medical insurance funds have put up the premiums for obstetricians so much. One is that they were shockingly underfunded in recent years and they have had to try to make up for that underfunding in a short period of time. The second is that while the number of cases has not been great, it is true to say that sometimes the payouts, the damages awarded, are very large indeed. While the college of obstetricians is prepared to concede that there is a danger that people might leave the field in the future unless we do something about it, it is certainly not of the view that such an exodus has already occurred.

I intend to look very carefully at a study which hopefully will be published by about March of next year on this question and to try to deal with it in the first half of next year. Obviously we do not want obstetricians to leave in the future. It is a specialty that is of vital interest to all of us. I think the Medicare data shows how silly is Senator Herron's claim that half the obstetricians left in the last few years.

In the four years from 1988 to 1992, Medicare data shows that there was a decline of only 3.7 per cent nationally in the number of specialists who perform more than five confinements or caesareans annually. The number of obstetricians practising in Australia in 1984-85 was 722 full time and 151 part time; a total of 873. By 1992-93 that was 748 full time, 167 part time and 18 others; a total of 933. Far from half leaving, the numbers went up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has he been fibbing?

—I would not ever say that he has been fibbing. He has simply been misinformed, Senator Cook. I think it is worth noting that 87 per cent of those 748 full-time obstetricians got at least 10 per cent of their incomes from obstetrics and 59 per cent of them got at least half their income from obstetric items. The top quartile, I might say, of full and part-timers accounts for 53 per cent of all births billed to Medicare.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister is quoting from a document and he has not told us of its origin. Would he table this document?
—There is no point of order, but whether or not the minister wants to table it is a matter for him to decide.

—There will probably be another question on this matter and I might get an opportunity to use the rest, so I will not table it now. But if Senator Herron does not know that the Health Insurance Commission collects Medicare data, he is in more trouble than I thought when he got this so wrong. To believe that half have left when the figures reveal what I have just said shows an extraordinary ignorance.
—I will produce the figures later.

—That means that the college is lying as well. Only Senator Herron, apparently, is in some way the repository of all knowledge. We all know that that is not true. However, I will give an assurance that we will act early next year to make sure that those medical defence costs do not keep going up at the rate they have.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In today's Australian newspaper Professor Judith Sloan commented:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . providing training courses to the unemployed . . . will not of itself lead to job creation . . .
The most permanent solution is to create an environment in which there is strong and sustained growth in the number of private sector jobs . . .

Can the minister indicate how the rise in fuel taxes, the increased tax on the wine industry, the increases in wholesale sales tax and the removal of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act will help to create jobs in the private sector?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had Ms Sloan's comments drawn to my attention, but I think that was only the preliminary bait to get to the main question, so I will not comment on her report. Senator Troeth asks: how can any tax stimulate employment? What we are doing to stimulate employment goes to the general macro-economic approach in which we are arguing, in this particular year, that we should have a budget deficit of $16 billion—and that will certainly have a stimulatory effect.

PARA.TAB: It is also true to say that if we took taxes off all businesses, there would be some growth in employment. But there would also be a massive shortfall in revenue to any government. It is always easier to say, `If you do not have a tax covering this or that particular industry, you will have wider employment'. The main factor in the government's thinking is to make sure that the tax falls fairly right across-the-board and that the tax mix is right. That is something that Senator Troeth's party has no conception of at the moment because of the policy vacuum that exists.

Those opposite do not know whether they support direct tax or indirect tax. They will not even address the question of deficit reduction. They have no idea what they are going to do in relation to that. As I said earlier to Senator Kernot, we get these mindless oppositionist tactics where those opposite simply come in here like a bunch of sheep and vote against absolutely everything on the basis that something may turn up in 2 1/2 years time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and comes in the wake of Sydney's successful bid to host the year 2000 Olympics. As Minister Kelly acknowledged yesterday in the House of Representatives, today's 10- to 17-year-olds—our school children—will make up the bulk of the Olympic team for the year 2000. Will the federal government make a commitment to implement the 40 recommendations of the Senate inquiry into physical and sport education? This shows how the federal government can turn around the disastrous state of decline of physical education in schools across Australia and so not only help us to find the athletes for the year 2000 but also prevent a further decline in the health and well being of Australians.

—The government wants to reiterate its congratulations to all concerned with the successful Sydney bid. That has been stated by the Prime Minister and by all members of the government, and I think it is certainly a bipartisan or tripartisan position of all of us.

PARA.TAB: We anticipate that, on present indications and at the present rate of expenditure, by the time of the Olympic games in the year 2000, we will have spent between now and then around $200 million on Olympic sports in Australia. The minister anticipates that because we have the Olympic games, there will be a much wider participation of Australians in sports in those Olympic games.

I think most of us would be aware that, because we are hosting the Olympic games, we are automatically eligible to enter a team in all the team sports and do not have to go through the prequalifying rounds. This will mean that Australians will be able to see many more of their citizens participating in the Olympic games in every sport for the first time. In many sports which some people in Australia might call minor we will have an Australian team participating. As a result, the minister anticipates that we can expect increased funding to take account of that excellent outcome of hosting the Olympic games in Australia.

We also recognise that in order to surpass our excellent effort on the last occasion that Australia hosted the Olympic games, 1956, when we won 13 gold medals, we have to get more people participating in sport. That will have to be a joint Australia-wide program between the federal government and the states. The minister has already indicated her keenness to have discussion with the states about preparing appropriate programs to encourage an increased participation of Australians, particularly in many of those sports at the Olympic games in which we will now be eligible to have teams.

As far as the recommendations of the Senate committee are concerned, I will have to take that part of the question on notice and come back to the honourable senator with a direct response. But I can assure her that the government is very enthusiastic about ensuring that as many Australians as possible are able to participate in the preparations for the Olympic games, and also that we use this to make Australia a fitter society than it is at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I thank Senator Ray for his earlier statement that the `government is responsible for the macro-economic performance of the country'. Is the minister aware that when the Labor government came to power in 1983 our foreign debt was $35 billion and it is now $200 billion? Great macro-economic performance! How will today's massive blow-out of $379 million in the balance of trade payments help reduce our foreign debt? How does the minister reconcile this with the lower value of the dollar?

—I did not catch all of that question, but I think I caught enough of it in order to answer it. The question, as I understand it, is how we intend to improve our trade performance in view of the balance of payments figures today. The question included a comparison of foreign debt then and now. This answer requires more than the available time to complete, but let me go to the main reasons as headings and not develop each of them as full arguments.

PARA.TAB: We are improving our exports; the figures which came out today show an increase in exports at a much higher level. That is pleasing because the exports that we have performed better at are exports in the elaborately transformed manufactures section; that is where there is the most value added.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The minister has already admitted that he did not hear my question and he is now giving an answer to something that I did not ask. I would ask you to call him to order.
—There is no point of order.

—I know that it is good news, and I know that those opposite are merchants of bad news who are talking down our export performance. When the facts are put objectively, they do not like the truth. However, let me make the point that Australia has been increasing its exports of elaborately transformed manufactures—that is, the highest value added products that we can produce in this country which provide highly skilled work opportunities for Australians.

PARA.TAB: That is where we are succeeding in broaching new market opportunities in Asia and the rest of the world. That is because of the micro-economic reform that we have conducted as a country, the improved efficiency of our industry, the reform of our labour market and the ability of Australian entrepreneurs to seize on this and win new markets for themselves. The other thing that has to be remembered is that the world is still, largely, in economic recession.

I refer to the locomotive economies of the world, the ones we have traditionally relied on to lift economic performance globally. The economy of Japan will probably return, in the year ending 30 March 1994, a negative growth of about half a per cent. The locomotive economy in Europe is Germany. This calendar year the German economy will contract by about two per cent. The United States, the other great pillar of economic growth in advanced industrialised economies in the world, is batting along at about a 2.3 to 2.5 per cent growth.

It is salutary to recognise that the growth figure for Australia as at 30 June 1993 was 3.3 per cent—at the head of the OECD table. That is to say, in the face of the world economic recession that has bedevilled the West, Australia's rate of growth is the highest of any developed country in the world. Let us hear a comment of approval for Australia. Let us hear a bit of economic patriotism from those opposite. Let us hear a bit of analysis that encourages Australians to take advantage of the massive export opportunities that are growing in the Asia-Pacific region. Then this question can be seen for what it is—an attempt to slight those who have performed well for Australia and to confuse the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to forecasts of a poor rice harvest in Japan this year and ask the minister whether this means Japan may have to consider importing rice. If so, can the minister inform the Senate what the government is doing to promote the interests of Australian rice exporters?

—I have seen reports in several newspapers today that the Japanese government is considering opening its market for the importation of rice. Northern Asia has suffered a poor winter and with adverse weather conditions, both in Korea and Japan, the rice harvest in both those countries is coming in at well under the anticipated level of consumption. It may well be that, this year, the Japanese government will be looking to import two million tonnes of rice. Australia would be a prime source of supply to fill that market gap.

PARA.TAB: The good news is that Australian rice growers have in store sufficient stocks to meet whatever demand is called upon to be supplied into that Japanese market. The Australian government has, of course, consistently registered with the government of Japan the need for it to open its rice markets and to regard the Australian product as a product that it can draw upon to meet the needs of its own consumers. We are competitive as a rice supplier in the world, both in terms of price and in terms of the quality of our product. Indeed, it can be said that Australian grown rice suits the needs of Japan almost more than other rice from any source. It is not, however, appropriate for a government to be grateful that weather conditions have created a marketing opportunity. While one should take advantage of that marketing opportunity, there are some structural issues about the Japanese market that need to be addressed here.

This time last week I was in Tokyo. I met the Prime Minister, Mr Hosokawa; the Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Mr Hata; and the Minister for International Trade and Industry, Mr Kumagai. In my role as trade minister, I put to all three of them that it was important that Japan cease its policy of self-sufficiency and adopt a policy of food security, that is, not to try to produce all their food needs domestically but, rather, to have a mix of imports and domestic production as well and open their market accordingly.

Secondly, the issue that begs for a comment here is the issue of the Uruguay Round. Both the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Industry and Trade in Japan are firmly committed to the completion of the Uruguay Round by 15 December. They reassured me solidly on that point. But for the round to properly be completed with a balanced outcome across all sectors and in a fair way, it is important that the issue of agriculture be addressed. Specifically, in Japan and Korea that means addressing the closed rice market. The views that Australia has consistently argued—that the market should be opened—were again put by me as a means of successfully concluding the Uruguay Round. That means a commitment by Japan for comprehensive tariffication of its market barriers for rice across the board without exception. In view of this shortfall in domestic production, I hope that can be something that the government seizes on as a positive signal to help complete the Uruguay Round this year and reduce the price for Japan's own domestic producers in the interests of freer trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the government's proposal to introduce a one per cent tax on the diesel fuel rebate scheme. In the event of this legislation becoming law, if a farmer, hospital or mining company claims a $10,000 rebate under the scheme and Customs deducts the one per cent tax—that being $100—from that amount, will the farmer, hospital or mining company then be able to claim a tax deduction for that $100 as a legitimate business expense in the same manner as that farmer, hospital or mining company would do for other taxes?
—The responsibility for this particular piece of legislation is actually with the customs portfolio, not mine, but I will inquire into the matter and get an answer for Senator Ferguson.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has said he will obtain that information from the Australian Customs Service. Could he also find out the net benefit to the government that would be received from that proposed tax and advise the Senate whether it will in fact be far less than the $10 million in actual return to the government that is cited in the budget papers? If it is going to be far less than the amount quoted in the budget papers, is it the government's intention to raise that tax even further?
—Why didn't you ask it originally? It is not a supplementary.

—We are getting to the extraordinary situation where supplementary questions are longer than the original, bear very little relationship to the original and bear no relationship to the answer which was given. I am not quite sure how it properly constitutes a supplementary question but, to the extent that there is any useful information that can be supplied in response to Senator Ferguson's question, I am happy to supply it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to a report in yesterday's Australian Financial Review regarding the minister's presentation last week of the inaugural award to the ACT small business woman of the year. The report indicates that the minister sees the dominant position of men in small business as under challenge. What is the basis of the minister's comment and how long does he expect it to be before women outnumber men in small business?

—I thank Senator Zakharov for her question. Last Wednesday I had the great honour of representing the Australian government at the presentation at Woden hosted by the Business and Professional Women's Club of Canberra as part of the ACT small business—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber and I ask that they cease.

—Last week I had the honour of presenting awards, on behalf of the Australian government, at a function hosted by the Business and Professional Women's Club of Canberra as part of the ACT small business week. During my speech, I referred to the published research, entitled Employment patterns and practices in small firms in Australia: an assessment of skill deficiencies and training needs, undertaken by Professor Alan Williams of the University of Newcastle. In his research he found that, of the more than 11,000 businesses surveyed, 38 per cent were owned and operated by men, 33 per cent were owned and operated by women and 28 per cent were jointly owned and operated by men and women.

PARA.TAB: He also indicated that there was a marked shift towards women owning and running their own firms. If this trend continues, it is anticipated that certainly by the middle to the latter part of this decade a majority of small or micro businesses in Australia will be run and owned by women. We still do not have enough research on why this is occurring, but it is quite clear from anecdotal information around the place that women are more successful at running their own businesses than men.

We believe that women are better at customer service and industrial relations. From what I have been told in discussions with the financial institutions, women are more cautious in their financial arrangements. They are better managers of the finances of a small business. They more thoroughly prepare their business plan for their small businesses than do men. One banker told me that if he had to choose between lending money for a small business to a man or a woman, he would lend to the woman because, on balance, according to the figures available, women are more likely to be more successful in running a small business.

I think this is one of the significant changes in our society that has not been recognised. As small business is already providing the biggest part of economic growth and employment growth in Australia, we have to give due recognition to the fact that it is women who are doing it to ensure that we get the job growth for all Australians.

The only area where we would like to see some increase in women's activity is the area of export oriented industries. A survey by the export access program shows that only about two per cent of those businesses that are successfully into export are actually owned and run by women. That is one area in which we would like to see an improvement in women's participation. Overall, this trend is very good for women but, above all else, it means a good outcome for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the minister admit that the current waterfront dispute, which the minister said today has ended and which cost shipping operators about $2 million, arose because the government squibbed on the main issue of labour flexibility in its waterfront reform program, despite repeated warnings from the opposition? When will the government concede that it got it wrong and that it is the job-for-life on the waterfront that is the problem?

—No, that is not the case. At this morning's meeting with the parties I heard proposals for additional flexibility on the waterfront being discussed that I have not heard being discussed in the three years that I have been responsible for this portfolio. I was extremely encouraged by that result.

PARA.TAB: I should point out what happened when the original question was asked, and I hope that Senator Sandy Macdonald noticed it. A barrage of interjections came from his colleagues on the opposition benches, who were clearly praying for an extension and continuation of the dock strike. It is totally consistent with the expression of their obvious disappointment that the industrial disputation would not be enlarged and would not continue. It is consistent with the permanent opposition mentality that has developed in the opposition here in the Senate and the completely negative approach it is taking to anything in here, despite the impact that it might have on Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of an article in this morning's Australian Financial Review entitled `It's a man's Games, isn't it?' about the search for an executive to run the Sydney Olympic Games organisation? Can she comment on why the chances of a woman getting the top job or there being a `Ms 2000' is summed up as virtually non-existent by some of Australia's top head-hunters?

—I am aware of the article by Sheryle Bagwell in today's Australian Financial Review. In that article, Ms Bagwell cites a tabloid newspaper which spoke of a search for Mr 2000, the executive who will be given the massive task of running the Sydney Olympic Games organisation. Indeed, one could say that the Olympic bid team was not back in Australia one day before Mr Fahey and Mr Baird were contesting for the position. It looks as though Mr Baird lost out to Mr Fahey. Perhaps it will go the other way; we will wait and see.

PARA.TAB: Sheryle Bagwell says that she could not find a head-hunter willing to put any money on there being a woman chief executive for the Sydney Olympic Games organisation. Sadly, that is still not surprising. Despite the enormous gains made by women over the last decade, there is still not one woman chief executive at the helm of any of Australia's top 200 companies. The top 10 companies do not have one female board member. Women make up only 1.3 per cent of senior managers.

As illustrated so graphically at the Trust the Women launch the other day, there are still too few women in our parliaments. This has been mirrored so far in the management of our bid for the Olympics. According to Ms Bagwell, while there were women on the honorary committee, there were none on the bid's executive board.

I fully support the call that women be fully represented on the new 11-member board of directors which is to choose the new chief executive for the games organisation. I also want to see women making up 50 per cent of the many thousands of employees who will be an integral part of Australia's massive games effort.

I am also very keen to see young women fully participating in the games. Honourable senators opposite would know, as do my colleagues, that I have never supported the appointment of women to any position except on the basis of merit. That is why I strongly support the participation of women in the Olympic games. It may come as something of a shock to the opposition, but one thing that we have from the Women and media report is the largely unrecognised and unheralded record of Australian women in sport.
In the Olympic sports from 1948 to 1992, Australian women won 39 per cent of all the medals, but they comprised only 21 per cent of all the teams.

TALK.START.PARA: —And got the gold.

—I thank Senator Robert Ray; that was my very next point. I am glad to be assisted by him. The other point that needs to be made is that women have won 11 of the 14 gold medals won by Australians for track and field events since the Olympics in 1948. So Australian women do it very well. They do this country very proud. They will be there, competing for gold, as they have in the past Olympics, and, once again, contributing splendidly.

PARA.TAB: We saw the contribution of women in our Olympic bid. We want women to have the opportunity to make the contribution that we know they are so capable of, be it on the sports field, in business or on the Olympic committee. I hope that, with the other achievements of government, we will see the private sector and this Olympic bid committee taking up the challenge to have a fair representation of women on the board. Perhaps they will surprise us after all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is time to put an end to the excitement. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax on Business Travel

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to the proposed extension of the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan's answer was very curious. It was curious because of its stupidity and its ignorance. It comes hard upon the heels of the pious poppycock that the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, speaks about small business. It is pretty obvious that neither Senator Schacht nor Senator McMullan have ever had anything to do with small business. The way they run their portfolios—

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you had?

—Do those opposite want to know, because I will tell them what experience I have had in small business. I have run small businesses employing 20 to 25 people in three towns in North Queensland. That is my experience in small business. I have also invested in small business in the tourist industry.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht, by comparison, has spent his life working for the Labor Party or being a teacher. I think Senator McMullan had some success as an apparatchik of the Labor Party, but he certainly has had no success when it comes to money, business or dealing with the economy.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner is another member of the government who would know a lot about small business. He spent all of his life running the figures for the Left in New South Wales. He would not have a clue. That is the same for the whole front bench of the Labor Party. They would not understand what business is about and they would not understand what hard work is about.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan answered my question by saying that this measure would raise revenue and create jobs. The budget was supposed to be about creating jobs. I ask Senator McMullan to point out to me how putting a fringe benefits tax on the hotel, accommodation and tourist industry creates jobs. Nobody else in Australia can understand that. I would appreciate it if Senator McMullan could tell us about that.

I read in the Australian Financial Review the other day that Access Economics indicated that had the FBT on business travel gone through, as originally announced in the budget, then there would have been between 10,000 and 20,000 jobs lost, principally from small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted to put 15 per cent on every small business in Australia.

—Senator Schacht, as the Minister for small business, might be interested to know that those jobs would have come out of small business. Those 10,000 to 20,000 people would be added to the 35 per cent of youths unemployed already. It is young people who are employed in the hotel and tourist industry.
