SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL (No. 1) 1993

PARA.TAB: Mr. President, this bill is part of a package of bills designed to replace the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, which was introduced into the Senate on 7 September 1993. That bill contained the Government's key Budget taxation measures.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of its campaign to obstruct the passage of the Government's 1993-4 Budget, the Opposition referred the Deficit Reduction Bill to a Senate Committee. The Committee was asked to determine whether, by combining measures dealing with several subjects of taxation, the bill contravened section 55 of the Constitution.
Parliament has been passing taxation bills combining several subjects of taxation since at least 1984. Only now has this been raised as an issue.
The Government's senior legal advisers, and Parliamentary Counsel, gave advice to the Committee that the Deficit Reduction Bill was clearly valid and that none of its measures imposed taxation.
The Senate Committee concluded, correctly, that only the High Court can determine issues of constitutional validity.

The Committee also concluded that there was a risk that the bill would be declared invalid. This conclusion was contrary to the advice of the Government's Chief General Counsel and of other experts who presented their views to the Committee.
The Government does not accept the Committee's conclusion. Moreover, the Committee gave no reasons for its conclusions and gave the Government no guidance as to how to split the bill.
Views put to the Committee that the bill is invalid fall into two categories.
first, that any increase in the formal rate of a tax is an imposition of tax. This view draws an illogical distinction between a rate increase and an enlargement of a tax base.

second, that any increase in liability to taxation is an imposition of tax. If this argument is accepted, then most of the tax laws passed over the past 50 years are also invalid. This is an absurd argument.
The Government is entitled to rely on the clear and unequivocal advice of its legal advisers.
Nevertheless, the Opposition's actions on the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill have created considerable uncertainty.
The Government has decided to remove that uncertainty and withdraw the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill and to re-introduce the Budget measures in a package of related bills.

Apart from the measures included in the `test case' bill, the re-packaged bills would not be challenged by those who argue that the only amendments in the package which impose tax are those which increase a rate of tax.

The Government has deliberately rejected the extreme view that any increase in the incidence of a tax is an imposition of tax. It has, therefore, refrained from structuring these bills to avoid a challenge from this quarter. If that view is correct, then virtually all of the Commonwealth's tax laws are invalid. It would be pointless to address those concerns without rewriting the corpus of all the existing tax laws.
The bills comprised in this package are:
the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bills (Nos. 1 to 3) 1993; and
5 sales tax bills.
Each of the bills has been marked with a `T' to signify that they are not bills which impose taxation.

The Government also believes that the constitutional issues must be resolved once and for all, so that the Parliament can focus on the substance, and not the form, of Government initiatives. To allow the issue to be settled quickly, and without affecting the integrity of the Budget package, one of the bills (the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993) has been drafted as a test bill to facilitate a High Court challenge. This has been done by combining 2 minor rate increases involving different subjects of taxation. These measures do not affect revenue until after 1 July 1994.
I turn now to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993, which contains the following measures:
Increases in the Medicare levy low income thresholds.
Removal of the concessional treatment that applies to the taxation of unused annual and long service leave.
Changes in the taxation treatment of excess domestic travel allowances and expenses and certain non-deductible expenses.
Denial of income tax deductions for car parking expenses for self-employed persons.
Changes in the taxation treatment of credit unions.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Medicare levy
This bill will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the low income thresholds below which people will not be required to pay any levy.
For 1993-94, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $12,688 and couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $21,366 will not be required to pay the levy.
There will be no change to the provisions which increase the threshold for couples and sole parents by $2100 for each dependent child or student.
The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $30 million in 1993-94, $60 million in 1994-95 and $45 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Unused annual leave and unused long service leave payments
The bill will remove the concessional tax treatment that applies to lump sum payments of unused annual leave and unused long service leave made on termination of employment.

Payments in respect of unused long service leave accrued on or after 18 August 1993 and payments in respect of unused annual leave made on or after 18 August 1978 will be taxed as normal income. However, there is no change to the tax treatment of these payments if the taxpayer's termination of employment is as a consequence of bona fide redundancy or invalidity or is under an approved early retirement scheme. Neither is the concessional tax treatment of long service leave accrued before 18 August 1993 affected.
The proposed amendments ensure that the tax system does not discourage taxpayers from using their leave entitlements for their intended purpose.
The estimated gain to the revenue is $80 million in 1993-94, $180 million in 1994-95, $165 million in 1995-96 and $180 million in 1996-97.
Taxation of credit unions

The bill will remove the exemption from income tax for income in the nature of interest received by credit unions on loans made to their senators and will allow credit unions to be taxed as cooperatives where they satisfy the requirements for that treatment. To give credit unions time to adjust to the new measures, there will be a phasing-in period.

The measure will remove the competitive advantage credit unions enjoy as a result of the special tax treatment given to them, and is consistent with the Government's general approach of ensuring tax neutrality between business enterprises.
The estimated gain to revenue is $25 million in 1995-96 and $30 million in 1996-97.
Non-deductible expenses

The income tax law will also be amended to allow deductions to employers for expenses incurred in providing their employees with a range of benefits such as entertainment, club fees, leisure facilities, travel expenses of accompanying relatives, Higher Education Contribution Scheme payments and Student Financial Supplement Scheme payments. These expenses have previously not been deductible.

Benefits of this nature, if provided to employees, are fringe benefits under the fringe benefits tax law. However, the taxable value of these benefits is reduced to the extent to which they are non-deductible to employers under the income tax law.

This amendment, which will apply from 1 April 1994, will allow a deduction to employers for these expenses under the income tax law. In consequence, it will subject these benefits to a fringe benefits tax liability.
The estimated gain to revenue is $435 million in 1994-95, $240 million in 1995-96 and $240 million in 1996-97.
Excess domestic travel

This bill will amend the fringe benefits tax law to create a new class of fringe benefit based on the amount of a travelling allowance received by an employee for travel in Australia which is in excess of a prescribed amount. The amount will be prescribed by regulation and will be set following consultations with interested parties.

The income tax law will also be amended to disallow expenditure incurred by employees or self-employed persons on travel expenses (ie. accommodation, food, drink, and expenditure incidental to travel undertaken in Australia) which are in excess of the prescribed amount.
These amendments will apply from 1 April 1994.
The estimated gain to revenue is $60 million in 1994-95 and $45 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Car parking expenses for self-employed

The bill will also amend the income tax law so that, from 1 July 1994, a tax deduction for the cost of car parking for persons other than employees will be denied in certain circumstances. This will place car parking by self-employed persons on a comparable tax basis to car parking for employees.

A deduction for car parking expenses incurred by self-employed persons will only be denied where certain conditions apply. The rules for determining the non-deductible amount of a car parking expense in this bill are similar to the rules applic
able to employers in valuing a car parking fringe benefit.
The estimated gain to revenue of this measure is $70 million in 1995-96 and $35 million in 1996-97.
The bill will come into operation on the day on which it receives Royal Assent.

TAXATION (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill is the second in the package of bills which replace the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

the increase in the rate of fringe benefits tax; and

the change in the taxation treatment of friendly societies, including an increase in the rate of tax on their life insurance business to bring it into line with the rate of tax on similar business undertaken by life companies.

This bill has been deliberately designed to facilitate a challenge in the High Court on the constitutional issues raised before the Senate Committee that considered the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill. It does this by combining two rate increases, for different subjects of taxation, in the same bill. The Government's legal advisers believe that this bill is constitutional but the Government considers that any uncertainty in this area must be resolved quickly.

The measures in this bill will have no practical effect before the middle of next year, and will have only minimal revenue impacts. Therefore, there is time for the constitutional issues to be tested without affecting taxpayers.
I turn now to a more detailed explanation of the two measures.
FBT rate of tax
This bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the current rate of fringe benefits tax from 48.25 per cent to 48.4 per cent. The increase will take effect from

1 April 1994 and will maintain the alignment of the FBT rate with the top marginal personal tax rate and Medicare levy rate. The increase reflects the increase in the Medicare levy rate, from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent, on 1 July 1993.
The estimated gain to revenue is $9 million in 1994-95 and $8 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Taxation of friendly societies and other registered organisations
The bill will change the taxation treatment of friendly societies and other registered organisations.
It will phase-out, over three years from the 1994-95 income year, the concessional tax rate for friendly societies in respect of their life insurance and certain other insurance business.

As a consequence of that change, the bill will, from 1 July 1994, extend to friendly societies the same entitlement to deductions as is allowed to life insurance companies for the costs of getting in their life insurance premiums.

Another change will increase, from 1 July 1995, the rebate available to holders of friendly society life policies who are assessed on bonuses. This increase is a consequence of the phasing-out of the concessional tax rate.
The estimated gain to revenue from these measures is $25 million in 1995-96 and $69 million in 1996-97.

TAXATION (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill is the third in the package of bills which replace the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: It incorporates changes to the timing of the first stage of the tax cuts announced and legislated for in 1992, the deferral of the second round of those tax cuts, and the introduction of a low income rebate.
I turn now to a more detailed explanation of the provisions.
Personal tax cuts
The amendments contained in the bill will change the timing for the commencement of the two stage reduction in the tax rates announced in One Nation on 26 February 1992.

The first stage will now commence on 15 November 1993, seven and a half months earlier than scheduled. The bill provides that the second stage of tax cuts will commence at the beginning of a financial year to be fixed by regulation.

Because the first stage of the tax cuts will commence on 15 November 1993, the bill contains the new composite rate scales to apply for 1993-94 and the first stage rates for the 1994-95 and later income years.
The new rates to apply from 15 November 1993 will benefit taxpayers with taxable incomes in excess of $20,700.
The tax cuts will cost the revenue $1.55 billion this financial year. The ongoing cost to revenue of the first stage of the personal tax cuts is $2.9 billion in 1994-95 and $3.12 billion in 1995-96.
Low income rebate

The bill will also provide a rebate of up to $150 to taxpayers whose taxable income for 1993-94 and subsequent income years is less than $24,450. The new rebate will mainly assist those taxpayers who do not benefit from the One Nation tax cuts.

Taxpayers with a taxable income of up to $20,700 will be entitled to a rebate of $150 in their assessments for the 1993-94 and later income years. The rebate will reduce at the rate of 4 cents in each dollar of taxable income in excess of $20,700 and completely phase-out when taxable income reaches $24,450.
The estimated revenue costs for this measure are $530 million in 1994-95, $515 million in 1995-96 and $500 million in 1996-97.

SALES TAX (CUSTOMS) (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Mr President, this bill is the fourth in the package of bills designed to replace the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. This bill, together with four other bills in this package, will give effect to changes to the sales tax law announced in the 1993-4 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not accept that any of the bills in this package imposes tax. Nevertheless, it has structured the sales tax bills so as to put the matter beyond challenge by those who would argue that an increase in a formal rate of tax is an imposition of tax.
For constitutional reasons, sales tax is imposed by four Acts. Those Acts impose sales tax to the extent that it is:
a duty of customs;
a duty of excise;
a tax on in situ swimming pools;
a tax that is none of the above.
This bill modifies the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Act 1992 to the extent that that Act deals with tax imposed by the Sales Tax Imposition (Customs) Act 1992.
Mr President, I now turn to the three sales tax changes covered by this bill, and the other sales tax bills in this package.

The first change will increase all sales tax rates by one percentage point, with effect from 18 August 1993. This is expected to raise $435 million this year and $585 million in 1994-95. A further one percentage point increase for all sales tax rates will come into effect on 1 July 1995.

The second change will increase the rates of sales tax on wine, also with effect from 18 August. Compared with beer and spirits, wine is lightly taxed. While it is presently subject to sales tax, it does not carry any excise.
It is proposed to increase the rate of tax on wine with an alcoholic content of greater than 1.15 per cent from 20 per cent to 31 per cent.

The rate of tax on low-alcohol wine, that is wine with an alcoholic content of 1.15 per cent or less, is to increase from 10 per cent to 21 per cent. Some low-alcohol wine is currently taxable at 20 per cent and its rate of tax will increase to 21 per cent in line with the proposed increase for all sales tax rates.
The gain to revenue from this measure is estimated to be $70 million in 1993-94, $95 million in 1994-95, $105 million in 1995-96 and $110 million in 1996-97.

The last sales tax change will vary the rate of tax applicable to luxury motor vehicles, also with effect from 18 August 1993. Luxury vehicles are currently taxable at 30 per cent on their entire wholesale value. The current sales tax treatment results in a substantial pricing distortion: the addition of one dollar to the wholesale price of a passenger motor vehicle now priced at the threshold would increase the sales tax liability by $4873.

It is proposed to remove this distortion by applying a split rate of sales tax to luxury motor vehicles. Broadly, the ordinary rates of sales tax applicable to motor vehicles will apply up to the wholesale luxury threshold. A rate of 45 per cent will apply to that portion of the wholesale value over the luxury threshold.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the Qantas Sale Act 1992 received royal assent on 21 December 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill is a portfolio bill which will make minor amendments to the Commonwealth's anti-discrimination legislation, the Privacy Act 1988 and the High Court of Australia Act 1979. I will only outline the significant parts of this bill, as a number of the amendments it contains are merely technical or made as a result of other legislative amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, amendments were made to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 to simplify and streamline the procedure for enforcing determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in the Federal Court. Briefly, that procedure provides that the determination, on being registered in the Federal Court, becomes enforceable as an order of the court after 28 days, unless the respondent to the determination applies for review of the determination within this period. I am concerned that this strict 28 day time limit may cause injustice in some circumstances, so I have introduced amendments to allow the Federal Court to review a determination outside this 28 day time limit in exceptional circumstances.
The bill will make a number of amendments to the Privacy Act.

The procedures for making a representative complaint and for enforcing determinations under the Privacy Act will be replaced by new provisions modelled on last year's amendments to the Disability Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and Sex Discrimination Act. In addition, the amendments I have just outlined to allow a respondent to seek the leave of the court to have a determination reviewed outside the usual 28 day period, will be included in the Privacy Act.

The bill will also clarify that compensation awarded by the Privacy Commissioner to a complainant as part of a determination can include compensation for loss or damage suffered by way of injury to feelings or humiliation. This will bring the Privacy Act provisions into line with the position under the Crimes Act 1914 (in relation to spent convictions) and the Disability Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Sex Discrimination Act.
These amendments will ensure greater consistency in the legislation administered by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

The bill will amend the rules under the Privacy Act governing disclosures of credit information by credit providers to state and territory government authorities administering schemes which assist low-income earners to obtain mortgage credit. It was brought to the Government's notice that the Privacy Act, as it is currently structured, does not sufficiently cater to the information needs of a number of states that operate, and effectively underwrite, mortgage assistance schemes. The amendment will resolve the information needs of the governments without unreasonably infringing the privacy of individual borrowers.

I am introducing an amendment which will delay the commencement date of the superannuation amendments which were inserted in the Sex Discrimination Act in 1991. These provisions were to commence in June this year in order to give superannuation funds time to develop options to allow existing members to transfer to non-discriminatory schemes. The guidelines to be formulated by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to assist funds to develop non-discriminatory options were not finalised in sufficient time. Accordingly, I have introduced an amendment to delay commencement of the provisions until 1 July 1994 to allow time for the funds to be in a position to comply with the new regime.

The amendments to the High Court of Australia Act 1979 will change the administrative structure of the High Court by amalgamating the existing offices and responsibilities of the Clerk of the Court and the Registrar into one office which is to be called the Chief Executive and Principal Registrar. This will streamline the administration of the court by avoiding duplication of the functions currently performed by the Clerk and the Registrar. The Chief Justice has specifically requested and approved these amendments.

OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (MARITIME INDUSTRY) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Australians and the Australian economy pay dearly for work-related fatalities, injuries and industrial diseases. The Industry Commission, in its recently released draft report into workers compensation in Australia, has noted that every year there are at least 500 deaths, 200,000 injuries and an unknown number of people who fall ill principally because of hazards they have been exposed to at work.

SPEECH.PARA: The monetary costs are estimated to be of the order of $10 billion annually.
Employees, their families, employers, insurers and society in general all bear this burden.
Non-monetary costs, such as the pain and suffering of an injured employee or the loss of a loved one killed in a work-related accident, cannot be calculated.

In the Australian shipping industry alone, over the past 5 years there has been an average of 1,000 injuries a year reported to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Many of these injuries could have been avoided.
The purpose of this bill is to make the maritime industry a healthier and safer industry to work in.
The bill has two key elements:
Firstly, it establishes a consultative framework for the ship operator and maritime industry workers to cooperate in developing a safer working environment and better work practices.
Secondly, it sets out the duties of care to be observed by all who work on board ships and offshore industry mobile units. This element, in effect, codifies the common law.

Mr President, over the past decade or so, all Australian states, territories and the Commonwealth have developed new style OHS legislation based on International Labour Organisation Convention No 155—the Occupational Safety and Health Convention 1981.

This national approach was reinforced in 1985, when this government established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to provide national coordination, facilitate national action and raise public awareness of OHS issues.

The arrangements set out in the bill are based on the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 and are similar to the arrangements provided under the occupational health and safety laws of the Australian states and territories.

Last year, parliament passed legislation introducing a new workers compensation scheme for seafarers. One of the vital elements of that scheme is its mandatory rehabilitation arrangements, aimed at getting injured workers restored to health and back to work as quickly as possible.
The new OHS arrangements will complement the new seafarers compensation legislation by addressing the causes of accidents and thus reducing workplace injuries.
To reinforce this complementary element, the administration of the new maritime OHS arrangements will be combined with the administration of the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992.
The authority will have its functions expanded to reflect its new responsibilities and its name will be changed to the Seafarers Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority.
Mr President, I will now describe the major features of the bill.
General duties of care

The provisions contained in Part 2 of the bill set out in general terms the mutual responsibilities of ship operators, employees and contractors, as well as the responsibilities of manufacturers and suppliers of plant and substances used on ships.

In essence, all parties must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the workplace and the work performed there do not endanger the safety or health of the workers, or of any other person in the vicinity.

Included in the employer's responsibilities is the important requirement to give employees the necessary information, instruction, training and supervision to perform their work safely and in a way that does not risk their health.
Mr President, as part of those responsibilities, industry employers and the maritime unions have been jointly developing industry-wide training packages suitable for use on board ships.
I congratulate the industry on this initiative, which will allow seafarers to keep up to date with their OHS training during their off-duty periods.
Workplace arrangements

The bill provides a framework for employers and employees to cooperate and consult in addressing health and safety matters in the workplace. It does this through the establishment of designated work groups and health and safety committees, and the selection of health and safety representatives.

The workplace arrangements provide mechanisms for the health and safety representatives of the shipboard work groups to work with shipboard management in ensuring safe working practices and in identifying and eliminating work hazards.
I do not intend to describe these arrangements in detail. However, it is important to note a number of aspects in relation to the powers of a health and safety representative.
The representative has the power to issue a provisional improvement notice requiring the person in command to take corrective action to stop or to avoid an unsafe practice.
If the person in command and a health and safety representative cannot agree on the solution to a problem, the bill provides for intervention by an inspector.

In addition, if the representative believes there is an immediate threat to health and safety, the representative may order a cessation of the activity in question. This action can only be taken in an emergency and only if a supervisor cannot immediately be located.
The cessation of work must be immediately reported to a supervisor so that an assessment can be made as to whether it is safe to resume the activity.
Standards and codes of practice

An important aspect of the bill, in terms of the government's commitment to encouraging a uniform national approach to OHS, is that it provides for the adoption of suitable standards and codes of practice which have been declared by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission.
However, account will also need to be taken of the standards imposed on shipping by international maritime safety conventions and international labour conventions, through the Navigation Act.
Inspectorate

While the legislation's co-regulatory approach, which I have already outlined, emphasises cooperation in ensuring health and safety in the workplace, there needs to be effective enforcement of standards. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) will have inspectorate responsibilities under the bill.

AMSA has extensive experience in dealing with health and safety matters on Australian and foreign ships in its administration of the Navigation Act and the judgement and skills of AMSA's marine surveyors are widely acknowledged throughout the industry.
AMSA is developing appropriate OHS training courses for its surveyors, to reinforce their existing knowledge and experience.
Appeals
The bill provides for appeals against the decisions of inspectors. Appeals may be made to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, referred to in the bill as the `reviewing authority'.
Sanctions
The bill provides that financial penalties can be imposed on employers or employees who breach the legislation.
Manufacturers and suppliers will also be liable to prosecution and fines for contravening the legislation.
If a health and safety representative abuses his or her powers, the representative can be disqualified for up to five years.
Conclusion
Mr President, over the past decade the Labor Government has introduced a number of far-reaching reforms for the shipping industry and the waterfront.
These reforms have resulted in large productivity gains and significant improvements in industry sector competitiveness.
In the shipping industry, there has been nearly a 40 per cent reduction in crew sizes on modern ships, compared with the situation ten years ago.

This bill is another step in the reform program. It will bring the maritime industry into line with the modern OHS arrangements applicable in the states and in Commonwealth employment, ensuring a safer working environment for seafarers.
This, in turn, will further reduce costs to the maritime industry and the many industries it serves.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

MARITIME LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to complete the process of bringing Australia's maritime zones into line with those to which Australia is entitled under international law as reflected in the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The Bill makes changes to existing law in four principal areas. These are establishment of rights in an exclusive economic zone, adoption of a revised definition of the continental shelf, assertion of rights in a contiguous zone and adoption of new international legal provisions for the drawing of territorial sea baselines.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal legislation to be amended is the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973. The Bill amends, in a consequential way, a number of other pieces of legislation.

At present the Seas and Submerged Lands Act refers to the 1958 Geneva Conventions on Territorial Sea and Continental Shelf. References to those Conventions are no longer appropriate. In 1982 a new United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea was adopted and signed by Australia. Australia has not yet ratified the Convention. That Convention, however, now has 56 ratifications and is likely to enter into force in the near future (it needs 60 ratifications to do so). It is, apart from the provisions relating to mining of the deep seabed, generally accepted as reflective of international law. The Government considers that in relation to maritime zones the Convention should govern Australian practice.

At present, consultations are taking place under the auspices of the Secretary-General of the United Nations with a view to overcoming some of the difficulties that have arisen under the Convention in relation to the provisions dealing with deep seabed mining. If these consultations are successful Australia and other developed States will be in a position to give serious consideration to ratifying the Convention and hence ensuring that it is universally accepted as the law on the subject. It is therefore appropriate, at this time, for Australia to amend its domestic law to bring its practice in relation to maritime zones into conformity with that provided for in the 1982 Convention. As I indicated earlier Australia considers the maritime zone aspects of the Convention to be reflective of customary international law.

Australia has, over the years, gradually asserted its various maritime entitlements under international law. Thus, in 1983 certain territorial sea baselines were proclaimed and in 1990 a 12 nautical mile territorial sea was established in place of the previous 3 nautical mile territorial sea. As long ago as 1979 Australia established a 200 nm fishing zone. The current Bill will complete the process of bringing Australia's maritime zones up-to-date. It replaces operative provisions in Commonwealth legislation which refer to the 1958 Conventions with references to the 1982 Convention.

The Bill makes clear that Australia asserts the full rights to which it is entitled under international law in a 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone. As stated in the preamble to the Bill, the rights that Australia has in such a zone include not just sovereign rights over both living and non-living resources but also jurisdiction as provided for in international law in relation to the establishment and use of artificial islands, installations and structures, marine scientific research and protection and preservation of the marine environment. The sovereign rights and the jurisdiction which a coastal State possesses in its exclusive economic zone in regard to these matters are set out in detail in the 1982 Law of the Sea Convention, the relevant parts of which form a schedule to the Bill. It will be for future legislation to deal expressly with matters such as pollution control in the exclusive economic zone.

The Bill also adopts the definition of the continental shelf in the 1982 Convention. The 1958 Convention defines the outer limit of the continental shelf in terms of a depth of 200 metres or beyond that to a depth capable of exploitation. This open ended definition has proved unsatisfactory and customary international law has recognised that the limit of the continental shelf is the edge of the continental margin, and that it does not include the deep seabed. The 1982 Convention contains in Article 76 a precise definition of the continental shelf. This is a minimum 200 nautical miles regardless of the physical configuration of the shelf. Beyond that distance, where the configuration of the continental shelf allows, however, the limit may extend to a distance not exceeding 350 nautical miles from the baseline or 100 nautical miles from the 2,500 metre isobath. This limit is calculated either by reference to the depth of sediments or the distance from the foot of the continental slope, defined by gradient. Adoption of the 1982 definition will enable Australia to claim a larger total area of continental shelf than under the 1958 Convention. The gains made by adopting the new definition outweigh any potential minor losses and will bring Australian legislation into conformity with internationally accepted principles.

The Bill also for the first time in Commonwealth legislation deals expressly with a contiguous zone. This zone extends from the limit of the territorial sea to a distance no greater than 24 nm from the territorial sea baselines. It is a zone in which a coastal State can exercise rights of control to prevent infringement of customs, fiscal, immigration or sanitary laws and to punish infringement of the above laws committed within its territory or territorial sea. It is envisaged that specific legislation such as the customs or quarantine legislation will in due course be amended to assert more fully the rights to which Australia is entitled in such a zone.

The Bill amends in a consequential way a number of Acts as set out in Schedule 1. These amendments mostly relate to the definition of `continental shelf' in those pieces of legislation so as to remove references to the 1958 Convention. One amendment of particular note is the alteration of the adjacent area boundary under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act in relation to Tasmania and Western Australia. This will ensure that the operation of that Act extends to all the areas of continental shelf which Australia is entitled to claim under the 1982 definition. The existing adjacent area `picture frames' which are used in certain offshore area legislation do not extend far enough in those two areas.
The relevant parts of the 1982 Convention are set out in schedule 2 to the Bill and will form part of the revised Seas and Submerged Lands Act.

Mr President, the passage of this legislation reflects the need for Australia with its significant interests as both a coastal and maritime State to position itself to take advantage of developments in the law of the sea. Australia's action in this regard will promote further consolidation of coastal and maritime State rights and obligations as set out in the 1982 Convention.
I mention that the Bill does not affect the offshore constitutional settlement. The States and Northern Territory are consulted in relation to maritime issues and I expect this to continue.
The Bill will have no direct financial impact.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993, which contains proposals by the government to change the oath of allegiance given by Australians who take out citizenship in this country. To say that this is premature is an understatement indeed. It is well ahead of its time. If Australia were ever to become a republic, one might then change the oath of allegiance. Until that time occurs, there is no requirement, no need and no reason to change the oath of allegiance.

PARA.TAB: The only reason the government is bringing this up now through this bill is to allocate to itself nearly a quarter of a million dollars to use towards its pro-republican campaign. That is what would flow from the passing of this bill. A sum of about a quarter of a million dollars would go to the government towards the support of its republican campaign so that it could continue to undermine the stability of this country in the way that it has been attempting to do in recent times. The government is using the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 as a vehicle to allocate that money to itself.

One of the most significant things that a person could ever do in his or her life would be to take out citizenship of another country. It is not something that I have had to do; it is not something that I would ever expect to do. But I have been to a number of citizenship ceremonies. One cannot attend a good citizenship ceremony without being impressed by the significance of the occasion and by what it must mean to a person to do that.

There are people who take out citizenship in this country because they have had to flee the country they were born in. They have had to find somewhere else to live. They would virtually have had to be without a home and without a country to belong to before they found somewhere else. This has gone on since the Second World War. A number of people came here, particularly from Europe, because they were displaced persons.

Anyone I have ever spoken to who has taken out citizenship has been moved by the occasion and the circumstances. I think of the boat people who have come here from Vietnam in more recent times. I do not believe that any one of us sitting here could contemplate or understand the feelings of people who have fled their country of birth to travel to this country in boats that are unfit to leave a wharf in the first place.

Some people live here for many years before they finally take out citizenship. Having lived in this country for perhaps a long time while retaining citizenship of another country, people find it a very emotional experience when they finally make the commitment that Australia is where they belong. Some people have come here as young people to make a life for themselves; others have come here with young children to make a life for their family in this country because of the stability and opportunities that it offers.

A citizenship ceremony, which has all of these emotions present in the air, is a very solemn, happy and moving occasion. All of that suddenly seems to be going out of the window, particular this year. I refer to the way in which the citizenship ceremonies are being run, at least in Canberra. I can only conclude that it is at the direction of the minister that the occasion should be downgraded and that the circumstances in which the ceremony takes place should no longer be presented as significant, but as a mere routine bureaucratic arrangement.

Since I have been in the Senate, the ceremonies in Canberra were held in the theatrette at the National Library. They were very simple, but moving occasions and very worth while indeed. One of the members of federal parliament from this electorate always took part and was invited to speak. For many years Australian native plants have been handed out to those who have received their citizenship as a mark of the occasion. I think that still occurs. It was an occasion where people really felt that something important had occurred.

More recently, the citizenship ceremonies have been held at the Community Centre in Dickson. That also is a very suitable place and a nice occasion. I have been to a number of excellent ceremonies there that I and those who have taken out citizenship have enjoyed. Those involved have felt that they were doing something and that their commitment to this country was being recognised.

I took part in an excellent citizenship ceremony in the open at Commonwealth Park in Canberra on Australia Day this year. It was a great occasion. There was a citizenship ceremony at a Lions Club dinner, and I also attended one to mark Refugee Week at which the ACT Chief Minister officiated. All those who took out citizenship on that occasion were refugees.

Twelve other ceremonies have taken place at the offices of the department in Canberra and in the room about which Senator Bishop spoke earlier today. In fact, today 10 groups totalling 200 people are going through that room because the space is not big enough to hold a ceremony for all 200 people at once as there is in the Dickson Community Centre, in the theatrette of the National Library or in this building, as has already been pointed out.

There are plenty of places in Canberra where one could hold a citizenship ceremony for 200 people with a little style, unlike the way it was done this morning in Canberra. Ten separate groups came in and out every few minutes, people were given a plant and they were sent on their way. No other people were invited to take part in the ceremony or to speak or to be in any way welcoming to the participants. I can only conclude that it is a deliberate policy of the Government to downgrade the nature of the ceremony. It has culminated today in this bill, which deals with changing the oath of allegiance.

I also wonder why this bill is being brought in today. It is not urgent. One would have to say that it is to fill in time in the Senate—presumably while the government attempts to get its budget program in order. Why else would we be having this rushed through today when there are, according to the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, so many other things that ought to be dealt with? Every night when he has been on the news in recent times—petulant little man that he is—he has preached about the Senate holding up the budget and business generally and the Senate not doing this and that.

The Treasurer keeps abusing us for not dealing with important legislation. Yet today this bill to change the oath of allegiance is the No. 1 priority of the Government. Let the people of Australia note that. The republican push and changing the oath of allegiance are much more important to this government than any of the other things that it keeps talking about. Let us not forget that.

There is no necessity to change the oath of allegiance at present. Nothing before us deals with changing the oath that we as members of parliament take when we are sworn in after each election. The reason is that in order for us to do so the constitution would have to be changed. Nothing before us changes the oath that a member of the armed services takes when entering the forces. I can only conclude that taking out citizenship of this country is less important to the government than any of these other things. I do not accept that as reasonable or correct.

This oath should not be changed unless there is a change to the structure of this country. I can see that one would have to change it in that event. In other words, if we became a republic, the oath as it presently stands would need to be amended. But that is not the case. For some reason, we have this matter before us today when the Treasurer keeps abusing the Senate for not dealing with the important business of the Government. He should be told what we are actually doing today.

Someone should tell the Treasurer that this morning we passed nine bills. It was a pretty good morning in the Senate. I am not suggesting that they should not have been dealt with. The protection of the sea bills were important and warranted the attention of the Senate. But we are now considering the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 as the next most important thing to be dealt with.

The bill does not deal with things such as dual nationality, which is important and has some substance; it just deals with changing the oath of allegiance to fit in with some other agenda. I refer to the oath and the pledge, as it is called, for the future. The present oath of allegiance is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

That recognises the constitutional structure of this country and its institutions. Within it the person taking out citizenship makes his or her own personal declaration: `I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen'. That is what one would expect it to say.

PARA.TAB: The pledge that we are now given contains no commitment—nothing! It states:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward, under God,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.
There is absolutely no substance to it, and anybody reading it would know that. One can only wonder why the government would come forward with a pledge in that form.

PARA.TAB: It is worth having a little look at the words that we are discussing. The oath of allegiance, which is a solemn appeal to God and a solemn commitment to some person to some thing, is being abandoned. It is an attestation of the truth of what one is saying and of the binding character of the promise to testify on oath. An oath of allegiance has some significance and depth to it.

I agree that the word `pledge' is a solemn promise. But the word `pledge' has other meanings—such as a pledge of aid; a pledge or a security for the payment of debt. Although it has a meaning of promise, it is not a word used in that fashion and it is not a word that has any real depth or meaning to it. We are not talking about such a concept when talking about taking out citizenship of this country. One can have a `promise'—I accept that word—which is a declaration with respect to the future that one will do or not do, or give or not give something. In my opinion, a promise has much more meaning to it.

The term `to swear an oath', as it is worded at the present time, means to make a solemn declaration with an oath of allegiance to Almighty God. It does not have the same meaning when used by many people who make the affirmation, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: I solemnly and sincerely declare that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

The commitment to this country should recognise the constitutional status of the country. It should show some understanding of what a person is doing in taking out the oath of allegiance and making one's commitment to this country.

PARA.TAB: Under the new wording, the oath of affirmation becomes:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

I heard another form of words recently that I think is worth bringing into the debate. It was given by emeritus Professor Ralph Elliott in a radio program in Canberra when he was asked what he thought about the change in the words. Acknowledging the Labor Party's attitude to this—which I think is probably not his own—by leaving out reference to the head of state, his suggested words were:

I hereby solemnly promise (before God) to be a loyal citizen of Australia, to obey its laws, to cherish and safeguard its democratic institutions, and to foster mutual respect between the country, all its people and myself.

That is a much more personal way of wording the commitment. It puts much more of oneself into it than the words that have been given to the Senate to consider today. I am not suggesting that Professor Elliott would change the present oath—I certainly would not—but at least that type of wording is a far more personal commitment than the words given to us today, which I regard as totally inadequate.

PARA.TAB: As I have indicated, there are two aspects to this matter; the words themselves and the complete lack of depth and meaning to the pledge that is presented, and the government's attitude towards the ceremonies which are conducted to enable people to take out citizenship. I hope the Senate will throw out this bill. The matter could be looked at at an appropriate time when, if ever, there was to be a change in the constitutional status of this country. This has not yet occurred and will not occur.

The bill before us at this time has no place in the Senate. There is no requirement and no need to change the oath of allegiance for Australian citizenship. I ask the government to withdraw the bill and to not bring it forward either in this fashion or at all until such time as it would naturally fit into a constitutional change in the country. I think the mere fact that the other oaths I have mentioned are not being amended and are not being capable of being amended indicates that there is no real substance to this, other than to try to boost the government's republicanism push and to enable it, quite wrongly and quite falsely, to get hold of taxpayers' funds to help them push this along.

There are other people who want to speak in this debate and there are other reasons that people have given as to why the matter should not be dealt with. To me it is quite simple and straightforward and the wording proposed I find appalling in any event.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Senator Panizza, do not start. I have listened to Senator Panizza talking about modern Australia. Senator Panizza never had to go through a citizenship ceremony because he was born here. —The republic has been a great success in Ireland.

PARA.TAB: The republic in Ireland has been a success because it can develop as a nation. Previously, Ireland has been held back as a nation because it was being controlled from outside. We are here because of the benefits and advantages of being an Australian under the Australian constitution and under the Queen as Queen of Australia.

But the mob on the other side somehow seem to think that they can just change history, change the world, change the country and promise everybody that everything will be great. It is interesting that those opposite make a lot of play about Australia being part of Asia. Let me tell them, as an ethnic Asian Australian, that Australia is not part of Asia and never will be part of Asia. Geographically we are a separate continent and, more importantly, we are completely different culturally. No matter how many ethnic Chinese we get in this country, we will still never be part of Asia. The people who come here come here for what Australia is now, not for what they have left.

It is peculiar that the mob opposite, who prattle a lot about Australia being part of Asia, were particularly silent this week when Cambodia, which was a communist republic in Asia, reverted to being a constitutional monarchy. Mr Keating and some of the people on the other side seem to think that we have to change our constitution and our oath of allegiance so that we can become a republic in the mistaken belief that we will become more like Japan, which is a constitutional monarchy. They even have the crazy idea that, if we change the oath of allegiance and insert this rubbish put before the chamber today, we will sell more wool overseas. They will tell you anything. But the problem with this mob is that their promises always fall short of what they deliver. They will sell you their grandmothers—but they will send her COD. The mob opposite have to be the weakest bunch of people ever to occupy the government benches.

When this country is in a financial and economic crisis which is without parallel, when they bleat every night on the television about the need to get the budget passed, what do they do? They bring before the chamber this nonsense of a bill. Senator McKiernan had the audacity to come into this chamber and say that it is one of the most important bills that will be dealt with by this parliament in this session. What a lot of hogwash! It is not blarney that Senator McKiernan brings to this chamber, it is bull—bull and unadulterated bull. I have not seen more bull since I opened a Santa Gertrudis sale about a month ago. It is bull from one end to the other. That is all we seem to get from this government.

I am steadfastly opposed to this bill. I am steadfastly opposed to weakening the requirements that we have of people who seek from us the benefits and advantages of citizenship of this country. I say: Australia for Australians. I welcome to these shores with open arms people who want to become Australians first and foremost. People who want to weaken the test and requirements of Australian nationality are unpatriotic. This bill is unpatriotic. Most importantly, this government is unpatriotic, not only in what it does but also in what it fails to do—to address the real issues of this nation. That is why it ought to be thrown out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard another great speech from Senator O'Chee—
—Were you listening to a different speech?

—He has put the coalition's position very well. He has said that he is steadfastly opposed to the bill and its contents. Let us look at what the opposition is opposed to. The opposition is opposed to recognising that Australian citizenship represents formal membership of the community of the Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: People on the opposition benches are steadfastly opposed, to use Senator O'Chee's words, to the proposition that Australian citizenship represents formal membership of the community of the Commonwealth of Australia. They are opposed to the proposition that Australian citizenship is a common bond involving reciprocal rights and obligations, uniting all Australians while respecting their diversity. They are opposed to the proposition that persons granted Australian citizenship enjoy these rights and accept these obligations. They are opposed to people who are going to become Australian citizens pledging loyalty to Australia and its people. They are going to oppose that proposition when they oppose the bill.

They are going to oppose the proposition that there is an obligation on people who become Australian citizens to share the democratic beliefs of Australia and its people. They are opposed to the proposition that people who become Australian citizens should respect the rights and liberties of Australia and uphold and obey the laws of Australia. They are opposed to a pledge which says `From this time forward under God'. They are opposed to the proposition that people who want to become Australian citizens should swear: `I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people, whose democratic beliefs I share, whose rights and liberties I respect, and whose laws I will uphold and obey'. Why should anybody be opposed to those propositions? Senator Sherry represents the state of Tasmania; I hope that the people of Tasmania would believe they were part of Australia and had an obligation to uphold the democratic rights of everybody in Australia—people who are citizens.

The present oath swears allegiance to the Queen. What we swear under the present oath is that we will be subjects, but under the proposed oath we would swear that we will be citizens of a country. I think there is a big difference in those propositions.

This bill does not make Australia a republic. It does not make the Queen anything that she is presently not, that is, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia. It does nothing in respect of either of those things. It does not make Australia a republic nor does it take it towards being a republic and it does not remove the Queen from her present position as Queen of Australia. What it does is emphasise to people who want to become Australian citizens the sorts of things they should keep in mind and expect when they do become citizens. Why would anybody oppose this quite beautiful pledge:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward, under God,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

Senator Kemp, for whom I have the greatest of respect and who sat on the committee which looked at this, will explain why he is opposed to those sorts of things. Knowing him, I know that, deep down, he is not opposed to the sorts of things that this pledge and this oath provide for.

PARA.TAB: This bill is very short, with 10 clauses. It contains an oath. If people do not want to take the oath to swear under God, they can make a declaration which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

They can do that on the basis of a preamble which emphasises Australia, emphasises those great qualities of Australian life—the democratic beliefs that we all hold strongly, the respect we have for rights and liberties, the determination we have to uphold and obey the laws of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see—and I think it is important to keep repeating this—why anybody would be opposed to doing that. It is a bill that I would have thought would have had the support of everybody across the board. It is a bill which former Senator Tate had much to do with. He is a person who needs to be given praise and acknowledgment for the work he did on this Australian citizenship bill. He is a person who is deeply religious, a person dedicated to Australia, a person who is one of the most respected senators ever to serve in this Senate and a person who produced this bill with all those aspirations that it manifests.

I will just say something about my good friend and associate Senator McKiernan, who was taken to task for swearing allegiance to the Queen to serve in this parliament. Senator McKiernan has made a great contribution while he has been here. He has an Irish background. He would not be alone in Australia, I hope, in having some connection with that great and magnificent country. The suggestion that he in some way swore allegiance as a means of obtaining something that he would not otherwise have obtained casts an aspersion on his character which is completely undeserved. He is as loyal and as great an Australian as any other person in this chamber, and I think that ought to be stated.

The other point he made is right. This is an important bill. We cannot go around being economic rationalists all our lives and we cannot go around being what is a derivation of that, that is, social rationalists who say, `There is no way we can improve the present situation except by eliminating more things that go to manifest the greater aspirations of the heart and soul of the human condition. We can't have that. It is unimportant that we should want to become citizens, that we should want to emphasise our citizenship rather than our subjugation to the Queen'. That is what we do when we swear the present oath of allegiance.

This is a very important bill. If one looks at its terms, it is very hard to see how people can vote against it. As I say, it has nothing to do with the republic. It has nothing to do with in any way insulting the Queen, a monarch for whom we all have great love and respect. That is irrelevant to the present debate. It is not irrelevant to the present debate that people who vote against this will be voting against the propositions that are set out in clause 3 and the schedule in clause 8. The schedule contains that pledge—that beautiful form of prayer almost—that people who want to become Australian citizens are asked to take and which manifests very clearly what is expected of them and which is very understandable.

The pledge must be very plain as to what people are doing, very understandable in the context of where it is sworn and very clear as to what it means. People do not swear allegiance to any particular person who may or may not be in a country. Rather, they swear that they will be loyal to Australia and its people; that they will be loyal to Australia's democratic beliefs, which they share; that they will be loyal to the proposition that rights and liberties should be respected; and that they will be loyal to the proposition that laws that Australia or the states of Australia proclaim will be upheld and obeyed. It is a very simple, very effective, wonderful pledge and one that is historic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney has just given us his usual defence of the government position.
—The indefensible.

—Senator Cooney is well known as the Kamikaze pilot of the Labor Party: he will defend the indefensible. Lately he is being considerably overworked because the government is finding itself in many positions in which it has to call on Senator Cooney's very great debating skills. Nevertheless, I do not think Senator Cooney was terribly convincing in his defence today. This is the third time in the 10 or 12 years since 1973 that the government has tried to change the Australian Citizenship Act and denigrate the pledge that people have to make to become citizens of Australia.
—They have no sense of history, those blokes.

—History seems to be a dirty word for the Labor Party. I have never been able to understand it, because if we do not have a past then we have a very doubtful future. The Whitlam government attempted to change the oath in 1973 to one that read:

SPEECH.PARA: I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution of Australia, observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
That was defeated, quite rightly, in 1973. In 1983 the Hawke government came in again with an amendment to replace the existing oath with this pledge:

I renounce any current citizenship and allegiance to any State other than Australia. I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
Again that pledge was defeated, and it was removed from the bill by an amendment in the Senate. We have to admire the government's consistency. It keeps moving forward on this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Moving forward—that is true; we are always moving forward.

—The government is moving forward, but it is moving forward in the face of opposition from Australia. One thing about Senator Schacht is that he is a political animal. I do not say that in a derogatory sense. He is one of the men who sets the pace for the Labor Party. I do not want to cast any aspersions on Senator Schacht's character. `Political animal' is a term that is used fairly significantly around this place. But even Senator Schacht would have to see that he is on a hiding to nothing.

PARA.TAB: I know Senator Schacht feels passionate about the republican issue. The debate on it has changed around. It is running out on Senator Schacht. Forty-four per cent of Australians are against it now and 39 per cent are for it. Once a debate turns around, it is a hiding to nothing. Senator Schacht will have to put his best foot forward to pick this up. I do not think the people of Australia want it. They have thought it through now. It is nothing to do with the royalty; it is about the Westminster system.

The people of Australia have thought this through. They think this Westminster system may have a few problems, but no-one can find a better system in the world. Through the smokescreen they are starting to see the government's attack on royalty and now they are starting to think, `Gee, we could lose the most precious thing in Australia—our Westminster system. We could de-power the Senate. We could emasculate the states'. All this is up for grabs. All this can be put in a package to change our constitution. That is where the government is going to go down the mine. People do not want a change. They are very happy with the Westminster system. They are very happy with the Senate. They are very happy with the states and with the state representatives having the right to do the job that they were elected to do. Now we have replaced this oath with a pledge of commitment which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward, under God—
and I acknowledge God in this place, as I always have—
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

Technically, I suppose, there is nothing wrong with that pledge; it reminds me of a bit of poetry. The National Party and the Liberal Party believe that the bill is misguided because it spurns the enduring traditions that are our inheritance.

PARA.TAB: I ask again: why do we always have this fetish in Australia with denying our past?. What is wrong with our past? We have proud traditions. We have grown up from a little nation into a proud nation that has the greatest rights and traditions in the world, yet for some reason that I have never been able to understand—and maybe Senator Schacht and I can discuss this privately; he might be able to explain it to me—there is a fear amongst the Labor Party politicians that there is something wrong with our past.

TALK.START.PARA: —When it is a National Party government, there is certainly something wrong with it in Queensland.

—I do not think Senator Schacht can really say that. Under the coalition governments of the past, Queensland led this nation in creation of jobs, in creation of wealth and in creation of most other things—something that this government has destroyed. All this government can claim is that it has caused one million people to be unemployed. The National and Liberal party governments in Queensland were governments of prosperity—something this government does not understand. The pledge of commitment, like the government's republican proposal, is founded on the Labor Party's belief that our institutions do not necessarily have to reflect our national identity.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner said in his second reading speech that the pledge of commitment would capture the current way in which the Australian people view their national identity and that this would continue to develop a special Australian identity. I think people are very happy with the identity that they have. I have been overseas from time to time and I have never had a problem with knowing that I was an Australian, and I have never felt ashamed of it. I do not know whether government senators do. I have always felt proud to be an Australian.

This is the same language that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) uses when he attempts to justify his push for a republic. He has said that it is hardly radical to suggest that our constitution should be remade to reflect our nation's values and aspirations. Senator Faulkner and the Prime Minister are wrong. They are proposing to change traditions and institutions that are precious to us all. They seem to have this in mind. They are proposing to change traditions and institutions that have been developed over hundreds of years in favour of pledges dreamed up by their own ministers and Treasury frontbenchers. I acknowledge former Senator Tate's commitment to his religion and to his God. He was a great person to have here.

TALK.START.PARA: —He got sent to the back bench; he was not that good.
—I thought he was pretty good. Maybe he was embarrassing a few people.
—He had to free up a spot for Senator Schacht.

—Maybe he had to free up a spot for someone. Senator Faulkner complained in his speech that the existing oath of allegiance had its origins in feudal times. This was the oath that people were given in feudal times and it is ridiculous to suggest that there is anything similar to it now. The oath said that in feudal England the king as liege lord was bound to maintain and defend his people in return for service and obedience. That is nothing like the oath that people take today.

PARA.TAB: The role of the oath has changed since then, but the oath that was taken in 1824 by Timothy Pitman, the first person naturalised in Australia, is a recognisable predecessor of the oath or affirmation that new citizens take today. That is another tradition that we have and the Labor Party is so keen to change. The long history of our oath of allegiance gives it weight, depth and feeling. Many residents who choose to become citizens find it deeply moving that they are reciting an oath that links them to our great traditions and to the hundreds of thousands of immigrants who took the oath before them.

It is a great privilege to be allowed to come into Australia. Very few people ever ask me to try to get them out of Australia. I would say most of my time in constituency work is spent trying to bring people into Australia. I have never heard anyone say to me, `I want to come into Australia but I am not prepared to take that oath, so if I have to take that oath just forget me and I'll go and live in Canada'. I do not think any person on this side, or any senator on the other side of the chamber—if they were totally honest—would say that immigrants had come to them and said, `Look, I do not want to take the oath'.

I was proud to take a similar oath as a member of parliament when I came here for the first time. It was the same oath that had been taken by Mr Curtin and Mr Menzies, Prime Ministers of Australia. I felt proud to recite, with my hand on the Bible, that oath that previous Labor and Liberal Prime Ministers had taken.

Senator Faulkner and the government now want to discard the oath of allegiance with all its historic associations and replace it with a pledge that really does not have a great deal to recommend it. I understand that Senator Tate flew to Taree and got Mr Les Murray to draft a new pledge, but I gather Senator Tate did not particularly like it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not fair to Senator Tate.
—Did he not substantially rewrite it?
—No, he didn't substantially rewrite it; he made changes to it.

—I understood that he substantially rewrote it. Let us say that he changed it. But Mr Murray said later that the pledge was clumsy and bureaucratic, so Senator Tate must have changed it significantly for Mr Murray to make those criticisms. Mr Geoffrey Barker described it in the Age as being pedestrian, bureaucratic, legalistic and a tongue twister. Someone else said that it had the poetry of a tax return. It does not refer to our head of state or to our constitution.
—It refers to Australia.

—Yes, but until the government wins this debate, whether it likes it or not the people of Australia will decide whether we have a republic or a head of state called the Queen of Australia. That is not the government's decision to make. The government is trying to lead the debate but it is not its decision to make. That is the people's decision, and when they have made that decision, or if they make that decision—and I do not think they will—the government would have every right to introduce this piece of legislation and change our oath of allegiance. The fact remains that the Queen is head of Australia. The government might not like it and might do everything that it can to oppose it, but it does not alter that fact. The government is getting too far in front of itself by bringing this legislation in now.

PARA.TAB: It is a sort of vague and insubstantial statement; it does not really mean a great deal. One of the justifications that Senator Faulkner put forward was that some residents are reluctant to apply for citizenship partly because they do not see the present oath or affirmation as being adequately Australian in character.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—That was the argument put by the other side. The question emerged as a political concern in the early 1980s when the Fraser government decided to institute national consultations on citizenships. The consultations produced evidence that suggested that a large number of permanent residents were not taking out citizenship because the government's 1983 bill was directed toward encouraging residents to take out citizenship by reducing the language requirement from adequate to basic and by reducing the residency requirement from three to two years. But what was discovered in that exercise was that people were concerned that if they took out citizenship in Australia, they would have to renounce their original citizenship and that that would not allow them to go back. That was one of the main reasons for that inquiry concluding that people were not taking Australian citizenship. So it had nothing to do with the Queen or an Australian oath of allegiance.

PARA.TAB: The latest Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs figures show—and I think Senator Cooney or someone opposite used the figure—that around one million eligible residents were not Australian citizens. These raw statistics conceal the fact that figures are obscured by a large number of British, Irish and New Zealand residents in Australia who believe that they are part of the British empire and part of the Australian political process and do not therefore have to take that extra step.
