Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That the following address-in-reply be agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! Before I call Senator Murphy, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and I also wish to thank other senators for allowing me to make my first speech. May I say at the outset that I am very proud to stand here as a new senator representing the state of Tasmania and the people of Australia generally. It is with a degree of humility that I take up this task but it is one that I will endeavour to perform to the fullest extent. Hopefully, I will meet the expectations the public have of their elected representatives in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: My pursuit of political life is born out of my working class background and the struggles that have confronted ordinary Australians over the time that this country has developed. They are struggles that I will continue to pursue during my time as a senator in this chamber.

I was born in the west coast mining town of Queenstown, Tasmania. My father worked as a fitter and turner at Mt Lyell copper mine and my mother was from a farming family in the north of the state. I attended school at the Hagley Farm and Prospect high schools. However, I was no great scholar and left school at the end of my third year of high school.
I had many jobs after leaving school, and at the age of 15 I headed for Queensland to work in shearing sheds in the outback.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good choice.

—Yes, and it was a good place too. During my time in Queensland I learnt to be a shearer. This became my job and life for the next 14 years. This was a period of great learning for me and contained many lessons about life. It was a time I enjoyed enormously and remember fondly. I worked throughout most states of Australia and met some wonderful characters and made many great friendships.

PARA.TAB: It was also my first real introduction to the trade union movement, something that was to have a profound effect on me in time to come. In the late 1970s I returned to live in Tasmania, with my interest in politics growing by the day. I joined the Labor Party in 1982 and became heavily involved in the Tasmanian branch of the ALP from that time on. In 1989 I became state secretary of the Australian Timber Workers Union, which is now a division of the CFMEU, the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union, a position I held until elected to the Senate.

This provided me with the opportunity to represent workers in an industry where employers had neglected to address matters such as training and education, that had pay rates that were not commensurate with the tasks performed, and where there was no recognition of skills and no career advancement opportunities. During my four years as secretary I saw many changes that were brought about by the efforts of the union—changes that not only improved conditions for workers but also improved the whole work process and led to greater productivity and efficiency within the industry. I believe I can say quite categorically that none of those changes would have occurred without the efforts of the union. I would like to congratulate the leadership of the union at both the national and state level on the great contribution they made and to thank them for the support they gave me.

Of course, not all employers would accept such processes. One example of this is the APPM dispute that occurred at Burnie. For the first time in a long time in Australia's industrial history, workers were confronted with the type of bastardry that the opposition would have us believe does not exist in this country—where an employer sought to deny workers the fundamental right to be collectively represented and organised. To their great credit, the overwhelming majority of those workers took the issue on and fought for what was right. They should be commended for their effort, their unity and their commitment to protect that fundamental Australian democratic right.

Obviously, industrial relations will be an area of keen interest to me. It is with the knowledge of the APPMs of this world that I have often noted, and with some amusement, the continual castigation of the trade union movement by members of the opposition. This action, plus the industrial relations policy it went to the election with, simply does not gel with the calls it now makes for fairer treatment of the working class Australians. It is policies such as those and the actions of many of Australia's employers that maintain my commitment to the trade union movement. I will do whatever I can to ensure its survival and the continuation of its role of representing workers of this country. In saying that, I do not imply a disinterest in or lack of understanding of the concerns and aspirations of Australian business, nor a disbelief in profit making or business success. I do understand and recognise these things because I know that without successful businesses there is no employment.

Of course, the opposition still clings to the belief that we have to get rid of unions to free up the labour market and allow bosses to sit down with their workers individually and supposedly work out a fair deal for all. However, one of the major problems with that approach is the management in many of Australia's companies and businesses. Because of their lack of foresight, initiative and general incompetence, to them a free labour market means reducing wages and conditions of workers and not working smarter or developing new products or, indeed, seeking new markets or improving the quality of products they produce. Of course, this leads to claims about the current industrial relations system—the system that is supposed to give unions all power.

I would like to give an example of how it does not and how employers are exploiting workers even under this presumably restrictive system. This example involved four unemployed sawmill workers who, in seeking work, had a proposition put to them that they could set up their own business and operate their own sawmill. The proposer of this deal would sell them the logs necessary to cut the timber and then would on-sell the finished product for them. Of course, they had no money to start with, so the proposer would lend them the first month's rent for the sawmill as well as some other money for outgoings.

They were informed that they could not draw wages until the mill made a profit but, in the meantime, they would receive $20 a week from this new found friend to pay for their petrol, et cetera, ensuring that they could still collect social security. This continued for nine months and, according to the bookkeeper—who just happened to be the proposer—the mill never made a profit, despite all of the timber being sold and no wages being paid.

It is that sort of thing that really leads me to maintain a great commitment to what is right for workers in this country. Those workers were not members of a union at the time. They finally sought the assistance of the CFMEU and, even under the current system, the union had great difficulty in doing something about it because of the way the deal was set up, the way this person was technically avoiding the law.

The matter was reported to the Department of Industrial Relations and also to the Department of Social Security—with little result. The union is now taking the matter to court to try to bring about some justice for these workers, who were trying to create an opportunity for themselves and who were being blatantly ripped off by some grub of an employer.

I could outline numerous such circumstances that occurred just during my time as a union secretary. So imagine how these types of employers would operate under the free labour market system being proposed by the opposition! John Howard's proposed office of employee advocate would have been the only area of employment growth and would have probably become one of the largest industrial relations departments in history. Even then, it would still not have been able to deal with the exploitation that would have occurred.

It should not be forgotten that the people of Australia rejected the opposition's industrial relations policy on 13 March. They were not prepared, even in the face of difficult employment times, to support policies which would have made things worse: they would have reduced their wages, put more of them out of work and placed them in a position of great vulnerability. As honourable senators are aware, the current system, whilst not perfect, has delivered stability and, in many respects, fairness; however, it can and will be improved.

The government is currently reviewing industrial relations legislation and, much to the disgust of those on the other side, it is consulting the trade union movement, along with industry. We recognise that, to have a process that can deliver in the interests of the country, we must take account of all views. The opposition, on the other hand, would not have done that. It would have simply legislated to outlaw unionism as Australians know it today. It would have reduced the current award system to a state of worthlessness; indeed, I believe it would have ultimately abolished the award system.

Given the outlook for employment growth in the short-term future, the exploitation of Australian workers would have gone out of control. We would have ended up with a society of haves and have-nots. And what would that have done for the economy? Not much, I think. People would be less able to save, with less to spend, and the result would be additional job losses to those already occurring through productivity and efficiency gains. This is not what Australia needs, and that is why Labor won the last election—because Australians believe in a fair go.

Whilst on the issue of fairness, I feel it appropriate that I speak about the achievements of 10 years of Labor in government and, in particular, about the current budget. When we came to office in 1983, Australia was an inward looking, protectionist, inefficient, uncompetitive country with double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and a confrontationist industrial relations system that had industrial disputation at record levels. We had poor education and training levels—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because you ACTU-ed it.

—Yes, Senator Panizza, the ACTU has done a lot to improve the lot of business in this country. We had a Third World pattern of exports and a government—the Fraser government—that chose to ignore the potential trade opportunities within the Asian region. A decade later the Australian economy has been transformed. Certainly we still have high unemployment, but the rest of the picture is dramatically changed. Our economic fundamentals have been dramatically improved through building a much more competitive economy, along with a cooperative approach to industrial relations; greatly enhanced levels of education and training, research and development and export assistance; a much more competitive business tax system; and a government that is promoting and pursuing trade opportunities in Asia as well as the rest of the world.

PARA.TAB: We now have the lowest level of inflation in 30 years; interest rates which are the lowest in 20 years; international competitiveness up by over 30 per cent since 1983; industrial disputes at the lowest level ever recorded; productivity increasing at a healthy 2.5 per cent per annum; exports of manufactured goods rising at 20 per cent per annum; service exports that now represent 20 per cent of total exports; and many small and medium manufacturing companies which are competing in overseas markets. In short, we have a much more innovative, productive and competitive economy than 10 years ago and, as a result, Australia is better placed to advance the welfare and living standards of its people. We have also built a much fairer Australia, with those on low incomes and those in need receiving greater assistance through better targeting of welfare and community services.

The government, during its 10 years in office, has been about vision and a clear sense of direction. We set out to transform the Australian economy, and we have. Australia is on a fundamentally different path now to that which it had followed for most of this century, and Australians have accepted this change in direction. Even the opposition, which governed Australia for most of this century and made it what it was up to 1983, has fully accepted this change, and its criticisms are not about the directions we have taken, but rather that we are not demolishing quickly enough the structure it put in place.

But where do we go from here? The government's objectives are straightforward enough. They are: to increase the rate of economic and employment growth, thus increasing real incomes and reducing unemployment; to enhance the level of our domestic savings, which is an essential element of addressing our balance of payments problem; to continue the process of making Australia a creative, innovative manufacturing nation; to improve the international environment for our export industries by new and improved international trade arrangements; to establish a new vocational education and training system which will better meet the needs and priorities of industry; and to continue to enhance social justice in our society. Therefore, there should be no doubt about where the government is taking the nation. The record shows that we are headed in the right direction.

These measures have been continued in the latest budget which, despite all the claims, maintains a fairer society and yet continues the program of returning this country's economy to a stable and vibrant position for the future. Of course, we have not solved all of our problems, and one of the fundamental issues that we must continue to address is that of unemployment. Although we have put in place substantial labour market programs for the next 12 months, including the continuation of programs such as newstart, jobclubs, LEAP, NIES and so on—which have been very successful in getting people into full-time work—we cannot rest there.

Personally, I believe there are some areas that must be given special consideration. In particular, we should look at imports which come into this country. I do not believe we can continue to allow imports to come into this country without a greater requirement for identification of the country of origin. The buy Australian program must be revitalised and the loopholes that allow the current system to be rorted must be removed. We must be able to guarantee Australians that when they seek to buy Australian they really can buy Australian. This is a matter I intend to pursue with some vigour, particularly in the area of forest products, which represent around 10 per cent of this country's imports.

Obviously, part of the process of addressing import replacement will be business investment and development. However, a lot of Australian companies seem to be sitting on their hands in this respect. But there are now good reasons why investment should commence: profit shares are at quite high levels and rising; and the gross operating surpluses of trading enterprises are at high levels compared to this stage of recovery from the previous downturns in the mid-1970s and 1980s. It is also 22 per cent higher than it was in March 1983 when Labor came to office. Real unit labour costs have been virtually stable. All this, coupled with low inflation and interest rates and further business tax concessions in the budget, has provided a better business investment outlook for the future.

The budget measures are, of course, important. Together with business tax concessions announced in the One Nation package, they form a comprehensive array of incentives. They also provide a very competitive tax regime compared to those of our trading partners, even our Asian trading partners. The new company tax rates are 33 per cent, down from 39 per cent—something the opposition was going to increase to 42 per cent had it won the election. I must say that there have been some interesting comments from business about that.

The strategy on which this year's budget has been based is to enhance growth in the short term through further expenditure for job creation and tax cuts, which will lead us into a longer term recovery that will come as the world economy picks up. What I now find difficult to understand—in fact, almost inconceivable—is the current position being adopted by the opposition in respect of this budget. On the one hand it claims to want fiscal responsibility, yet on the other it is opposing the government's revenue raising measures. I can understand its disappointment at losing the supposedly unlosable election, but Australians should now judge it for the reckless disregard it is showing for the welfare of this nation.

Another area of concern to me is our economic relationship with New Zealand. While I believe it is necessary and important, I find it difficult to accept the imbalance that lies in the employment related area. I know that the Senate has conducted inquiries into some aspects of this, but the problem still seems to exist. Regardless of the explanation, I do not see why the people of New Zealand should be treated differently from people from other countries when it comes to working in Australia, or vice versa for that matter. It should be noted that, on current figures that can be identified, the New Zealand work force in Australia represents about two per cent of our current unemployed people, and I believe this is unacceptable.

I would now like to turn to two other key issues facing Australia today. The first relates to land rights and native title, which have been highlighted by the recent Mabo decision. In essence, this decision provided us with the opportunity to appropriately address something that has been wrong for so long. The unfortunate thing about the debate is that some interest groups have tried to politicise it. All sorts of instant experts have come out of the woodwork, none more notable that Hugh Morgan of Western Mining. He made all sorts of statements about land claims but there was one claim he was not telling us about—that was the greatest claim jumping exercise in Australia's mining history, and he lost. However, regardless of all the politicising and disruptive tactics of some, the government will introduce legislation that will do something genuine about this longstanding and unacceptable situation. I hope that all honourable senators will support such steps.

Finally, I would like to speak about Australia becoming a republic. This is something I have supported for a long time, not because of any disrespect for our historic links with Britain or the monarchy; rather, I support it for the reasons that it should occur. This country has developed socially to the point where it is necessary for us to become a republic if we are to gain a sense of completeness. For me, it is the only way that a full sense of pride can exist for all of Australia's people. It will be like the completion of a long journey or making the final payment on something one has never owned. Regardless of people's views, I do not think anyone could reject the notion of having an Australian as head of this country.

Surely the most recent event of Sydney winning the 2000 Olympic Games brings home the importance of having a head of country and, indeed, a flag that would truly be our own. I am sure it would seem odd to other countries that, following our competing against Manchester, England, for the Olympics, we then turn around and have the Queen of England open our Olympics. There are no valid reasons why we should not become a republic. We should get on with the job and instil even greater pride in this great country.

In closing, I would like to thank my wife, who is here tonight, for the support she has given me and to congratulate her on becoming the first woman to be elected as a state secretary of a union representing workers in the timber industry. I would also like to acknowledge my trade union colleagues who are here tonight and to thank them for travelling so far and for making that effort. I would simply like to say to them, `Keep up the struggle; the workers need you'. Of course, to my two staff members here today, Vicki and Yvette, I thank them for the tolerance they have shown during my preparation of this speech.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!
Debate (on motion by Senator Schacht) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to congratulate Senator Murphy on his maiden speech. Obviously, if he can pull such a crowd from Tasmania as is in the President's gallery at the moment, he must have been a very popular unionist, and I congratulate him once again.

PARA.TAB: Before Senator Murphy's initial contribution we were debating the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993. I was saying that there are about one million people in Australia who have immigrated to Australia and who have not become Australian citizens. Sixty-one per cent of those people have Irish, British or New Zealand origins. As I said before, those people felt that they were part of the society and part of Australia, but had not become Australian citizens. A further study showed that 40 to 60 per cent of residents from non-English speaking Mediterranean countries, north-western Europe and Third World countries became citizens almost immediately. Overall, 80 per cent of those people from those countries became Australian citizens.

The study showed that the most important reason why people did not become citizens was that many countries did not allow dual citizenship. I suppose people needed to feel that if they were not satisfied here, they could go back to their original country. The study also showed that the oath or affirmation were not significant reasons why migrants did not become Australians. The myth that has been perpetrated from the government side of the house that they did not become citizens because they had some fear of, or opposition to, taking the oath of allegiance is simply not correct. The government believes that it has a monopoly on history.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have Manning—they can keep Manning.

—Yes. The Prime Minister has said that the Labor story has always been very much Australia's story. I think the government's understanding of Australian history began with the 1890 shearers' strike which the ACTU has commemorated as the founding of the Labor Party.
—Well it was.
—That is the history of the Labor Party, but it is not the history of Australia.
—The important part of it, though.

—It is a significant part of it; I would not say it was a most important part of it. The government does not understand that national institutions, such as the current oath of allegiance, are precious because they are steeped in history, and history is part—
—Did you know the oath of allegiance off by heart before this speech?

—Yes, I did know the current oath of allegiance. If Senator Sherry wants to have a personal discussion, we can have dinner together tonight and debate this. The government has a misunderstanding of the history of our national oath of allegiance. The powers and responsibilities of our three branches of government were defined over the course of six centuries: they are the legislative, the executive and the judiciary. They all form part of our history. The political events that clearly established parliament's power to control the government's finances was King Charles's attempt at personal rule. He tried to rule for 11 years.
—He had his head chopped off.
—Yes, he did. He could not work with the parliament due to the controversy that erupted when his officials attempted to collect two taxes. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. It is significant and important and, in respect of the development of the Australian identity, it is a great bill. I hope the Senate has the courage to pass this bill. I note that the report from the committee indicated that the majority of the committee supported the bill, with the Australian Democrats representative, Senator Spindler, abstaining. I understand that Senator Spindler will be moving a minor amendment which the government will be happy to support. Therefore, I trust that, with the support of the Democrats and maybe the other minor parties in the Senate, this bill will be carried.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has vehemently opposed this bill from the beginning, in the committee and here again today in the Senate chamber. I find that an astonishing attitude to take. I note from the report of the committee that opposition senators want a complete review of the total act and then they will look at something in the future. Obviously, that is an attempt to disguise their own opposition to any change to the oath of allegiance and to this bill.

The opposition does not desire to give any credit to this government, the Democrats and other people in the community who want, in an evolutionary way, to move forward the development of the Australian identity. Opposition senators want to oppose it because they are petrified that the present government—in particular, the present Prime Minister—may get some political credit and some community recognition for these proposals. This is really a political campaign to ensure that the present Prime Minister and the government are denigrated in every way possible. What we see today—and it is in this report of the committee—is quite astonishing in that those opposite again assert that this bill is a disguise, a front and a diversion from the real issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—Whatever I may think of the capabilities of opposition senators—and I do not think they often have that many capabilities—I would have thought most of them could think of, and deal with, more than one issue at a time. I quote the famous remark of the late President Johnson about Gerry Ford: `Unfortunately, Gerry Ford can't walk and chew gum at the same time', which means that he could not deal with more than one issue at a time. The opposition is admitting that it cannot deal with more than one issue at a time. Opposition senators may want to denigrate themselves, but to say that the Australian community cannot deal with more than one issue at a time—
—We haven't said that.

—Those opposite keep saying it. It is in the minority report—it says that it is a diversion. We have heard them all the time saying this is the number one issue, which we have never denied, but that the only issue those opposite want to deal with is the economic issue and they say all of these other issues are diversions. The Australian people are quite happy to participate in either side of the debate. They can deal with it. If Australian people had listened to the opposition's view back in the 1890s, we would never have got Federation. In the early 1890s we had the worst economic crises in this country's history and, at the same time, we developed the Federation. We were able to have referendums to establish the Federation of Australia, despite Australia going through the worst economic crisis since white settlement began.

PARA.TAB: So it is astonishing that those opposite can assert now that issues such as this are a diversion. I think this parliament is quite capable of dealing with many issues. I still think opposition senators are stupid. I would not mind their saying that they are opposing this on other issues, but to say that it is a diversion, that people cannot handle this issue or that those opposite cannot handle it, is just absurd. The parliament is here to handle many different issues every day.

This simple bill contains what we now call the pledge of commitment as a citizen of the Commonwealth of Australia, as well as the preamble, as amended by the Australian Democrats, which reads, `recognising that Australian citizenship represents formal membership of the community of the Commonwealth of Australia; and Australian citizenship as a common bond, involving reciprocal rights and obligations, uniting all Australians, while respecting their diversity; and persons granted Australian citizenship enjoy these rights and undertake to accept these obligations by pledging loyalty to Australia and its people, and by sharing their democratic beliefs, and by respecting their rights and liberties, and by upholding and obeying the laws of Australia'.

The Bill sets out the pledge of commitment that people swear when they become citizens of Australia at citizenship ceremonies around Australia. I, like every member of this chamber, have attended citizenship ceremonies at which people have taken out citizenship under the existing oath of allegiance. I believe—I have certainly had anecdotal evidence given to me; I cannot prove the numbers—that there are migrants in this country who will not take out citizenship because they want to swear allegiance to Australia rather than appearing, as they see it, to swear allegiance to the Queen of England. There have been reports in the press that, in the last few months since this legislation was introduced into the parliament, people turning up at citizenship ceremonies to become citizens of Australia have been upset that they cannot use the new oath of commitment. This is an indication that people want to be loyal to Australia and want to be able to take that pledge.

The opposition is not interested in those people. It wants to use an oath of allegiance that is clearly written for the 19th century. This is indicative of where the politics of the opposition are. Its politics are the politics of the 19th century. It cannot cope with progressive, evolutionary change in respect of the identity of Australia, the feeling of pride that Australia can stand alone and the belief that Australians want to identify with their own symbols and not the symbols of another country.

That in no way denigrates the role and standing of Her Majesty the Queen of Australia and Queen of Great Britain, but is a recognition of the fact that this country is evolving its own identity. All honourable senators opposite want to stop that because they have another political agenda. They just cannot conceive, and do not have the graciousness to say, that the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the present government may be doing the correct thing in respect of Australia's national identity. They do not want to concede to the government what they consider to be political capital.

As I have said in previous debates, these are the politics of the permanent opposition. I have said before that this is the first time since federation that members of the non-Labor side in the Senate have not had ministerial experience. That is the truth. Nobody opposite has had to accept ministerial responsibility and the responsibility of being in government. Opposition members have ended up like the Labor Party unfortunately was in the 1950s and 1960s: satisfied with being in permanent opposition, collecting the money for being here, but not really wanting to be in government. That is where opposition members are at.

Those opposite are adopting procedures in this place that reflect the fact that they form a permanent opposition. They cannot conceive that they could be in government again, and that is why they have adopted this attitude towards this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is going to happen in South Australia in a few weeks?

—I am glad Senator Kemp mentioned that. In South Australia the Liberals may; we will wait and see. The opposition was very confident in February this year that it would become the government. The Liberals in South Australia are very confident that in the next few months they will be in government. But just as members of the federal opposition ended up with egg on their faces on 13 March by losing the so-called unlosable election, they should not bet too much on the result in South Australia just yet.
—Do you want to bet?
—They should just remember that they were so cocky all through 1992 that they were going to win the election. Unfortunately for them, they are still sitting on the other side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I return to this important bill. Once the Senate passes this bill and its provisions are publicised and made available, I anticipate that many more people will come forward to take out citizenship in Australia. They will see that this oath of commitment is, for them, a commitment to Australia and the society they want to be a part of rather than, in the case of the present oath of allegiance, a swearing of allegiance to a head of state on the other side of the world.

Again, I in no way want to denigrate the role of Her Majesty the Queen. Unfortunately for her, some of the carryings-on of the other members of the royal family in recent times have not added great lustre to the monarchy in Great Britain. I suppose that in all modern families these days we have to accept that, though we may try for perfection in our family lives, these things occur. But Her Majesty has carried out her constitutional functions without any criticism.

Honourable senators opposite would have noted that the other day Her Majesty the Queen authorised the Prime Minister to say that she would accept whatever advice is given by her ministers in Australia. This was a natural, proper and appropriate constitutional comment. I agree that there was nothing sensational about it. Of course, some people opposite would have hoped that the Queen had not said anything other than what was entirely appropriate.

This bill, which will be carried this year, will be another step forward in what will be an ongoing debate in this place and, above all else, in the community about how Australians see themselves and what sort of function they want for their government during the rest of this decade. I notice that Senator Boswell quoted a particular opinion poll today. I do not get too carried away about opinion polls, which can have us 15 per cent ahead or 15 per cent behind on this issue.

There will be a considerable amount of toing-and-froing over this issue. That is why it cannot be rushed. I have never argued for there to be a rushed debate. It will take some years. The people of this country need to feel confident that when ultimately a referendum is put to them they will understand all the ins and outs of what they are voting for.

Another issue involving national symbolism is the national flag. Mr Coates, the President of the Australian Olympic Committee, made an interesting comment in the last couple of days. He indicated that he thought it would be useful to have, even by the time of the Atlanta Olympic Games, an Australian flag without the Union Jack that is totally identifiable with Australia. He pointed out to his critics, including Mr Howard, that he has marched four times behind the existing Australian flag at Olympic opening ceremonies.
Mr Coates pointed out that he finds it a confusing symbol. He hopes that by the time of the Atlanta Olympic Games—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he that dumb?
—It is a confusing symbol to the rest of the world in terms of our presence and recognition.
—He is more intelligent than that.
—Just read what he said. As far as I am aware, Mr Coates has never played any political role in Australia.
—Doesn't sound like it.
—Senator Kemp may want to attack Mr Coates, who played an outstanding and seminal role in winning the Olympic games for Sydney.
—The symbols were so confusing for the rest of the world.

—I know that those opposite must have listened to his remarks with some chagrin. He raised the issue quite sensibly and openly. He also pointed out that the decision regarding the flag is one for the Australian Parliament to make. He also remarked that the republic is an issue to be decided by the Australian people. He said that of course the Olympic Committee would accept whatever the decision of the Australian people may be. But his personal view was that a new flag for Australia without the Union Jack would be preferable. Of course, in the year 2000 he would like to see an Australian citizen, as the Australian head of state, declare open the Olympic games. It is all part of the public debate and it is ongoing.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by pointing out that honourable senators opposite are in a lather over some aspects of this debate. I believe that one reason they are starting to lose election after election is that out there in the community—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the flag.

—That is the mistake that Senator Kemp is starting to make. People in the community always know that when it comes to substance and interest in the broader issues the Labor Party, not the opposition, is the one doing things. I suppose that some of this may be sentiment and some of this may be emotion. Arthur Calwell—he was not a successful Labor leader by any means, but a successful minister for immigration who established the immigration program that has brought millions of people from around the world to make this a multicultural society and a much better society—once said about his personal philosophy and the identification of the Labor Party that `we are Labor because we are Australian, and we are Australian because we are Labor'.

PARA.TAB: At some university that remark may not be, in philosophical terms, absolutely correct but, in emotional terms, it sums up what the Labor Party and Labor movement is about. It sums up our identity as Australians and why we are proud to take on the debate about our identity and not afraid to raise the issue of change for the future in an evolutionary way.

If the opposition keeps boxing itself into a corner we will be more than happy. Those opposite may think that our fifth election win was a mistake, but the way they are going on they will make it certain that we will win the sixth and the seventh election so that we will still be in government when Australia is declared a republic on 1 January 2001. This bill, which I hope the Senate carries, is another important step forward for Australia's changing national identity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate concerning the oath of allegiance. I oppose the bill that the government has brought forward.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht mentioned Arthur Calwell in his closing remarks. Despite the fact that I am a Liberal, I acknowledge the fact that Arthur Calwell was a great Australian. Arthur Calwell had many features. There is an interesting quote in Hansard to show what a great supporter Arthur Calwell was of the Australian flag.

There was a debate between Arthur Calwell and Mr Menzies during a debate on a bill relating to the flag in 1952. One member referred to the blue in the flag as the blue which reminded him of the clear Australian sky. Arthur Calwell said the blue in the flag reminded him of the Eureka flag. Arthur Calwell was a very strong supporter of the Australian flag as was Dr Evatt, Ben Chifley and Curtin. The history of the Labor Party, right up until the time of Paul Keating, regarding national symbols was at one with the Australian nation.

In this debate we see how Labor is not only constantly dumping on Australia's history but also constantly dumping on Labor Party history. It was Dr Evatt who described the Australian flag as the most beautiful flag in the world. There is a very famous quote from Dr Evatt relating to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the young Liberals.

—Senator Reynolds's knowledge of Australian history is weak but her knowledge of Labor Party history also shows significant gaps. It was a great irony that Senator Schacht chose to lecture us about what he saw as a foreign queen. It was Senator Schacht who moved the motion at the Hobart conference to make Australia an independent nation, as he called it.

PARA.TAB: It was Senator Schacht who also brought down quite an interesting report entitled, A review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. When we are debating the independence of Australia, I invite Australians to look at that report because in that report Senator Schacht, the mover of the republican motion, also advocated a recommendation that Australians have access for domestic disputes to UN committees. For the first time since the passing of the Australia Act of 1986, when the Australian legal system became self-contained, Senator Schacht decided that the government should open up appeals by Australians in domestic disputes to foreign judges. Senator Evans has called this the new internationalist agenda.

Senator Schacht claims that he treasures the independence of this nation and comes into this chamber and lectures us about the need to make Australia more independent. There is an interesting page in this report where Senator Schacht refers to the need to make a declaration under article 41 of the ICCPR, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. By signing this particular article and removing the reservation, other countries for the first time have the right to make complaints against Australia and those complaints will be judged in a foreign court with foreign judges.

I put it to Senator Schacht that there are many paradoxes in his character. He has been constantly opposed to censorship. I remember him constantly chiding Senator Walters over this matter but he wanted to censor political advertising. He wanted to censor the publication of Odgers.

Senator Schacht reached the height of hypocrisy when he moved motions about the independence of Australia. He has reversed the philosophy of the Australia Act of 1986 and he has opened up the Australian legal system to foreign courts. I dare say that he will be recalled, to the extent that he will be recalled at all in Australian history, as the man who reversed the philosophy of the Australia Act and for the first time involved foreign judges in our legal system. So he should not speak to us about the independence of Australia.

There is another different point of philosophy that came through in Senator Schacht's speech. His concern was with what he called the developing Australian identity. That is the code that Senator Schacht and his colleagues use to say that they are unhappy with the current Australian identity. One can hold that view. I do not hold that view.

I put to Senator Schacht that a lot of Australians are very proud of their country, very proud of their history and very proud of their current identity. They do not believe, unlike the Paul Keatings and the Senator Schachts of this world, who are so worried about our current identity, that we need to develop it further. Certainly over a period of time things change and people change. I put to Senator Schacht that to suggest that something is wrong with the current identity of Australia is a philosophy or view not shared by most Australians.

The subject of this debate is the oath. I congratulate my colleagues Senator Short, Senator Reid and Senator Boswell for the contributions they have made and the way they have analysed the oath which the government is wishing us to change to and the way they drew attention to the features where this oath seems to lack coherence. There are

SPEECH.PARA: two areas of the oath I find quite extraordinary. The first is—and Senator Bolkus will remember this—that there is nothing in this oath which suggests that we should be forswearing all other allegiances or putting Australia first and foremost.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that if those opposite were going to come into this chamber and try to beat the patriotic drum—I must admit that given Senator Schacht's record of encouraging foreign judges to become involved in Australian disputes, it is a beat which sounds distinctly discordant to my ears—it would not be unreasonable that the section of the oath which the Labor Party removed in 1986, which had the phrase `forswearing all other allegiances', might have been incorporated. But of course it was not.

It was interesting that when Mr Abbott from Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs he put some views that there should be some amendments to the current oath. He suggested that the words should be along the lines of `forswearing all other allegiances'. When a representative of the Australian Republican Movement came before the committee I put to him, to make it clear, that this oath should be assertively more Australian. He said that he did not feel that was needed; in fact, he felt that could be regarded as a divisive element. If we are really wanting to beat the nationalist drum, surely those words, which have been part of the oath for a large number of years, should be included? Senator Short read the American oath to the chamber. It includes the phrase:
I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereignty.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an assertively American republican oath. Of course, in Australia, under the somewhat equivocal nationalism of the Labor Party, such a sentiment is not acceptable. We see in the current oath that there is no element of any loyalty to any particular institution, constitution or head of state. That is another weakness of the oath of allegiance.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting, because of the nationalism that Senator Schacht tried to manifest in here, that there was a debate in the cabinet about whether the word `nation' should be included in the oath. Those great nationalists in the Labor Party—Mr Keating and his ministers—reflected on whether it was really politically correct to include the word `nation' in the oath. Former Senator Tate was kind enough to inform the committee investigating this bill that the Labor Party felt that the word `nation' did not have the right resonance for the current period. Again, it shows just how equivocal the Labor Party is on these particular issues.

Senator Cooney said that he felt this debate we are having today should not be confused with the republican debate. I think Senator Cooney was wrong. This is entirely part of the republican debate. Anyone who, like myself, has a great respect for Senator Cooney and the contributions he makes to debates would listen to his comments and think about them. But Senator Schacht made the point that the oath is indeed part and parcel of the Labor Party's republican push. It is part of that wider debate. We do not know what sort of republican constitution the Labor Party wishes to put forward to the Australian people. I believe, with good reason, that the Australian people are becoming increasingly nervous about the sort of republic that Mr Keating would have in mind.

One person put it to me that the case against the republic could be summed up in two words—President Keating. I think it is a telling point that people are concerned about what sort of country Australia will become led by a man who has lowered the standards of his office to an all-time low, who attempts to politicise every major activity in this country, who speaks about our past history in a way which I think repulses most patriotic Australians and who goes home to Ireland and says he is returning home.

I will tell the Senate where my home is. My home is here in Australia. When I return home, it is to my home here in Australia; I do not return home to Ireland. I make that point without any disrespect to my Irish grandparents who came out to Australia. They undoubtedly brought with them a lot of the Irish spirit which we so admire. But Ireland is not home to me. It may be home to Mr Keating, and I think most Australians wish that he would go home, and go quickly. Our home is here in Australia.

It showed the quality of the man when Mr Keating came home after Australia won the Olympic Games—which gave all of us a great boost; what a great achievement it was—and immediately attempted to politicise the games. He tried to enlist the Olympic Games to the wider Labor agenda. The government backed off that particular issue pretty rapidly when the Australian public, through talkback radio, made known its view of Mr Keating's contribution to this issue.

The oath of allegiance is part of a wider debate on the republican issue. It is a desperate attempt to remove what the Labor Party sees as an offensive symbol in the oath of allegiance. I have to say that no people are faster to swear allegiance to Her Majesty than members of the Labor Party when they win office. When Mr Keating stabbed Mr Hawke in the back he was quickly up to Yarralumla to swear the oath of allegiance as Prime Minister. There was no concern or hesitation in the Labor Party at that time about any oath which contained a reference to Her Majesty.

I want to make a couple of final points. As a member of parliament I make a habit of attending as many citizenship ceremonies as I can, as indeed do Senator Short and my colleagues here. I have always been impressed by the diversity of people who are becoming Australian citizens. I spend some time speaking to them and listening to their views. Not one of them has ever expressed any concern about the current oath, and I have been to many citizenship occasions. This is a total furphy raised by the Labor Party in an attempt to pit Australians against Australians.

We are involved in a major debate about Australia's constitution. Australia today is a very tolerant, peaceful, multicultural society—a society which I believe is probably the envy of most countries around the world. Indeed, Tina Turner's song, which was played before the rugby league grand final, could equally be applied to this country—it is Simply the Best. We have come as far as we have because we have constantly built on the foundations of our history. I do not believe there has been a generation of Australians which has not been intensely proud of this nation and wanted to build it further.

There has never been a leader in Australia who has not been proud of this country, who has been confused about the country's identity and who has not felt a sense of pride when he sees the Australian flag flying—except Mr Keating. That is Mr Keating's great contribution to this country after 92 years of democracy and federation under a constitutional monarchy. We are, as I have said before in this chamber, arguably the world's oldest continuous democracy. We have come this far because of the inherent values of the Australian people which we have cultivated and nurtured; because of the institutions and systems of government which we have developed; the role played by our churches and so forth.

What we are seeing is an attempt by the Labor Party to denigrate the past—those things that have gone before and created this country that we feel so proud of, the things that have enabled us to win the right to host the Olympic Games. In fact, the only person confused about the Australian flag at the IOC occasion, when we were given the Olympic Games, was apparently Mr Keating. The rest of the Australians there did not suffer Mr Keating's particular confusion, and indeed felt that great flush of pride which pulsed through the nation on hearing that Sydney had been chosen to hold the Olympic Games.

In the broad sweep of history this will not be seen as a major development. It is a pity that this bill has been brought forward, and it is a pity for this reason: it is another divisive, nasty attempt by the nastiest, most divisive Prime Minister in Australian history to pitch Australians against Australians. When Mr Keating goes home to Ireland and he feels that flush of pride, he should understand that when Australians come home they, too, feel that flush of pride. They feel a great pride in their own history. The Labor Party spits on our history at its peril.

This debate has a long way to run. I regret the way Mr Keating is running this debate. The only way the debate can be run is to say, `We have a better constitution which will improve the lot of the Australian people'. He can run that debate, but I say,`When you run that debate do not spit on our past'.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I thought the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 was being called into aid by the government in its campaign for a republic, I certainly would not vote for it, even at the second reading stage. I had intended to vote for this measure at its second reading stage. There is no-one in this chamber who would not agree with me that the Australian Citizenship Act needs amendment. Of course it needs amendment.

PARA.TAB: This was adverted to in the dissenting report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs by Senator Vanstone, Senator Kemp and Senator O'Chee. They quoted Sir Ninian Stephen as saying that the act is an `abysmal document', that not only is it an extraordinary example of legal and bureaucratic language but that it is extraordinarily inappropriate for its title. The dissenting senators went on to say, `We believe it is inappropriate to make piecemeal amendments prior to such a full-scale review'. I am inclined to the view that the amendment being put is not piecemeal. There are certain features of this bill—leaving aside the pledge—which many people would not have any objection to and which would improve the bill.

I have listened to the republican debate and I am concerned that there is now an attempt to call into aid certain questions, certain issues that should not be called into aid, namely, the amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act. There is also an attempt to call into aid religion to sustain a particular position on the republican issue. That would be the most inappropriate action for anyone to take because it only heightens and fosters what we least need in this community—sectarianism.

I listened to what Senator Cooney had to say. Senator Cooney, who is Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, assured the Senate that this was not part and parcel of the government's program to achieve a republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Schacht then went on to contradict him.

—I heard that, too. It is now for the minister to say precisely what the government's view is on that matter. Let the government tell the Senate whether it considers this measure being presented to us today as part and parcel of its moves towards a republic. I am prepared to debate that issue on its merits. Certain issues have not been adequately canvassed in that arena thus far. I go to the question of land and the rights of the Crown, and to various other key matters which have been discussed but which need mature consideration.

PARA.TAB: I am prepared to agree to this matter going through the second reading stage, provided that we get official indication from the minister, as Senator Cooney has indicated, that this measure is not part and parcel of the republican push. I say that because I recall this debate last year and, quite frankly, it did not hit me as being part and parcel of a republican push. I recall speaking to our former colleague Senator Tate about the wording that is now proposed for the pledge of allegiance. I would like to see some of that explained in the committee stage as well.

There is a need to have incorporated into the principal act a preamble that sets out what the actual meaning of citizenship is and what it represents. There is an attempt to do that in clause 3 of the bill. It would be illuminating for the Senate to consider that in the committee stage. Unless I hear from the minister in his reply that Senator Cooney was wrong in assuring the Senate that this was not part and parcel of the republican debate, I will support this measure at the second reading stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to conclude this debate, let me at the outset reflect on some of the proposals put forward by Senator Spindler. It is the government's intention to agree with the amendment circulated by Senator Spindler to clause 3 of the bill; that is, that the third phrase in the preamble be amended to include the words `undertake to' before the words `accept these obligations', so that the full text of that phrase will now read, `persons granted Australian citizenship enjoy these rights and undertake to accept these obligations'.

PARA.TAB: We do so because we feel that the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats strengthens the commitment that one has to make to citizenship and to Australia as a nation. It does so by demanding an active act rather than the passive words that were in the text and that are in the text now. I indicate that we support those and, hopefully, those words will be passed by the Senate.

Senator Spindler also requested that the preamble should be read at citizenship ceremonies. I undertake to ensure that the act is implemented in such a way that the regulations pursuant to it provide for the preamble to be so read by ceremony administrators.

I also agree with the third proposal of Senator Spindler which is to adjust the citizenship certificate to include the words `and having undertaken to fulfil the responsibilities of a citizen'. I think they also are words that demand an act on the part of those who are being granted citizenship.

Having said that, and given that there does seem to be some degree of support in this place for the new oath of allegiance, let me say at the outset that the government sees that, with the passage of this legislation, this parliament will be doing a number of things. It will be reflecting the nature of our changed society. It will not be taking that act of republicanism that Senator Harradine was talking about. It is not a formal recognition of a republic Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are dumping on the Queen, Nick, aren't you?

—Look, little boy, just calm down. It does reflect the nature of the society that we now have in Australia. It is a changing society. It is a society which now consists of some 140 different ethnic communities. It has changed enormously and radically in the last 20 to 30 years. It is working extremely well, and it is working well because not only is the composition of that society so diverse, but also this parliament has a deliberate policy—and a bipartisan one at that—that has as its benchmark an inclusive approach to our society. It says to people of different religions and different ethnic backgrounds, `We respect your right to celebrate your religions and your diversity, and we will ensure that there are mechanisms in place to ensure that you can enjoy those rights, privileges and religions in a way that is tolerated, supported and recognised by the rest of society'.

PARA.TAB: The approach we are taking is inclusive and to that extent we can be compared with many other parts of the world which take an approach to migrants coming to live in those countries which excludes them from full participation in the society in which they live. I have just spent some time in Europe and I have been able to witness the difference between this country and others when it comes to how migrants and people of different ethnic backgrounds are included in the life of the societies of such countries. I have seen the racial tensions that exist in other parts of the world. It is not very hard to analyse those tensions and those societies, and to appreciate that when you start excluding people—when you start oppressing them and repressing them when they want to enjoy and maintain the sorts of traditions that they have lived with for generations—you will get those sorts of racial tensions.

We in Australia have an inclusive approach and when it comes to an act like the citizenship act and the rights of citizenship we are once again inclusive. We do not, for instance, bar people from application forever, nor do we bar them from application to rights of citizenship for eight to 10 years as some countries do. We say to them, `Come to Australia, spend time here, prove yourselves as good citizens and after a short period of time you will be entitled to the rights of citizenship'. That is an important aspect in ensuring that people feel as if they are part of a society and have a commitment to the core values of the society.

That is the other aspect of what makes our society so strong. Being part of Australia does not only mean that you can enjoy those traditions and religions and ethnic backgrounds, it also involves a commitment to a common core set of values and principles and institutions. We need such a commitment. We need to have that spelt out. The citizenship pledge, which we have had in legislation for decades—one that has had change in the past—needs to reflect those core values, those core principles of the institutions that we hold as fundamental to our society.

By putting up this particular piece of legislation the government is updating the legislation in such a way that it does reflect the bonds that are common to all Australians and that unite Australians. To that extent, it needs to be a distinctively Australian commitment. It is one of a series of national symbols that we have in Australia and as such is a symbol—

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't the constitutional monarchy a core institution? Why are you afraid to answer the question?
—You have had your go. I put up with you earlier on. You either keep quiet or you get tossed out. I have put up with you long enough.
—Order!
—Can't you handle the interjections?
—Order! It is not question time, Senator O'Chee.

—What we are seeing this afternoon is this parliament legislating, this society moving on, and this Senate moving on, without the opposition. The opposition lost the last election, not only because its economic policy was out of sync or out of tune with the aspirations and the needs of the people, but also because it did not have a social policy with which society could bond. Its policy did not recognise sufficiently the nature of women in our society or the nature of the multi-cultural aspects of our society.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite have been barricaded into the values of the 1950s. Some of them are smart enough to know it and they are not getting involved in this particular debate, but a lot of them do not. Once again, they have been led from behind, led by the rural rump, led by those who really have not had a new idea—a new concept—for decades. What we have seen this afternoon, as we saw yesterday and as we will probably see tomorrow, is the opposition delving into the garbage bin of rhetoric. That is all those opposite have—no substantive new ideas, no grasping of the reality of where this society is going and no grasping with the concept of where we are and what our imperatives now are.

We are no longer six states and two territories competing against each other for markets. We are now one nation competing with Asia and the rest of the world for markets in the fields of technology and of commerce. We are now living within a world which no longer has people staying in one part of the world and not moving. With technology and with communications the world is moving very quickly. Money is moving quickly, financial corporations are moving quickly, jobs are moving quickly and, with that, people are moving quickly. The only force in politics and the only force in our community that has not grasped that is the opposition.

It has been barricaded into the past. It lost the last election because it has not responded to that social change and it is in danger of doing the same again—not because next time it will not have a social policy but because next time it will have an anachronistic social policy, one that does not take into account what sort of society Australia is and what the needs of that society are.

Those opposite have come in here this afternoon lost in those arguments and in the rhetoric, talking about antiquated values, but for most of the time, what have they done? They have abused the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). They have set out to abuse the Prime Minister personally and denigrate him, saying that he is lower than life and whatever. This is the same person about whom they were saying these same things this time last year and it is the same person who gave them a hiding at the election earlier this year. He gave them a bath because he tapped into what Australians are thinking and what direction Australia is now taking.

I have no doubt—and I did not support the Prime Minister when he was making a run for the leadership—that he will be remembered as a pioneering Prime Minister, one of vision, one of guts and one who was prepared to make the changes to fit Australia in a way that would make it adequate and appropriate and fit to fight the battles of the end of this century and into the next century. He recognises both the economic imperatives and the social imperatives, and no degree of abuse from the other side will undermine that reputation which he will have into the future. No degree of abuse from the other side will detract from the fact that there is an irreversible tide in the electorate moving in the same way as the government is moving, in the same way as the Democrats are moving and in the same way as other forces in this place are moving, but which is not being responded to by the opposition.

As I say, we need to have an oath of allegiance which reflects the core values of Australia and which is a bonding instrument, and we can do so without any disrespect to our sovereign—absolutely none at all. No-one from this side and no-one from the Democrats who has participated in the debate in this place or outside of it has said anything negative about our sovereign. She is the Queen of Australia and whilst she is that we will go through the processes and we will pay allegiance, as the Prime Minister did when he went to Yarralumla to be sworn in, as we all did, in conformity with the law in the country. Our obligation is to the law as it stands. But the reality is that there is an anachronistic situation in that we in Australia swear an allegiance to the head of state of another country.

I was at a dinner last night in Parliament House where the first toast was to the President of Lebanon, who was there as the official guest. The next toast was to the Queen of Australia. I hoped that the person next to me, the President of the National Assembly of Lebanon, really appreciated how the Queen of England found her way into the proceedings of the night. It is an uncomfortable situation, but it is part of the law and as part of the law we obviously observe it.

Senator Short has mentioned the need for a revision of the Australian Citizenship Act. I want to place on record the government's appreciation, and my appreciation, for the work that former Senator Tate did in crafting this amendment, with the assistance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and cabinet. Senator Tate took a very deep interest in this proposal. We should recognise the work that he has done, and I gladly do so. I see the amendment that Senator Tate initiated on this oath as being very fundamental and one that has been able to be proceeded with without the need to address other aspects of the act. It is one that the government has been keen to ensure would proceed without being hindered by other considerations in respect of the Australian Citizenship Act, so we are proceeding with it.

Very early in my time in this portfolio I said that I have been considering the rest of the act and how that also needs to be reassessed by government. I agree to a certain extent with the words of Sir Ninian Stephen that the act needs a fair degree of updating. Some of the basic principles of the act are fundamentally right and they do allow us to manage the process of citizenship in a positive way. I am looking at ways that the act can be reviewed and I expect that before Christmas I will be able to make some announcement as to how we can proceed on that broader issue. I have made those comments before today, both domestically and overseas, and there is nothing new in them.

I see this amendment as fundamental and one which can and should proceed. This amendment recognises and reflects a changed Australia. It reflects the sort of Australia we now have. It also acts as a very fundamental instrument which reflects a need for common values, common institutions and common principles. As a consequence, the government and I personally are very pleased to be initiating this sort of change to our legislation.

PARA.TAB: I also wish to acknowledge the minister's commitment to insert certain words into the citizenship certificate that will be given to all people who take citizenship.
