TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the minister. It relates to the statements and undertakings that he gave during the course of his second reading speech. One of those was not particularly clear, so I take this opportunity to ask the minister again. He said that it was necessary that our oath, pledge or whatever other phrase will be uttered by migrants who assume Australian citizenship recognise the `core values and institutions of the country'.

PARA.TAB: Given that the constitution sets out the core legal and constitutional institutions of this country, why is it that this particular pledge, which the government is putting forward in this bill, seeks to completely ignore one of those core institutions, which of course is the constitutional monarchy, as contained in the Australian constitution? Does the minister believe that the constitutional monarchy, as contained in the constitution, is not a core institution of this country; or does he believe that this pledge has missed one of our core institutions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very obvious question and one that has been canvassed from time to time over recent months. The government's position has been that both in the preamble, where we talk about upholding and obeying the laws of Australia, and in the pledge where, once again, there is reference to upholding and obeying the laws, we anticipate, as part of the core values and core institutions of this country, that those values and laws will be adhered to, particularly the laws.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee asked whether the Queen is an institution within the Australian constitution. I think everyone acknowledges that the Queen has a very important part in the constitution. What we are talking about though is swearing allegiances to the democratic beliefs, rights, liberties and laws of the country. In terms of an oath of allegiance for citizenship one does not have to take the next step and swear an oath of allegiance to the Queen. We obviously recognise that the Queen is part of our constitutional make-up, but what we are saying is that when one swears an oath of allegiance to obtain citizenship, one does not have to go through a specific act of swearing allegiance to the sovereign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee raised a very interesting point. He, like I, has probably noted that the vast majority of citizenship ceremonies are conducted by local authorities—a core institution in our society. Unfortunately, it is not a core institution that is recognised by our constitution, and that brings to the fore another anomaly in a constitution which is now close on 100 years old.

—Having heard Senator McKiernan's persuasive words, I am starting to think that this pledge is more and more defective every moment. Not only has the pledge left out the Queen, who is part of our constitution, part of a tripartite system of government, but Senator McKiernan tells us that this pledge has left out other key institutions of this country.

PARA.TAB: The point is this: the minister gave us an explanation that we had to have a pledge that recognised the key institutions of this country, yet the minister's explanation for leaving out the Queen is that there is a reference to the laws of this land. The laws of this land are very important, but there is a hierarchy of norms in this country. The laws are part of a set of institutions, but we have to recognise that there is an institutional process for creating those laws. If we merely say that we are going to abide by the law, that is a fairly meaningless statement. If you do not abide by the law, you get put in gaol. It is so fundamental that I just cannot understand why the minister still chooses to leave out any reference to the constitutional monarchy.

The minister has told us that this has absolutely nothing to do with the republic. Why then does he oppose the reference to the Queen in this pledge if it has nothing to do with advancing the republican cause? I can see my friend Senator McKiernan over there straining like a greyhound in the slits looking forward to the passage of this bill. I know what Senator McKiernan's views are and I respect that they are different from mine. But the minister cannot escape the fact that this bill has an ulterior motive—and that is to advance the cause of the republican movement by weakening the adherence of Australian citizens and new Australian citizens to the institutions of this country.

At a time when we should be seeking more national unity to overcome the adversities which face our nation, it is particularly disappointing that this government seeks to bring into this parliament massive changes to citizenship in this nation through the change of the oath of allegiance. Yet this government will rely on a majority of but a handful to implement these changes. There is no way that an emotive change, a divisive change like this, can be passed with just a handful of votes. Technically and legally it can be passed; but for the good of this nation should it be passed on a handful of votes?

TALK.START.PARA: —What majority do you want?

—Well, if we are to unite this nation, unity can only be achieved where there is broad spread agreement. The division that we have just had in this chamber, the evidence that was presented before the committee and the enormous opposition to this from community groups from one end of this country to the other show that this bill and this change is divisive. It shows that this bill and this change do nothing to unite Australians but further set Australian against Australian.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take Senator Bolkus's interjection because I have more courtesy and manners than he does. What was Senator Bolkus's interjection? He is silent because perhaps he realises that most of the time he interjects it is not worth listening to, even if some of us will accord him the courtesy of giving him a second chance. Senator Bolkus probably did himself a favour by not repeating whatever it was he had to say. If I know him, it was pretty meaningless to start off with.

PARA.TAB: I say to this chamber that if we adopt this bill we will do nothing to unite this nation. If we adopt this bill we will set Australian against Australian and will create divisions in our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blood on the streets.

—Senator Chris Evans may want to have blood in the streets, but I do not. I come from a background that has had quite enough blood on the streets. If there is an ethnic group in this country that has had enormous persecution it is the Chinese; they know all about blood on the streets. The reason why many of our Chinese community are here, for the same reason that my family is here, flows from the benefits and security of our constitution. Senator Chris Evans may shake his head, but he has never had to live with it; he has never understood it because he was born, as I was born, in the days of the White Australia policy.

PARA.TAB: There is one fundamental difference between Senator Chris Evans and me: he has never had to live with the ethnic background of not being part of the White Australia policy. I come from the other side of the coin; I understand the ethnic divisions. So please do not come into this chamber and joke about putting blood on the streets, because some of us find it particularly offensive.

Some of us find particularly offensive the way that this Labor Party, when it had the opportunity, sought to drive people out of the country on the basis of the colour of their skin. This was the Labor Party that created the White Australia policy. It was the Labor Party that refined that instrument of racial oppression—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee, it might be better to get back to the bill.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, this is related to the bill; it relates to the motives of the government. Of course, the question is whether the bill stand as printed, and I am advancing the point that the bill should not stand as printed on the basis—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I speak to the point that you raised, Mr Temporary Chairman, and that is with respect to the discussion that Senator O'Chee is getting into at the moment. He is drawing an enormously wide bow in seeking to bring in the history of white migration in this country on this particular point. This is the committee stage of this bill, and one does not want to open up a discussion about discriminatory policies or otherwise and going to the 1960s and to the changes that the Whitlam government introduced to bring in a non-discriminatory policy after 23 years or so of discriminatory Liberal Party policy and so on. I think that is very much outside the ambit of this committee stage and I think, Mr Temporary Chairman, you ought to pull the honourable senator up.
—It is the committee stage of the bill and policy statements are made in the second reading debate. I would ask the honourable senator to confine his remarks to the contents of the bill.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I certainly shall confine my remarks to the contents of the bill. I am arguing, of course, that the bill as it stands is defective. The bill overlooks entirely and completely disregards one of the core institutions of this country. The standing orders recognise the fact that I have a right to develop an argument as to why that core institution should be recognised. Of course, Senator Bolkus, in taking the point of order, has tried to introduce new matter. Mr Chairman, you will understand, of course, that under standing orders he is not entitled to do that. I did not object to him introducing new matter in the standing order. But I will take the opportunity to point out, given that the minister has intervened in the committee stage, that it was not in fact the Labor Party that abolished the White Australia policy; it was the coalition government in 1967.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, further to the point of order: you have asked this honourable senator to restrict himself to the second reading stage and not to discuss policy. I have not introduced any new matter; I have reinforced the point you made. I think what he is doing is abusing your ruling and going on to discuss the policy issue which I think is very much outside the ambit of this part of the proceedings.
—I think Senator O'Chee is now confining his remarks to the bill, and I would ask him to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I have said before and I say again that this legislation is defective, and I do not believe that the bill should stand as amended. I really feel that for this bill to stand as amended is as ludicrous as the spurious arguments we have heard that the Labor Party changed the White Australia policy. We know that is a nonsense, in the same way that the suggestion that this bill stand as amended is a nonsense. This bill is technically defective in failing to address the fact that we have a core institution in the constitutional monarchy which is not recognised. I know that brings a great deal of disappointment to the minister, but it is a fact. It is a fact that the wording of this bill has overlooked the wishes of a large number of Australians.

PARA.TAB: So when we come to look at the question of whether this bill stand as amended, I say that this bill should not stand as amended. Although we have had amendments from Senator Spindler—and good amendments they were, and I support them; and Senator Spindler raised or foreshadowed similar amendments in discussions with us in the committee—I say that this bill still is not good enough. That is why I argue that this bill should not stand as amended.

I say that this bill should not be accepted by the committee of the whole because of its manifest defects, its manifest omissions and because it seeks to divide one Australian from another. I know that may be perceived as a policy argument, but we now have a bill in a new form from the original form we had. I was hoping that we may have had some amendments that might have improved the bill and really taken into consideration what the minister said about recognising core values in this country, but we did not have those amendments. So I have a right and an obligation to stand before the committee of the whole and say that the bill should not be accepted; that the committee of the whole should not accept this bill because, in its current form, it still overlooks all those issues that I have raised during the course of my speech.

I know it may pain the minister and some of his cohorts on the other side, but I would be failing in my duty if I did not point these things out. There is enormous danger when we have the tyranny of the barest majority. One always opens the way in issues such as this to intolerance, to racism and to bigotry—and some of us have lived with the consequences of those for far too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of points to make. Firstly, I wish to comment on Senator Spindler's amendment and, secondly, I wish to ask a question of the minister. Much to my surprise, I notice that Senator Spindler has left the chamber. The opposition did not oppose Senator Spindler's amendment to the bill. It was a worthwhile amendment which improves the situation. I want to make it clear that in supporting that amendment the coalition in no way indicated a changed attitude towards the bill as a whole. I will say something about that at the third reading stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with all legislation, it is drafted by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, which gets advice as to the legality and constitutionality of what it is doing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short has come up with oral advice, advice that on first hearing does not appear to have much substance. I am sustained by the fact that this legislation has gone through the process very well. This legal advice comes curiously at the last moment. We are used to spurious legal advice coming in in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned it in the second reading debate and I have mentioned it on previous occasions, including in my statement back in May.

—Without going any further into it, we have absolute conference in the legality of this pledge. That is sustained by the fact that in its drafting it has gone through the normal process of testing in relation to the legality and constitutionality of government legislation.

—I was going to ask a similar question to that asked by Senator Short. The current form of the pledge talks about allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia. According to the Macquarie Dictionary, the term `allegiance' means the obligation of a subject or citizen to the sovereign or government; duty owed to the sovereign or state; observance of obligation; or faithfulness to any person or thing. The new form talks about loyalty to Australia and its people. One of the problems with the word `loyalty' is that it generally attaches to a person. That person is to be the person who symbolises and epitomises, in a constitutional sense, the country's core values.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister: has the government considered the legal implications of changing the form of words where `allegiance' applies to a person who symbolises and constitutionally epitomises the country to the words `loyalty to Australia'? What does the word `Australia' mean in the new pledge? That is what I would like to know. I am seeking this information generally. The minister might also advise the chamber as to whether, in the event that there is a republic and a president of the republic, it is the intention of the government to change this pledge to return it to `allegiance to' in reference to the president of the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, we are trawling over old ground. On 23 June in this place Senator Tate answered much the same point that Senator Harradine raises. I do not think one can put it any better. I will quote what he said from the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . `I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people'. This is the affirmative, positive act indicating a solemn commitment, an allegiance to Australia and its people. `Australia' is used there in a very simple expression but it has various levels of meaning. Obviously, there is the political entity, the Commonwealth of Australia. Loyalty is being expressed to that political entity, the name by which we are known amongst all the nations. But there is also a geographical and physical sense, which should not be totally discounted—the place. There is a commitment to Australia as the place where we are fortunate to be, the sunburnt country . . .
Senator Tate goes on:

. . . the land abounding in nature's gifts of beauty rich and rare. In other words, we could have used the term `Commonwealth of Australia', but that would have been too restricting. `Australia' is just used in its simplicity with these various levels of meaning. So the loyalty commitment is meant to evoke obligations to Australian society, the political entity and the land itself, the place where we are.

I think that covers Senator Harradine's point. I think Senator Tate's comments also cover the point about precedents. It is a loyalty to the political entity, the land itself and the place where we are, and that encompasses the institutions of Australia in those senses. There is no intention to go on and do the things that Senator Harradine is worried about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a technical question for the minister. The wording of the pledge as it stands refers to Australia and its laws. As Senator Harradine has pointed out, that replaces an allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors. As Senator Harradine again quite rightly points out, allegiance in that sense requires obedience to the laws duly passed. The Queen is head of state not just of Australia but also of each of the individual states. So allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors requires obedience to the laws of the Commonwealth and each of the states. The wording which has been substituted in its place relates to the laws of Australia.

PARA.TAB: My concern—and I hope the minister can address it—is that this seems to leave out an obligation to obey the laws of each of the states, which are not mentioned in this provision. It would appear that the substituted wording does not catch the full meaning of the allegiance or obedience which is required in the existing oath of allegiance. I ask the minister whether this matter has been examined and on what basis is there an argument for saying that this proposed wording may include an obedience to the laws of each of the states, which are not expressly mentioned here and which are separate governmental systems?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If one looks at the relevant provisions of the previous affirmation or oath, one sees that there is a reference to bearing allegiance to Her Majesty, her heirs and successors according to law, and that is a distinct aspect of it. The previous oath or affirmation goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

That reference to the laws of Australia obviously embraces the laws of the national government, the state governments and the institutions under the constitution. The words that are now being proposed are `loyalty to Australia whose laws I will uphold and obey'. Once again we have the political entity and land entity that Senator Tate talked about. The reference in the new pledge, as opposed to the previous provisions, is very similar. It refers to an obligation to faithfully observe the laws and uphold and obey the laws of Australia. There is no difference between now and previously. It is very clear that any legal reading of the current pledge or the previous provisions indicates a need to uphold and obey the laws of Australia on a national, state and territory basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want to delay matters by speaking on those previous areas. I wish to make absolutely clear in this third reading stage how strongly opposed the coalition is to this divisive, pre-emptive and very dangerous bill.

PARA.TAB: I wish to pick up a couple of things that have been said since the second reading debate. In particular, I refer to a remark made by Senator Spindler in his contribution on the second reading of the bill. In support of the bill and the removal of the reference to the Queen in the oath or affirmation, he said—if I got him right—that we should be rejecting this symbolic relic of the past.

Senator Panizza, who followed Senator Spindler, found that remark very highly offensive. I also find that remark very highly offensive. Like Senator Kemp, who also spoke in the second reading debate, I am insulted and very angry at the recent attempts by the government and some of its supporters or fellow travellers to rewrite the history of this country. That is what has been going on here for a lengthy period. This government has become a past master at attempting to rewrite history. It is attempting to rewrite immigration policy, our multicultural policy and a whole host of other policies that really go to the core of our history and the values that have built this nation.

The remark made by Senator Spindler, perhaps unconsciously, adds to that. But even worse, Senator Spindler is simply wrong. The symbols that we are referring to are not relics of the past. Even Senator Bolkus accepted in his remarks just a while ago that the Queen still is central to our constitutional system, which is the whole framework on which our society, government and parliament are based.

The symbols referred to by Senator Spindler and by other speakers, particularly government speakers as a matter of denigration, are the present basic living symbols of our present basic living institutions. They are not just symbols; they are part of the essential working framework of this nation. Those symbols, those essential parts of our basic framework as a nation, do nothing at all to detract either from the multicultural nature of our society or the perception of our nation. On the contrary, what they do is enhance and enrich those great values, attitudes and attributes of our nation.

Many of us in the Senate—I know the minister does—spend a great deal of time talking with a very wide range of people across the spectrum of Australia. I spend a great deal of time talking with the leaders and average members of the so-called ethnic communities of non-English speaking backgrounds in all states and regions of Australia. In my discussions with those people, I have never had any view at all expressed to me on any concerted basis on the question of the reference in the existing oath and affirmation to allegiance to our head of state, to our Crown, to the centrepiece of our constitution.

Indeed, to the extent that I have heard comments proffered to me, they tend to be the opposite; they tend to express a great pride in the act of citizenship—and rightly so—and what these people are swearing allegiance to. The government, without any grounds for doing so, is sweeping away very prematurely those living symbols; they are not in any way relics of the past.

It distresses me very greatly—I will come back to this a little later in relation to Senator Harradine's request for an assurance from the minister about this—to see this bill being used in such a blatant way and as part of the push for a republic agenda. That is what all this is about. This is a deliberate, calculated attempt to hijack the republican debate and to pre-empt the outcome of it.

In that desperate, headlong rush to achieve his personal ambition and agenda, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is running some very grave and dangerous risks that are causing great potential damage to this country. It distressed me greatly—I am sure it distressed every Australian greatly—to hear that, during the Prime Minister's recent visit to Ireland, he was reported as saying just a few days ago that he is a republican because he is a Catholic. I have seen no refutation of that comment.

In other words, the Prime Minister, in his personal push towards building an agenda for an Australian republic is resurrecting the ghost of sectarianism that blighted this country through much of our history and which, thank God, we got rid of decades ago. When the government starts to do those sorts of things, to use this chamber, this forum and this bill to achieve its agenda, it is about time we said, `Hey, hang on. Let's have a long, hard and careful look at this'. The whole approach to this is offensive to most Australians. It is disgusting, dangerous, divisive and, above all, un-Australian.

The minister, Senator Bolkus, very rightly talked about tensions in other parts of the world. I could not agree with him more on that point. He is correct to compare our tolerant, inclusive, multicultural society with those tensions overseas and to draw attention to the fact that we have the great virtue of having escaped those tensions in Australia because we have done it right. We in this country must do everything that we can to preserve that tolerant, harmonious, enriched and diverse yet united society. It is our greatest gift and treasure.

What is this government doing? It is seeking, through this bill and in other ways, to divide the Australian people, not to bring them together. It is seeking to pursue policies which endanger our tolerant, generous and united nation. It is not only this bill that is doing it, although it is an important part of the agenda. Look at the government's handling of Mabo and all the legislation and debate surrounding that. Look at its handling of industrial relations issues and a myriad of other things. They all add up to a very long list of very divisive approaches.

Senator Harradine, in his very wise comments, sought assurance from the government, through Senator Bolkus as the minister, that this bill be not part of a republican push. I may be wrong, but I do not think Senator Harradine received that assurance. But even if he had, what earthly weight could he place on it? There can be no doubt that it is an integral part of the Prime Minister's headlong personal rush down the republican road at any cost—regardless of the cost to social stability, social harmony and the basic tolerance of our great nation.

If it is not part of that agenda—I put this to Senator Harradine and other members of the Senate—why bring on this obviously contentious and very sensitive change at this time? There is no urgency for this bill and there is no urgency to change the oath or affirmation of allegiance. There is no pressure to do so from the ethnic communities or any other sections of the Australian community.

Given that we are now in the middle of an ongoing and emerging debate about the future constitutional arrangements for this nation, the obvious and proper course of action would have been to let that debate run its course, to await the outcome of that debate and to find out the wishes of the Australian people to see what the clear majority of the Australian people feel about it. If they want to change our constitutional arrangements, so be it; that is fine.

But the Australian people need to decide that, not be pre-empted and hijacked in the process by a government which represents, at best, less than a majority of the Australian people. The obvious, proper and logical course would have been for this issue—the question of the oath of allegiance and, particularly, the deletion or continued inclusion of reference to the Queen as our head of state and the cornerstone of our constitution, which is the cornerstone of our nation—to be considered after we had concluded the debate and reached our views as a nation, a community and a people on whether we want constitutional change involving the Queen.
We are putting the cart before the horse in debating this matter in this way and with this timing. There can only be one logical reason for that, which is that it is part of the republican agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Republicanism by stealth.

—As Senator O'Chee says, it is an important part of the republicanism movement by stealth. The fact is that this bill is highly divisive within the Australian society and nation. It is premature in terms of the ongoing debate that we have. As I said, only when there is clear evidence of the need for change and a clear majority support for that change should we contemplate making the changes envisaged in this bill. There is not that need or clear majority. Indeed, the contrary is the case.

PARA.TAB: To proceed with this bill and these changes at this time is a course which I believe this government and, more particularly, the Australian people will rue because it will be part of a divisiveness that this nation can desperately do without. For all those reasons, I reiterate in the strongest possible terms the coalition's total opposition to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the advanced hour, I shall confine my remarks to a few very brief ones. A country's historic heritage is one of the most valuable possessions it has. It is part of a country's culture and substance. That does not mean to say that at every time in a nation's life we must try to retain everything that it had in the past.

PARA.TAB: That is what I meant when I made those remarks. Those remarks have apparently caused some distress to Senator Short and other honourable senators. I meant no disrespect to the Queen. But the fact is that the Queen is not part of the future of Australia. She is not here and she is not part of our national life at this stage. We must move on. The message is, in taking the action that the Senate is likely to take tonight, that we must point to the future and say that we must be loyal to Australia, to Australians and to the future of Australia and not loyal to a person who is essentially the monarch of another country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a difficulty that is part and parcel of things that have been said around the chamber today; but it may go beyond that. The question that may arise is why have a head of state at all. A head of state is supposed to be a person who represents the core values of our society. That person should be looked up to. That person is regarded as impartial and free from the partisan, political shenanigans that go on in a country.

PARA.TAB: Originally I felt that the words that were proposed in this amendment to the Australian Citizenship Act were far better than the words that are currently contained in the act. Having heard what Senator Short and the minister have said, my problem is with the question of to whom do we pledge allegiance. It is all very well to say that we pledge allegiance to Australia and its people but who is it that represents the core values, the constitution, the ideals and protects the people and, indeed, the parliament. That person is the head of state. That person can be the Queen of Australia or the president of Australia.
I believe that this matter needs further consideration. I suppose it will go through tonight. Under those circumstances I feel bound to vote against the third reading.

PARA.TAB: (4) The report prepared by scientists that contains these recommendations has not been publicly released.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 September, 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of the statement by Bill Mollison in his book `Permaculture: A Designers' Manual' that 93 per cent of chickens in battery cages develop cancers.
(2) Is the figure of 93 per cent correct; if not, what is the correct figure.
(3) Has any assessment been done of the potential health implications to consumers of the presence of cancer in battery chickens; if so, what are the possible risks; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister is aware of Mr Mollison's statement.
(2) The figure of 93 per cent is not correct.

The "correct" figure depends on the definition of "cancer" used. There are at least 100 different forms of cancer in chickens. The most common form, seen in birds of less than 22 weeks of age, is Marek's disease. The more common cancer in older birds is called leucosis. There is an effective vaccine for Marek's disease and commercial layer flocks are vaccinated, and in addition are from leucosis free stock. The frequency of leucosis in layers is less than 1%. Backyard and free range chickens also suffer from these cancers, usually at a much higher rate than commercial layers.
(3) Most chicken meat in Australia comes from broilers slaughtered before 7 weeks of age. These birds have a low, even negligible cancer rate.

Assessment of the potential health implications to consumers of the presence of cancer in battery hens shows that there is no association between the consumption of chickens in general and human health risk, and none between the consumption of battery hens with, or without, cancer.

There are no risks because virus diseases of animals, including chicken cancers, are species specific. Very few virus diseases will cross species barriers, and then only between closely related species such as monkeys and man and sheep and cattle.

The risk to consumers from eating chicken meat from battery hens is extremely low because, in addition to the species barrier, the meat is cooked before eating. Most bacteria and viruses are destroyed within a few minutes at 70(o)C. In addition the concentrated acid in the stomach and intestinal enzymes of the consumer will further degrade and inactivate viruses.

(2) No, I am advised by the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service that licence conditions have not been breached in the area and that no such area has been clearfelled.

(3) Yes. On 22 December 1992 I wrote to the Hon Garry West MP, the then NSW Minister for Forests, and the Hon Chris Hartcher MP, NSW Minister for the Environment, enclosing a list of areas likely to have high conservation values, for consideration by the State under the conservation policies of the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS). (5) The NFPS did not repudiate the 1990 agreement. It is the Federal Government's full intention to implement the important conservation initiatives outlined in the NFPS.
